TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. I refer him to the statement this morning by the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories in which she confirmed that Cabinet reached a conclusion last night about the States' proposed tax sharing arrangement, that there was not much right with the proposal, and that the Prime Minister would be making an announcement today on that matter. Was the Minister correct in these statements? Why did she pre-empt the announcement of the Cabinet decision? On whose authority did she speak?
—She is partially correct and partially incorrect.
—Fire her.

—I will tell you what: she gets it correct more often than the mob opposite does, at any rate. It is correct that the Cabinet considered this matter, amongst a number of other matters, until about 1.30 this morning. Where the Minister did not have it correct is that there was no intention on my part or on the Treasurer's to make any detailed comment about the Cabinet decisions last night. But I will say this for the benefit of the Leader of the Opposition: it needs to be clearly understood that this issue is to be the subject of discussion between the Commonwealth and the States at the Perth Special Premiers Conference. Let me make it clear that the proposal put to me by Premiers Bannon and Greiner last week was intended to help prepare for those discussions; it was not intended as a substitute for them. They stated clearly to me that the States' present proposal is negotiable. We in the Commonwealth are also finalising the elements of the position that we will take to Perth.

PARA.TAB: In that context, let me say that the Cabinet has considered the paper put to me last Friday by the States, and we have concluded that the present proposal for a `shared national personal income tax' is, for all practical purposes, a State income tax. As such, it is not something which this Government could support.

In conclusion, the Government is conscious of the States' understandable concern to achieve a greater degree of certainty in the financial resources available to them—that is an entirely understandable concern—and we are considering means by which more certainty in Commonwealth disbursements might be achieved.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Resources and relates to petrol pricing and the Government's fuel excise. What taxes are presently raised by the Federal Government from excise on petrol and diesel? Are these taxes high by international standards? How do Australian petrol prices compare with those of our major trading partners? What would be the impact on Australian Government revenues of a substantial reduction in petroleum excise?

—As honourable members would be aware, there is currently no sales tax applying to petrol. However, there is a petrol excise which is levied on volume. The excise rate on petrol is currently 25.7c per litre. The excise on petroleum products is expected this financial year to raise in excess of $7.5 billion in revenue—around $4.3 billion for petrol and $2.5 billion for diesel.

PARA.TAB: Petrol taxation in Australia is very low by international standards; in fact, Australia currently has the second lowest level of petrol taxes and the second lowest petrol prices of the 20 International Energy Agency countries. Only the United States has lower petrol taxes than Australia. Petrol prices in Australia at the moment are about 68c per litre, of which the petrol excise accounts for about 37 per cent. But what are they overseas? In New Zealand petrol prices are close to 80c per litre; in Britain and in Germany they are over 100c per litre; and in Japan they are around 125c per litre. Petrol prices are even higher in countries such as France, Denmark, Ireland, Finland, Portugal, Norway and Sweden. In Italy they are over 170c per litre. Although we would all like to pay less for our petrol, Australia is doing very well relative to our trading partners and the rest of the world.

The final part of the honourable member for Fisher's question was: what would be the impact on Government revenues of a substantial reduction in petroleum excise? It depends on the extent of the reduction, of course. As an illustration, last Thursday a report run on Sydney radio 2UE by rural reporter Linda Allen quoted National Party sources as indicating that under the coalition's consumption tax proposals there could be a drop in the price of petrol to as low as 45c per litre. Another 2UE report referred to a drop to less than 50c per litre.

On the basis of these reports, the Liberal's consumption tax proposals would mean the equivalent of about a 20c per litre reduction in petrol excise. The revenue cost of a 20c in the litre reduction in the excise rate for both petrol and diesel would be around $5.2 billion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha!

—The Prime Minister laughs and I concur with his mirth. This is a massive revenue reduction. The basic question which must be answered is: where is the money coming from? On the basis of those reports, there is already a revenue gap in the Liberal's proposals of billions of dollars which needs to be financed.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —If Opposition members do not understand that fundamental, they are in deeper trouble than I suspected.
—I don't believe this. What a joke!
—Order! The Deputy Leader of the Opposition will cease interjecting.

—As a matter of logic, not a matter of interjection, that means the consumption tax must be set quite high merely to accommodate this proposed action on the petrol front. That in turn leads to a fundamental question: what is the consumption tax rate going to be? It is quite clear that, whatever rate members opposite start with, it will only be the start of an inevitable upward slope as the consumption tax rate goes higher and higher. That is, in the words of the former Leader of the Opposition, as sure as night follows day. But history shows that one cannot trust the Opposition on these issues.

PARA.TAB: I do remind the House that when we discuss these matters of credibility in relation to tax matters—and the honourable member for Bennelong obviously is very alive to this—we should remember, `Lies, lies, lies'. When members opposite went to the election all those years ago, they of course made their promises; shortly after the election, they of course broke them all. I suspect that there will be many more headlines just like this one, if the Australian people have to put up with the sorry circumstance of having them in Government. In conclusion, lest the assertions of, in particular, the National Party Leader in the bush are taken at face value, I table the comparative petrol prices and taxes in International Energy Agency countries.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very impressed if that is the best the Government can do in an attack on the goods and services tax. My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. In the light of reports that there is now no challenge to the Prime Minister's leadership—

PARA.TAB: Opposition members—Ha, ha!

TALK.START.PARA: —Two jokes in a row! Will he give the people of Australia an absolute assurance that no deal, explicit or implicit, has been arranged to hand over the leadership of the ALP to the honourable member for Blaxland prior to the next election?

—In respect of leadership in the next election, there is one certainty and one uncertainty. The certainty is that I will lead the Government into the next election. It is far from certain, when the National Party starts deserting the Liberal Party on the consumption tax, who will be leading the Liberals.

—My question is addressed to the Treasurer. Has his attention been drawn to a document published by the International Monetary Fund entitled, Value-added taxes: administrative and policy issues? Will the Treasurer inform the House whether a value-added tax is regressive?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, my attention has been drawn to this document. It goes to the heart of the Government's rejection of a consumption tax. The IMF paper correctly noted:

ANSWER.PARA: A straightforward single rate VAT with no zero rates except for exports and few exemptions must mean that the VAT payments by low income households will be a higher proportion of their incomes and expenditures than payments by higher income households—that is, the VAT will be regressive.
This, of course, is the view of the Government. The Government rejects the introduction of a consumption tax because it is inherently regressive.

TALK.START.PARA: —Inherently, eh?
—Yes, inherently, Andrew. A consumption tax hits those on low income hardest.
—Order! The honourable member for McPherson!

—We are witnessing in this country a campaign now being waged by the Opposition which has as its philosophical core the concept of incentive. So let me define for the House the perfect computer-driven world of the concept of `incentive'. If one is well off, if one has property and privileges, then incentive means a reduced taxation burden and the provision of a capital gains tax rort. In short, incentive is spelt: c-a-r-r-o-t. If, however, one is on a low income, then incentive means a new tax on food, clothing and necessities; an emasculation of essential services; the elimination of programs targeted to benefit those least well off; and the abolition of unemployment benefits. So if one is not a Liberal Party high roller, incentive is spelt s-t-i-c-k or, alternatively, for the National Party people, c-l-u-b.

PARA.TAB: Australians well understand that the choice at the next election is not between a pro- or anti-consumption tax party. The choice that Australians face will be between the narrow group of individuals now in control of the Federal Liberal Party, who believe that culture, history, scale, location and individuals can be assumed away, and the Australian Labor Party, committed to further ensuring that reform is advanced in a way which protects those least able to protect themselves. I tell you, Mr Speaker, I would not want to be a Liberal or, even worse, a National Party backbencher for quids.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hewson Dr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. Professor Geoffrey Blainey has just declared that the Prime Minister's struggle with the honourable member for Blaxland comes:

QUESTION.PARA: During . . . an economic crisis probably more acute than any since the 1930's.
This could be the longest leadership crisis in Federal history and a needless source of damage to the whole nation.
When will the Prime Minister put aside his total preoccupation with one job—his own—and concentrate all his attention on providing jobs for nearly one million Australians who are now unemployed?

TALK.START.PARA: —When I get to the stage of having to rely on Professor Geoffrey Blainey as an accurate analyst of what is happening in Australian politics, then I will think that a very sorry state has been reached. I believe that Professor Geoffrey Blainey rendered a signal contribution to Australia when he stuck to his last as an historian. He has written some magnificent works in the field of history, in which he is a specialist. But when it comes to the question of current political issues, he is a no-one.

PARA.TAB: All I can say on the question of predictions about leadership in the last decade is that my record is, I think, second to none. I have always got it right. If only the honourable member for Bennelong had listened to me earlier, when I warned him, months in advance, of what was happening! Well may the honourable member for Bennelong look downcast, because it is well known that I am, fundamentally, a thoroughly charitable, thoroughly decent bloke. I tried to warn the honourable member for Bennelong. I told him of the numbers, and I got it exactly right. I said, `Look, you had better watch out for what is happening', and I was right. If he had listened to me perhaps the whole course of Australian Liberal politics would have been different. We would not have had the merry-go-round that we had with the coalition going back to the honourable member for Kooyong and then, when the honourable member for Kooyong and the honourable member for Bennelong both failed, going to the honourable member for wherever he is from—

TALK.START.PARA: —Wentworth.

—That is right; the honourable member for Wentworth. I repeat, as an act of great charity to the current Leader of the Opposition, that I am aware that, despite the angelic appearance on the face of the honourable member for Bennelong, he has not entirely interred his ambition. There is a little bit of subterranean talk along the lines of `Now listen, what happens if in fact the selling of the broad based consumption tax does not go too well?'. What happens if, as is suggested, the Leader of the National Party, Mr Tim Fischer, starts to run away—as people will? The Queensland National Party has already indicated it will not have a bar of it. The New South Wales National Party is looking very askance at it. The National Party everywhere is getting ready to get into the starting blocks to run away at 100 miles an hour.

PARA.TAB: When that happens, as it will—despite the grin by the Leader of the National Party, it will—then the subterranean talking of the honourable member for Bennelong and the honourable member for Mayo, who is starting to sound out the possible prospects of the honourable member for Barker, will happen. It is happening.

TALK.START.PARA: —For him!

—The honourable member for Barker has at last come to life. We thought he was dead. I hope the members of the press gallery listen to me this time; they did not listen to me when I told them what was happening to the honourable member for Bennelong. Just watch what is happening now. The honourable member for Bennelong is at it again—just a little bit, not a lot, but he is at it. The honourable member for Mayo could never go full out at anything, but he is sounding out about the honourable member for Barker. I say to the Leader of the Opposition, `Don't worry about this side. Watch your own back, mate'.

—My question is directed to the Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories. Is he aware of reports in today's press predicting a possible tenfold increase in tourism from Korea by the turn of the century? Is that a fanciful claim? What measures is the Government implementing to facilitate that sort of growth?

—Certainly, the suggestions made in the honourable member's question are far from fanciful. I welcome—and I think most people who understand the tourism industry would welcome—and certainly agree with the predictions that Korea will be a very significant inbound tourism market for this country. There are a number of reasons why I can make those predictions. First, we have had the introduction of the direct inbound services by Qantas from Korea, coupled with the very successful marketing effort by the Australian Tourist Commission. The direct services and that effort by the Commission will see record numbers of Korean tourists coming to this country.

PARA.TAB: Already we are seeing an increase in arrivals of up to 100 per cent on the figures that we saw last year. Between January and July 1991, 13,200 tourists from Korea came to this country. That figure is up from about 7,800 for the same seven months of 1990. Our growth has been assisted by a number of very significant steps. First, the Australian Tourist Commission was the first national tourism organisation allowed to advertise on Korean television. In May of this year the Australian Tourist Commission began a new campaign on television called `Make Friends with Australia'. That promotion featured Greg Norman and a very successful local television star. The campaign attracted some 52,000 responses to an associated competition that resulted in seven Korean tourists visiting Australia for the very first time.

The total Korean campaign is costing of the order of $1.8m, and that is being assisted by a cooperative marketing effort with Korean Airlines and Qantas to the tune of $200,000. It is important to note that tourism growth in those key markets and those growing markets, such as Korea, is not accidental. It is very much planned and is planned on the basis of detailed research. It is planned also through a coordination of effort between the Australian Tourist Commission and, in this case, the two carriers, Qantas and Korean Airlines.

My Department has also recently contributed a tourism perspective to recent air service negotiations—the Minister for Transport and Communications alluded to that last week—where we concluded a very successful round of negotiations between Australia and Hong Kong. I hope that that process, which included tourism interests for the first time in the negotiations, will be a continuing process between my Department and the Department of Transport and Communications.

Overall in this period, for the first seven months that we have figures available, given the very slow start we had this year because of the conflict in the Middle East, the inbound tourism numbers to this country are extraordinarily strong. I predict that 1991 will surpass our record year of 1988. For the last three months that we had figures, we had growth of 8 per cent in May, 9 per in June and a 12 per increase in July.

Given the record numbers of visas issued out of those major source countries, there is every indication that we will surpass the figure of 1990, so that this year will continue to be a magnificent year for inbound tourism growth to Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Prime Minister satisfied with the latest statement of the honourable member for Blaxland that there will be no future challenge for the leadership when, following his May-June unsuccessful challenge, the honourable member for Blaxland made a similar statement and the last few weeks have witnessed the greatest non-challenge in Australian political history? I further ask the Prime Minister: does he believe the latest assurance from the Minister for Social Security that there will be no losing leadership challenge? Did the Prime Minister believe the Minister for Social Security when he said that there would be no challenge just before the last challenge took place?
—The answer to that hotchpotch is covered by my answering the first question: yes.

—Before I call the honourable member for Prospect, I say to honourable members on both sides that in recent days there have been a number of questions which border very much on being out of order. While it is appropriate to ask the Prime Minister matters about national affairs and his leadership of the Government, when one starts to delve into the matters that affect parties, as members on both sides will recall, Speakers have said that those sorts of direct questions are out of order. I ask members on both sides when asking those sorts of questions to do so a bit more in accordance with the Standing Orders.

—I refer the Minister for Land Transport to Australia Post's reported profit of $140m for the past financial year. Could the Minister explain the basis of such a healthy performance by Australia Post? What action has Australia Post taken to improve the efficiency of its operations?

—I appreciate the opportunity to confirm the advice that Australia Post has announced. As the honourable member for Prospect indicates, during the last financial year it made a record profit in excess of $144m. That represents an increase of about 100 per cent on the profit that Australia Post made last year. One of the interesting things about this is that it was not brought about as a result of any substantial increase in charges; it was brought about largely as a result of a reduction in costs. Many of those costs were associated with the reduction in employment within Australia Post of about 1,000. That was able to be achieved in the context of the lowest level of industrial disputation within Australia Post since Australia Post was first established in 1975. There was also a significant increase in the quality of customer service.

PARA.TAB: Australia Post, under the corporate objectives which this Government has given to it since it became a corporation two years ago, has been increasingly customer oriented. For the sixth successive year, Australia Post has increased the charge of a standard letter by something less than the CPI. That represents a very substantial improvement for Australia Post customers. People on both sides of the Parliament should be able to receive this information with a great deal of enthusiasm and should welcome the information. It really has been an outstanding result.

We have worked with Australia Post in the development of its corporate strategy. In connection with the performance last year, on every one of those major targets that Australia Post set for itself, it either equalled it or surpassed it. When we are thinking of the sorts of benefits that public sector corporations of this kind can bring to government, the public sector and the national community, we might compare the dividends that Australia Post paid to the Government in the previous financial year of $1m with that paid in the most recent financial year of $25m. The implications and the benefits of that are immediately apparent.

The return on assets by Australia Post increased from 7.4 per cent in the previous year to 10.7 per cent, if we take into account community service obligations. That is a level which the Government would consider generally to be approaching an appropriate commercial return on investments. I think everyone recognises that Australia Post represents an investment by the total national community, and the national community—17 million Australians—are entitled to expect that the return on their investment will be a commercial return.

Australia Post, under the chairmanship of Maurice Williams and the managing director, Rae Taylor, together with all of the members of the board, from the top management through to all of its employees, has given the type of support we would expect to its commercial responsibilities. Australia Post has a total of something like 40,000 employees over the whole of Australia. It is a very labour-intensive operation. All of those people associated with Australia Post, in any capacity at all, should take a great deal of pride, as we do, in its achievements.

Some of the other highlights that I would like to mention briefly include a productivity improvement of 1.6 per cent; the establishment of a Postal Services Consultative Council, being chaired by the Deputy Chairman of Australia Post, which indicates the seriousness with which that task is being approached; the announcement of an independent monitoring of letter delivery service performance; a decrease of the basic postage rate, as I have said, in real terms for the sixth consecutive year; the commissioning of 14 high-speed electronic mail-sorting machines; the opening of 30 new-look retail post facilities; and the completion of a new network of parcel centres to improve delivery performance.

I have no doubt that, as a result of this very serious approach which Australia Post has brought to its responsibilities, this level of achievement will continue, and that will confirm the capacity of government business enterprises to undertake commercial exercises of this kind and to measure up well with the type of standards that we often see in the private sector. The Australian people have cause to believe that their investment in Australia Post will continue to be a very substantial one and continue to be a very successful one.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Prime Minister: how has the Government's policy to tackle unemployment changed since June when the honourable member for Blaxland left the Ministry? If the Government's unemployment policy has not changed, how can the honourable member for Blaxland repeatedly accuse the Government of lacking policy to deal with unemployment or, if the Government's unemployment policy has changed, will the Prime Minister please explain what was wrong with the Government's unemployment policy while the honourable member for Blaxland was Treasurer?
—I am not going to take the time of the House in listing—

PARA.TAB: Opposition members—Oh!

TALK.START.PARA: —I feel devastated by the question. Honourable members can see that I really have been knocked over by it. The honourable gentleman may like me to send around to him the marked pages of the last Budget Papers in which we specified the new decisions, the new outlays, that we have made that are relevant in this matter. If he is not capable of looking that up himself, I am more than happy to have that done.

—In addressing a question to the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, I draw his attention to an article which appeared in the Canberra Times on 8 November, and I ask: is there a lack of urgency amongst young people about applying to join the newly created Australian Defence Force Ready Reserve?
—I thank the honourable member for Brisbane for his question. He has taken a very close interest in the Ready Reserve since attending the launch.
—He was at the launch in Brisbane.

—As the Prime Minister says, he was at the launch in Brisbane three weeks ago. The article in question was by my good friend Frank Cranston—who, I must say to the House, generally speaking gets things right about defence. On this occasion, I think he has got things wrong. In the 22 days from the launch of the scheme until the time he wrote his column, 18,293 young people had inquired about signing up.
—How many?
—There were 18,293, and of those 3,117 had actually submitted a formal application.
—How many of those were unemployed?

—That is a remarkable response rate. Here we have a wholly new form of service which is being aimed at a relatively narrow and highly competitive section of the population, namely, young, fit, intelligent men and women, and it is being presented to them at a time when most of them are focusing on their exams. Yet we have an inquiry rate which is running close to 1,000 a day.

PARA.TAB: Of those who have inquired about the Army ready reserves—this is perhaps in response to the question by the Leader of the National Party—5,468 have indicated they would want to get full time jobs at the end of their initial one year of training, while 5,956, which is more than half, have indicated that they want to go on to university. So the ready reserves are drawing the interest of a section of the community which is distinctly different from those who traditionally apply for conventional military service—and I regard that as a very healthy development.

It is true that a disproportionately high level of inquiries—almost 7,000—have come from the home State of the honourable member for Brisbane, but then Queensland has always been one of our best recruiting grounds. While Queenslanders will not have to move interstate to complete their full time training, the fact is that for many young people being able to leave home is part of the attraction of joining the Services.

Already 114 people have been through the entire enlistment process and have been approved for entry to the ready reserves. That is already about 10 per cent of the number we are looking for for this year. The calibre of the new candidates is such that we will not have any difficulty filling all the positions from those who have already applied, but obviously we are still taking applications so that we are able to pick the very best recruits.

In conclusion, the Ready Reserve scheme was tailored specifically to appeal to the very people who are now applying in large numbers to join it. The Government went to a lot of trouble to ensure that it was a carefully designed scheme with appropriate incentives and we knew it would be a success. Above all, our confidence in the youth of Australia has been rewarded and the Opposition's cries that the Ready Reserve scheme would never work now have a very hollow ring.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Treasurer. I refer the Treasurer to an earlier answer he gave to a dorothy dix question in relation to an IMF report on goods and services taxes. I refer the Treasurer to the new IMF study by a Mr Alan Tait, which argues that a goods and services tax is not inflationary, that it encourages exports and helps countries overcome their balance of payments problems and that it is not necessarily regressive. Who should Australians believe about this—the International Monetary Fund, which has always supported goods and services taxes, or a Labor Party which once itself supported the introduction of a broadly based consumption tax but which is now running a scare campaign of deceit and dishonesty?
—Just ask New Zealand.
—The member for the Northern Territory will cease interjecting.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —In terms of the honourable gentlemen's more recent statements, I was wondering whether he was going to volunteer that the Opposition is going to put a goods and services tax on brothels, but it appears he is into more serious matters.
—Would you exempt them?
—Order! Order!

—Would the Opposition give them exemptions? The constant noise from the Opposition about how the Government is going to run a scare campaign on the goods and services tax is really becoming ludicrous because we do not even know what we are dealing with yet. We keep hearing about this thing. We have to deal in general principles because it is inherently regressive.
—Why do you oppose it?
—Order!

—We are not going to run a scare campaign. When those opposite finally bring their policy out, we will deal with it lock, stock and barrel in terms of the facts. There will be no need for scares; the only people who will be scared will be the Australian people.
—And the National Party.

—And members of the National Party. They will crack. Look at them: not a smile there. If I could just address the honourable member's question more directly, I have also seen that point in the IMF paper and I am studying it well. The section on this subject ended with a quote by an Australian commentator who stated:

ANSWER.PARA: A lot of people both in and outside Australia are going to need to be convinced that the inflationary burst caused by a GST is going to be a once and for all shift in the price level and not the start of a new, much higher rate of inflation. That is very tricky. Inflation expectations here in Australia are high and remain high despite stringent monetary policy. Throw in a year in which inflation goes from the current levels or prospective levels and you will create in the mind of the public an expectation of savings erosion which will have a fairly longstanding impact on their behaviour.

He was talking about current levels of 8 per cent and prospective levels of 6 per cent. Of course, since then inflationary expectations have fallen dramatically. A consumption tax would simply reignite those expectations.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have a consumption tax already.
—So, to avoid the consumption tax being translated into ongoing inflation there would have to be—
—What about your consumption tax?
—Order! The honourable member for Mayo!

—There would have to be a credible wages policy. Again, the Opposition has none. In fact, the Opposition Leader was asked this very question at a New York investment conference on 8 October this year. His response was:

ANSWER.PARA: We would seek to demonstrate to people that they had been compensated which should ensure that there is no pressure to flow on from that change to further increases in wages.

In other words, there is no mechanism to ensure that the increase in inflation is not reflected in wages and, therefore, in ongoing inflation. What would happen? A consumption tax would smash the gains we have made in reducing inflation. The only way the Opposition would have to lower inflation again would be through higher interest rates, lower growth and much higher unemployment. There it is: members of the Opposition have the outstanding example—where all their hopes lie—of New Zealand.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Langmore Mr J.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Treasurer and relates to his Department's booklet Australia's Foreign Investment Policy, which says in part:

QUESTION.PARA: All proposals by foreign interests to establish a newspaper in Australia or to acquire an existing newspaper business are subject to case-by-case examination irrespective of the size of the proposed investment.

I ask: does this mean that, if the receiver recommends purchase of the Fairfax newspaper by a consortium which includes any element of foreign control, such a proposed purchase will be scrutinised by the Foreign Investment Review Board and by him in consultation with his colleagues to assess whether it is in the national interest?

TALK.START.PARA: —The Foreign Acquisitions and Takeovers Act 1975 provides that a proposal by a foreign investor, either alone or with associates, to acquire 15 per cent or more of the shares in a company in Australia whose assets are valued at $5m or more must be notified to the Government for consideration. Under the Act, if I am of the opinion that control of the target business would become foreign as a result of the bid and that the proposal is contrary to the national interest, I may reject the proposal. A bid by a foreign interest for Fairfax that proposed the acquisition of less than 15 per cent of the shares may fall outside the provisions of the Foreign Acquisitions and Takeovers Act. Even so, any such bid of less than 15 per cent would need to be submitted to the Government under foreign investment policy.

PARA.TAB: As the honourable gentleman has noted, this policy for many years has been published in successive issues of a booklet, approved by the Treasurer of the day, entitled Australia's Foreign Investment Policy—a guide for investors. The booklet has been, and is, on sale at Commonwealth Government bookshops in each State and Territory capital city. It is well known to foreign investors, their advisers and lawyers. The policy booklet makes it clear that proposals by foreign investors, irrespective of size, in the media should be submitted to the Government for examination. This aspect of policy has not been changed for many years. Although this section of policy is not enforceable under the provisions of the Foreign Acquisitions and Takeovers Act, the Government expects foreign investors to comply with the policy. The bidders for Fairfax are, of course, fully aware of the policy and the Government's expectations that they will comply with it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Prime Minister to reports that his Government will spend $600m this year to create jobs under the mad cities fantasy. Given that it is now three months—

—Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. I have been very forbearing in Question Time in respect of raising points of order, but we have had repeated questions from the Opposition, of which this is another example, which materially offend that standing order which says that no question may be asked if it contains epithets or like material in the matter it puts forward. I submit that using the expression `mad cities policy' is manifestly ultra vires the Standing Orders.

—I refer the Prime Minister to reports that his Government will spend $600m this year to create jobs under the so-called—

—I hope that the honourable member for Mackellar had a good and a productive time on his recent visit to Africa, where he undertook a very useful function. I thank him for his contribution—but I am afraid that it has not sharpened the old boy up. For reasons which I regard as totally understandable, his head was below the railing—it has come up now. I welcome his reappearance. And well he may have hidden, because this is a very efficient government. But even with the enormous efficiency which I am able to summon and the great capacity of my relevant Ministers, it would even be beyond them to spend $650m in the rest of 1991-92. —Can the Minister for Resources inform the House what action is being taken to further develop Australia's offshore exploration areas?

—I thank the honourable member for his question. It is of course an important question. The task of encouraging both our oil and gas exploration efforts, in particular offshore, is of enormous importance to this country. If one imagines Australia as a car, it has about 12 years worth of juice in the tank. As it goes into the next century, unless it continues to encourage the exploration and development effort, quite simply it will run out of juice. It is very important that all Australians understand the central importance of this exploration and production effort.

PARA.TAB: The backdrop to the recent announcement of further acreage releases offshore is that in 1990 Australia had a record, both in terms of exploration and production. As a corollary, it is important to point out that most of Australia's gas discoveries of current and prospectively enormous importance to this country have been as a by-product of oil exploration. One need reflect only on the enormous contribution of gas sales from our North West Shelf project, in particular, to repairing our current account position to understand the enormous importance of that.

The recently announced release is part of the Government's 25-year program. It looks not to the next few months, or even years, but well into the next century. It provides an internationally accepted framework for proper exploration and production. It forms part of a raft of government initiatives lauded in various international forums. That certainty has been the message from all the players, including those coming to Australia for the first time.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Suspension of Standing and Sessional Orders

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jull Mr D.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That so much of the Standing and Sessional Orders be suspended as would prevent the member for Fadden moving forthwith—
That this House:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)That this House calls on the Government, notwithstanding internal bickering and objections from certain Government members, to give immediate approval for construction of the third runway at Sydney's Kingsford-Smith Airport; and

(2)requires that the Speaker be granted the endorsement of the House to participate in debate on the motion, so that he can explain, as the Member for Grayndler, the reason for his position in relation to the matter.

Mr Speaker, this is a particularly serious matter to come before the House for debate. It embraces an issue that would not normally be the subject of contention or dispute—the construction of a long awaited and very necessary part of our transport infrastructure. However, the alarm bells should have begun ringing for every Australian concerned for this country's development when the troglodytes from the extremes of the Australian Labor Party started weighing in against the proposal.

PARA.TAB: My attention was drawn to the Australian of 8 October this year. There for all to see was the unholy alliance of the New South Wales Labor Right and the Left—a picture of the honourable member for Barton (Mr Punch) and the honourable member for Kingsford-Smith (Mr Brereton) grimly perusing the environmental impact study into Sydney Airport along with the champions of the Left, the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services (Mr Baldwin) and the honourable member for Phillip (Ms McHugh). I never believed that I would see the Minister in the fraternal embrace of the New South Wales Right. Yet it is obvious that recent events within the ALP have thrown together some very strange alliances.

Coming in the wake of the Government's Medicare fiasco, it is little wonder that there is concern building within the community that the Government will lack the fortitude to make a decision in the long term interests of the nation on this matter. Over the years the Government has established an appalling record of caving in when the pressure is applied—whether it be from outside interest groups or from within the Government's own factions. Despite the fact that there are strong advocates for the third runway within the Ministry—such as the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins)—there is growing disquiet that this decision will become another victim of factional politics.

Let us examine the record. In 1982 the then Minister for Aviation, the present honourable member for Hume (Mr Fife), announced plans to proceed with a new runway at Sydney Airport. Opposed by the New South Wales Labor Government, the proposal was scrapped by the incoming Labor Government in 1983. Six years passed before the Government was able to summon up the courage to announce its intention to proceed with a parallel runway at Sydney Airport. That announcement was accompanied by a commitment to undertake an extensive environmental impact study into all aspects of the project. The honourable member for Barton, unable to accept the decision of the majority—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I would hate to stop the honourable member for Fadden making his point, but I think that he should be aware that we have two issues here: the first is whether to suspend Standing Orders, and then, if that is agreed, we will debate the member's proposition. In speaking to the motion to suspend Standing Orders, the member for Fadden should be saying why it is important to suspend Standing Orders and not necessarily running the arguments that he may run if that motion succeeds. I draw the member's attention to that, so that he does not continue the debate.

—That is precisely why I want to suspend Standing Orders, Mr Speaker. We have a situation where you and a number of members from New South Wales are undertaking, even on this very day, to put up obstacles to the third runway project. In the House we received a notice this morning that we will have an exhibition tomorrow by one of the groups against the third runway, and they will use this facility to keep pushing their objections to the proposal. We would like to know from whom the approval came.

PARA.TAB: Quite frankly, Mr Speaker, we are very concerned indeed that we will not get a clear cut decision on this project and get it under way as a matter of urgency. There are 40,000 jobs involved in the third runway extension for Sydney Airport. It is one of the most important pieces of micro-economic reform that we have in Australia, and it is quite obvious, I would think, to the meanest intelligence that the Government is in trouble on this matter.

It is one of the most important pieces of micro-economic reform, and we have got to a stage where we can undertake the whole thing, get it on the public record and find out what the objections are all about. Let us clear the thing once and for all. The Opposition recognises the importance of this project. We want to get it under way, and, if the Government makes the decision to get it under way, it will have our support 100 per cent. In the meantime, we have the difficulty of members of the Government, including members of the back bench, running around putting up every possible obstacle. It is about time that they all came clean. That is why we are raising this issue today.

I mentioned that the honourable member for Barton was unable to accept the decision of the majority. He resigned from the Ministry, thus laying the foundations for a continuing campaign against the proposal. Opposition from within the Government to the parallel runway has been evident for years and years. It involves senior members of the Government. Three years ago, Senator Gareth Evans, the then Minister for Transport and Communications, stated his very clear opposition to the parallel runway at Sydney Airport. Speaking before a Senate Estimates committee hearing on 13 October 1988 he said:

SPEECH.PARA: We have made it very clear that a further runway is not a credible, viable or financially, environmentally or politically acceptable option.

There could not be any clearer indication of what he thought about the parallel runway. Something quite dramatic must have happened in the six months after that to induce a change of mind within the Government.

PARA.TAB: The release of the EIS just a few weeks ago was preceded by very sound advice from within the Labor movement. Martin Ferguson, the President of the ACTU, said on the Sunday program on 15 September:

SPEECH.PARA: Political parties have to stop playing football and face up to their responsibilities on all sides of the political argument.

I trust that the Cabinet will take Mr Ferguson's advice. The problem was that Mr Ferguson was then openly criticised in the Sydney Morning Herald by the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services for having the temerity to support the third runway proposal as a means for reducing unemployment. It seems that, if one wants to take a step back into the Dark Ages, one can always rely on the Labor Left to lead the way.

PARA.TAB: It was at this time that the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, was publicly calling for the fast tracking for approval of the major project. These sentiments were echoed by the Treasurer (Mr Kerin) just last month when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: I think it would be very important psychologically to get a few of the projects that people allege are being delayed off the ground.

However, forces are certainly mustering within the ALP to reject the EIS's finding and to further embarrass members of the Cabinet. On 2 October, the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services made clear his opposition to the proposal. He stated in unequivocal terms:
In my view the EIS fails to provide a basis for the proposal to proceed.

My suggestion to the Minister is that, should he be unsuccessful in his scheme to halt this project, he should take a leaf from the book of his colleague the honourable member for Barton: he should resign from the Ministry, and he should do so straightaway. He should have the political courage of his convictions to join his colleague in political obscurity.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Ronald Edwards)—The Chair is listening to the reasons being given by the honourable member for Fadden as to why it is important for the Standing and Sessional Orders to be suspended. From time to time he is moving outside those boundaries.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's why he wants to suspend Standing Orders.
—Order! The Chair does not require the assistance of the honourable member for Bennelong.

—As I said earlier, the real reason is the unbelievable situation in the Government, whereby senior members of the Government, from the Ministry through to the Speaker, are voicing their objections to it at a time when it is one of the most critical decisions that should be made in Australian history. It is an urgent decision. We know that the 42 days that were required for consideration of the final EIS is up this week, and a decision has to be made quickly.

PARA.TAB: If senior Ministers of the Government and senior people on the back benches of the Government are running around putting up every obstacle they can lay their hands on, there is a matter or urgency in suspending Standing Orders to let all honourable members, including the Speaker of the House, come clean and give their good and valid reasons to this Parliament as to why they consider that the runway should not proceed as a matter of urgency.

TALK.START.PARA: —I know that when the honourable member for Fadden says `the Speaker of the House should come clean' he is not reflecting upon the Speaker in any other capacity.

—As the honourable member for Grayndler, the Speaker should be given the opportunity to come down from the chair and give his good reasons to this Parliament as to why he is running around the suburbs of Sydney putting up all these crazy objections why the runway cannot go ahead. This is a most important aspect of the whole debate. The most senior man in the House of Representatives outside in the real world can go through the newspapers and appear on the front pages of papers such as the Sydney Morning Herald vocally objecting to the runway and to the Government's proposed plans to go ahead with the extension of the runway, yet we cannot question him in this place. We want to give him the opportunity to stand up in the House right now, this very day, and give his reasons as to why this third runway proposal should not proceed. We want him to do that as soon as possible. That is why we are asking for the suspension of Standing Orders today. (Time expired)

—I am not here to talk about the cleanliness or otherwise of Mr Speaker, in whatever role he appears before us, but to say to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, to the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) and to all the members of this House that there is a reason to suspend Standing Orders. It was in mid-September that we heard from the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button). Then we were told that there is a time when we need to massage particular projects. This is the Monday of the sitting week before the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is due to make his long expected statement on how the Australian Labor Party will promote employment in our country. He has told us that on Thursday we will have a major ministerial statement—a mini-mini-Budget. If we do not suspend Standing Orders and try to persuade Government members to include within their prime ministerial statement on Thursday a commitment to the third runway, I think a golden opportunity will be lost for the Government.

PARA.TAB: I am disappointed that the Speaker, as the honourable member for Grayndler (Mr Leo McLeay), seems to be changing his role again. No, he is not—he is just changing sides. That is understandable, because one of the problems, and one of the reasons we have to suspend Standing Orders—
Government members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —There are not many occasions on which I invite the honourable member for Grayndler to return—

PARA.TAB: An honourable member—He can't make up his mind.

TALK.START.PARA: —He cannot make up his mind, as my colleague says. There is a real problem in our not debating this as an urgency motion today. Time is short. It certainly is critically short for those who are concerned about the fate of the third runway. I rise not just to allow those who are members of the Labor Party to explain what seems to be an extraordinarily new factional alliance in the way in which there are those whom some support, some oppose and, frankly, I think few have analysed. I know that the Leader of the House, who is long since a Minister for aviation—he knows something of the nuances of this affair—would agree that the time is short for action on what is a major development project.

PARA.TAB: As a member representing a rural electorate I can tell the House that there are more than 250,000 intrastate movements in New South Wales each year, and all of those travellers require access to the centre of Sydney. They will not be content to go out to Badgerys Creek. They will be absolutely frustrated if it takes as long for them to travel to an airport, which as yet does not enjoy the infrastructure to gain access, as they would to maintain access to Mascot. We also need to realise that if those who oppose the project—subsidised as they have been by Government money—were sincere, they would say that they would close Mascot. They do not say that they will close Mascot. They are in opposition; they want to have it halfway. The motion for the suspension of Standing Orders has to be considered today and the Prime Minister has to be given a chance to peruse this proposition. This was made clear in the statement by the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins) on 2 October—and this is now the beginning of November. The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mrs Kelly) has had an opportunity to consider the second proposal. There has been a voluminous report, but the core of it is in two elements. I think that every member of the House, certainly the members of the Government, members of the public, and even those who are opposed to the airport proposition, need to consider these two elements.

The first is that the construction of the third runway at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport will mean a massive 59 per cent reduction in the number of people affected by aircraft noise. So the first and most significant product, and the reason the Government ought to include it in its jobs program, is that there will be a reduction in aircraft noise. The second is that the third runway project will be funded entirely by the self-funding Federal Airports Corporation. There will be a significant job creation of between 26,000 and 40,000 jobs. The third runway will mean less noise and more jobs. It will be in the interests of rural and regional commuters, in the interests of Australia and the preservation of what is today Australia's principal international access. We deserve to debate this issue. This motion calls on the Government to give expedition to the consideration of the fast tracking of a proposition which would generate jobs and develop further the Kingsford-Smith Airport. I put it to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, and to the House that that is the course this House should take.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am a bit mystified at the Opposition's tactics in putting this motion forward in the way it has, for a variety of reasons. I think it is pretty well known that when we debate a suspension motion like this, it is most unlikely that the Government will do anything other than to proceed with the next item of Government business, so we lose about 10 minutes of debating time and also lose a focused debate.

PARA.TAB: This is a debate on the suspension of Standing Orders. Although the two honourable members who have spoken have ranged fairly far and wide, they were constrained to a degree because they had to keep their arguments narrowly confined as to why the Speaker should or should not suspend Standing Orders to immediately discuss the matter at this stage. A proper debate on a suspension of Standing Orders for this sort of proposition is why there are several series of time constraints engaged in future action that means that no course of action confronts the House sensibly other than a requirement for an immediate discussion of the matter. I do not think that has been terribly effectively demonstrated.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. The Leader of the House is indicating that the tactics that have been employed by the Opposition on this occasion will limit debate on this very important issue. Mr Deputy Speaker, you would know that, if the Government supports this motion, there will be an adequate time to debate it. Could I seek your indulgence to ascertain from the Leader of the House whether the Government will allow this debate to continue? In other words, will it grant urgency?

—The Opposition should wait with bated breath until minute nine to learn whether that will happen, or somewhat earlier if I run out of reasons, apart from the fairly simple ones, that ought to be put as to why this motion ought to be rejected. I do not think there would be any anticipation from those opposite that the Government would do anything other than reject this, if for no other reason than what is requested of the Speaker of the House.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. On behalf of all members of the House I seek your guidance as to what the decision of the Leader of the House means. The Leader of the House has just indicated that the Government proposes not to grant suspension of Standing Orders. Will that preclude the Speaker from entering into this debate and stating clearly his position in relation to the third runway?

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Ronald Edwards)—The Manager of Opposition Business has asked two questions. The first one goes to the arguments of the Leader of the House. He, of course, is at liberty in this debate to put those arguments sequentially, as have the colleagues of the Manager of Opposition Business—that is, the honourable member for Fadden and the right honourable member for New England—and he is doing that. The Chair cannot pre-empt what that decision would be, but I understand why the Manager of Opposition Business raises that. The second question, as to whether or not the Speaker would enter the debate, of course is a matter for the Speaker. Customarily that would not be the case, I would have thought, but that is a matter for the Speaker and not for the Chair at present.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, further on a point of order: with respect, sir, you misunderstood my question. My question is whether, if the Leader of the House does not permit this debate to proceed, that will preclude the Speaker from having the opportunity to speak. I am not asking you to indicate whether the Speaker will or will not enter the debate. I am concerned that the Government might take action, by weight of numbers, to preclude the Speaker from taking part in the debate—and that would be undemocratic.

—The Chair understands the substance of the point the Manager of Opposition Business makes. However, what he is really making in fact is a debating point which in relation to the discussion before the Chair is: how would this argument proceed in a way that the Speaker's speaking would be facilitated, or not facilitated? Of course the answer to that is to be provided by the Leader of the House rather than by the Chair because it is a matter of how he would treat the substantive matter before the House.

—The last occasion on which I recollect being advised of Speakers being involved in discussions in these ways was by my father—and it at least goes back to when he was a very junior member of the House, when Mr Speaker Rosevear was in the chair. My father discovered that Mr Speaker Rosevear had a tendency to sit on the Government front bench and my father, as a new aspiring member of parliament, felt it necessary to raise with Mr Speaker Rosevear the question of the objectivity of the Speaker. He went to him and said, `Mr Speaker, why are you sitting on the Government front bench?', expecting of course some answer such as, `Well, I like to come in and listen to the debate and I like to hear what is going on in the Parliament even when I am not in the chair'. What he got was the answer, `Mr Beazley, I am a member of the Government; that is why I sit on the Government front bench'. At the time my father thought this was a less than adequate explanation of the Speaker's role, but Mr Speaker Rosevear persisted with it.

PARA.TAB: Fortunately, that is not the attitude of the honourable member for Grayndler (Mr Leo McLeay), who is a most objective Speaker in this House, who does not regard himself as part of the Government and who refuses to participate in partisan debate or debate of any kind—and that is, of course, a completely appropriate role for Mr Speaker. So, though this proposition is meant with a degree of good humour and obviously in the best interests of ensuring—

TALK.START.PARA: —Goodwill.

—Goodwill, and any other particularly friendly epithet that the Opposition likes to attach to the proposition—one of the many reasons why we would not support a suspension of Standing Orders in order to discuss this particular matter is that we on this side of the House do not feel that we ought to so breach convention and have the Speaker actively engaged in debate on matters of Government policy or otherwise.

PARA.TAB: A second reason why the proposition ought to be opposed is that the processes are proceeding correctly. We have had an environmental impact study in accordance with the laws related to environmental impact studies. We have had an appropriate period for public comment. We have had a subsequent report on that comment. We have had that report go to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mrs Kelly) and that Minister, I think, has another couple of days within which to report to the relevant Minister concerned, who will then take the matter to Cabinet.

In case it has escaped the attention of honourable members opposite—it certainly has not escaped the notice of people on this side of the House—there is a whole new field of litigation opening up in this country in relation to administrative law. It goes on along the lines in these sorts of propositions that, if we as Ministers breach any of the duties that are imposed on us by law, we can quite often be quite successfully injuncted for any particular course of action that we intend to pursue.

To attempt to move the Government outside of the framework of a proper consideration of the legislative requirements resting upon it in this regard would be an act of pure madness if one's objective is to get the third runway in place because, in case it has escaped the attention of honourable members opposite, there is a strong view amongst the neighbouring suburbs—in my view, erroneously based—that they are going to experience substantial difficulty as a result of the implementation of the third runway. There is no question that, of the population of this country who are in some way affected by aircraft noise to a substantial degree, 85 per cent actually reside around Sydney Airport.

So this is not a view that we can just dismiss lightly and give a flick pass to, particularly when we know they are likely to march up and present themselves to us in serried ranks in court and are capable, if we have done anything untoward in the way in which we have conducted that process, of disrupting us. In my view, most of them would be benefited by the establishment of a third runway in terms of noise, but they have to be convinced of that—and they will not be convinced of that if we are playing fast and loose with the legal processes at any point.

This Government has resolved probably the most difficult question in regard to Sydney's future aviation needs that governments have confronted in the past; that is, the successful identification and beginnings of the development of a second airport at Sydney, at Badgerys Creek. Governments have risen and fallen on these sorts of issues in the past, but we have done that. We have also pursued through the proper processes what is the interim to medium term fix—that is, the third runway proposal. We are handling both those issues sensibly and with sensitivity and, I would say, on time in terms of meeting the aviation needs of Sydney.

So this Government does not actually need to get a hurry up on any of these particular matters. We do not need to be told of the significance of these issues to the aviation industry generally in Australia or Sydney in particular. We are the ones who have been addressing these issues and arriving at the relevant conclusions—not the irrelevant ones that honourable members opposite were managing to arrive at some time ago. When we finally get all these things in place, as we will, there will be no requirement for motions of these sorts. The problem will be solved. (Time expired)

That the motion (Mr Jull's) be agreed to.
