DEBATE.TITLE: FRINGE BENEFITS TAX AMENDMENT BILL 1991[COGNATE BILLS:INCOME TAX (INTERNATIONAL AGREEMENTS) AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1991TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 3) 1991INCOME TAX (DEFERRED INTEREST SECURITIES)(TAX FILE NUMBER WITHHOLDING TAX) BILL 1991MEDICARE LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1991]

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 10 October, on motion by Mr Free:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Ronald Edwards)—I understand that it is the wish of the House to debate the Fringe Benefits Tax Amendment Bill 1991 concurrently with the Income Tax (International Agreements) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1991, the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No.3) 1991, the Income Tax (Deferred Interest Securities)(Tax File Number Withholding Tax) Bill 1991 and the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill 1991. There being no objection, I will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid The Hon N.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Fringe Benefits Tax Amendment Bill 1991 and cognate Bills give the public of Australia a clear demonstration of a government in disarray, panic and incompetence over the leadership issue. Here we have a series of major and important pieces of legislation in the taxation area being introduced and the guillotine being applied without proper and full debate. These legislative matters will affect many people throughout Australia. It is a disgrace that they are to be debated in this manner, and that follows on from the disgraceful performance of the Government since the commencement of this Parliament in May 1990. In a little over a year since May 1990, 114 separate Bills were guillotined through the Parliament. What we are seeing is a follow-on from that—

—The House is listening to hear when the honourable member for Bendigo is going to begin debating the substantive proposition before the House—that is, Orders of the Day Nos 1 to 5, taxation measures.

—I am putting forward the view that these matters are of such importance that it is a disgrace that the Government has chosen to guillotine all of these Bills. I draw to the attention of the House the fact that 48 of the Bills guillotined since May 1990 were guillotined through the Parliament during two sitting weeks. We have a similar situation with these Bills. Apparently, the guillotine will apply right to the end of this session. The Government's attention is focused on other issues and it continues to treat this House with contempt through its handling of very important matters.

PARA.TAB: The amendments before the House at the moment are contained in the Fringe Benefits Tax Amendment Bill 1991, the Income Tax (International Agreements) Amendment Bill (No. 2), the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3), the Income Tax (Deferred Interest Securities) (Tax File Number Withholding Tax) Bill 1991 and the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill 1991. The Government has chosen to provide only an hour and a half for debate on these important pieces of legislation. They comprise many amendments relating to the ending of the tax concessions in relation to service in the Gulf, the treatment of certain social security benefits and allowances, the continuation of the special tax deduction for research and development expenditure, the method of listing organisations to whom gifts are tax deductible, the deductibility of expenses for environmental impact statements, the deductions for payment of the life insurance levy, the timing of franking credits, the capital gains tax cost base, the tax file number withholding tax, new rules for objections to taxation decisions and the deferral of certain company tax payments.

The coalition has a number of concerns about these pieces of legislation, including the amendment to the living away from home allowances section of the Fringe Benefits Tax Amendment Bill which will change the fringe benefits tax law to ensure that living away from home allowances paid to offshore oil and gas rig workers are treated as fringe benefits. I understand—it has caused some concern amongst the coalition—that some companies have overpaid tax prior to this fringe benefits tax amendment being introduced. The coalition is concerned about whether these companies that have overpaid tax will ever get it back. I ask the Minister at the table, the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mr Bilney), to take that on notice. There are a number of issues that I will be raising. We propose to move amendments in the Senate. We will not be moving the amendments in this House at this stage, but I want to flag the concerns of the coalition on a number of these issues.

A further matter I want to raise relates to the exemption of the pay and allowances of members of the Defence Force who served in Iraq and Kuwait. The proposed amendments will exempt from income tax the pay and allowances of members of the Australian Defence Force allotted for duty in Iraq and Kuwait in response to Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. I understand that the Government intends that the amendments will cease that exemption after 9 June 1991. We have no concern with the matter of pensions, benefits and allowances.

The reason underlying the amendment put forward by the Government in relation to investment related lottery winnings is that it minimises the risk of loan providers substituting non-assessable amounts—in other words, prizes—for assessable amounts, interest, to be paid to the recipients. The amendment does not affect ordinary lottos, caskets, art unions, raffles or any of those sorts of things, nor do the amendments apply if either the prize won or the right to participate in a lottery arrangement is already taxable. We are concerned that the legislation applies to prizes paid after the date on which the legislation receives royal assent and therefore applies potentially to arrangements entered into prior to the date of legislation. Therefore, it is potentially retrospective and will impact upon UK premium bonds currently held by Australian residents and equivalent investments offered by the New Zealand Government. These investments were obtained prior to the date of royal assent and we believe they should continue to be exempt. We also have a concern—maybe it can be clarified by the Minister at the table—about whether the provisions will exclude government bodies, bearing in mind the situation in the United Kingdom with its premium bond arrangements.

There are two important aspects to the section dealing with deductions for petroleum resource rent tax payments: firstly, to allow instalments of the petroleum resource rent tax to be deductible in the year in which the payments are made; and, secondly, to include refunds or credits of PRRT instalments for which a deduction has been allowed or is allowable in assessable income in the year in which the amount is received, credited, paid or applied. Basically, those two new provisions will ensure that deductions for the PRRT instalments are consistent with general income tax principles. The amendment will apply to all of those instalments made on or after 1 July 1991.

The next area that the coalition has some concern about relates to gifts to gift funds of cultural organisations. This amendment will allow deductions for gifts made directly to a gift fund of a cultural organisation admitted to the Register of Cultural Organisations. As a consequence, the names of seven cultural organisations that are presently listed in the gift provisions will be removed from the Act, including the Australian Elizabethan Theatre Trust. Honourable members would know the history of this organisation and the financial difficulties that it found itself in. A number of other organisations were caught up in the financial problems of the Australian Elizabethan Theatre Trust as well. The other cultural organisations included are the Sydney Opera House Appeal Fund, the Sidney Myer Music Bowl Trust, the Art Gallery Society of New South Wales, the Victorian Arts Centre Trust, the Queensland Cultural Centre Trust and the Australian National Gallery Foundation.

The amendment will allow gift funds of cultural organisations to receive tax deductible donations by entry on the register. To be listed on the register, a fund must be approved by the Treasurer and the Minister responsible for the arts. I wonder how much public input will take place because the main input into that register and the control of it, after its establishment by the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, will be from the Department itself. I wonder whether the Government has considered that this is an opportunity to allow for more public input into deciding which organisations appear on that register and how they are selected.

The next item that I want to move on to is the deduction of environmental impact studies expenditure. Under the existing law, the cost of studies undertaken to determine the impact that a project may have on the environment may not qualify for deduction. The amendment put forward by the Government will allow a deduction for cost of such studies where the cost is incurred on or after 12 March 1991. In most cases, the cost of the environmental impact study will be deducted over 10 years. However, if the study relates to a project which has a life of less than 10 years, the cost of the study will be deducted over that lesser period. This deduction will not apply to expenditure on environmental impact studies; that is deductible under some other provisions of the Act.

The cost of any plant used in an environmental impact study will be depreciable, like other plant, rather than deductible on the basis of other environmental impact study expenditure. The coalition is concerned that the tax treatment of the rectification of existing plant should be as follows. We believe that, where repairs do not add value to a plant, an outright deduction should be allowed or, in all other cases, a write-off over a three-year period should be allowed. We put that forward, flagging up that further consideration should be given to that between the debate in this House and the appearance of this legislation in the other place.

The life insurance protection levy has a rather long and chequered history. It relates to arrangements which will provide a measure of financial protection for policyholders of Occidental Life Insurance Co. of Australia Ltd and Regal Life Insurance Ltd. The proposed amendments put forward by the Government establish the taxation treatment of various payments associated with the legislative framework introduced to enable the imposition of one-off levy arrangements on registered life insurance companies.

The protection levy payments will be tax deductible to life insurance companies and will be taken to relate exclusively to non-fund assessable income. Grants paid from the life insurance policyholders' protection fund to Occidental Life and Regal Life will be exempt from income tax.

Any winding-up advance payments or final winding-up payments from the protection fund to life insurance companies will be treated as non-fund assessable income. If there is a remission or a refund of an overpayment of protection levy, an assessment may be amended to reflect the proper liability of a company with no time limit impediment. As I indicated to the House, these provisions are to provide a measure of financial protection for the policyholders of Occidental Life and Regal Life Insurance.

The coalition's flagged proposed amendments under subsections 116DC and 116DF of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3), which will be put forward in another place, suggest that it may be more appropriate for these subsections to state that the deductions allowable are taken to relate exclusively to the non-funded class of assessable income of the taxpayer. We put that forward for consideration by the Government and flag our view that this would be a more appropriate action.

The next clause deals with general mining, exploration and prospecting expenditure. I have a particular interest in this matter because I believe it may be of assistance to goldmining in the north-central Victorian area, where there is still a vast quantity of gold that we would like to get out of the ground at some time. This provision, combined with the long-awaited changes to the mining legislation in Victoria, may well bring about a renewal of the goldmining industry in north-central Victoria—and perhaps in Western Australia, Mr Deputy Speaker.

The general mining exploration or prospecting provision will be amended to remove the requirement that mineral exploration or prospecting expenditure need be incurred on a mining tenement to qualify for immediate deductibility. That change will allow expenditure incurred in exploring broad areas not covered by a mining tenement to be deductible. It treats all exploration or prospecting expenditure the same, whether that expenditure be incurred on quarrying, petroleum, petroleum operations or mining, whatever class of mining it may be.

The next provisions in this legislation that I want to make some comment about are the proposed changes regarding the capital gains tax cost base. The Bill will amend the capital gains tax cost base provisions to allow costs such as interest rates and land taxes, repairs and insurance premiums to be taken into account in working out the taxable capital gain made on disposal of an asset. Section 160ZH is being amended to include in the cost base of certain assets holding costs incurred by a taxpayer which are not themselves deductible under other provisions of the Act. However, this inclusion only related to expenditure incurred on assets acquired subsequent to 21 August 1991.

The coalition has some concerns about that. It feels that a fair proposal would be to extend that concession back to 19 September 1985, which was the date on which capital gains tax was introduced. I see the Minister taking notes on that proposal. I think that it is a matter that the Government should look at because there may well be people disadvantaged by what the Government is proposing to do there.

The provisional tax amendments, by which the Government proposes to amend the provisional tax requirements for 1990-91 and subsequent years, mean that taxpayers will be liable for provisional taxes on salary or wages if they satisfy both parts of a simple test. The two conditions are if the balance to pay on assessment was $3,000 or more and the pay as you earn deductions made from that salary or wages income were underdeducted by $3,000 or more.

When calculating the balance to pay on assessment, the whole of the previous year's provisional tax amount is currently allowed as a credit. Only the provisional tax on income other than salary or wages will be allowed as a credit when calculating the balance to pay on assessment. This splitting will occur only for the purposes of determining whether or not the balance to pay on assessment is $3,000 or more.

The amended test operates by splitting the provisional tax credit into two components. The first component is provisional tax raised on income other than salaries or wages. This component will be allowed as a credit in determining whether a taxpayer has a balance to pay on assessment of $3,000 or more. The second component of the credit will be provisional tax raised on salary or wages income of the preceding year as a result of a shortfall in PAYE deductions.

The coalition does not have any major concerns with that. However, I certainly do have some concerns about the next piece of legislation which is included in this package, and that is the Income Tax (Deferred Interest Securities) (Tax File Number Withholding Tax) Bill 1991, which will impose the tax file number withholding tax. What we are seeing with this is more and more influence of Big Brother taking over in everything that we do.

I am concerned about this particular piece of legislation because, from time to time, constituents, particularly the elderly, complain to me about their tax situation. They believe they have paid their tax; they have made their contribution to society. All they want to do is carry on with their lives without interference. Some were even threatened by the Department of Social Security, which said that if they did not make their tax file number available to the Department they may lose their pension. If ever Big Brother were alive and well, it would be here. This aspect of the tax file number causes a great deal of heartache, particularly for elderly people when they have to make their tax file number available at the threat, if they do not, of possibly losing their pension. I get concerned about that and I know that many residents within my electorate—particularly the elderly—are also concerned.

I understand that my colleague the shadow Minister for health, the honourable member for Lowe, (Dr Bob Woods) will be making some comments in relation to the Medicare levy exemption. The only thing I question is how much this measure saves. There is no costing in the explanatory memorandum as to what the Government hopes to save on this measure.

The further amendments relating to garnishee notices attracted my attention. Regrettably, I have not the time to canvass in great detail all of the implications of the legislation, but I indicate that the coalition has some concerns about the rapid speed with which the Government has presented this legislation and the limited time for debate. Part 10 of the Bill will amend various taxation laws so that, in relation to shares in building societies, the Commissioner may garnishee only those shares known as withdrawable shares. This will prevent the Commissioner from garnisheeing permanent or fixed shares in building societies.

I think that is very appropriate. I am not sure whether it was the Pyramid Building Society which attracted the Minister's attention when he raised this matter, but apparently the Pyramid Building Society had some arrangement about withdrawable shares that may have attracted his attention. Certainly one of Victoria's biggest building societies—the Bendigo Building Society which operates in my own electorate and throughout Victoria—has an asset base of over $700m, has 85 per cent of its lending in residential housing and is one of the most successful building societies in Australia. It is in very good shape.

I now want to refer to section 19, which relates to the direct lodgment of appeals and applications for review. Under the existing law, if a taxpayer is dissatisfied with the Commissioner's decision on an objection, the taxpayer may lodge with the Commissioner of Taxation a request to refer the decision to either the AAT or the Federal Court of Australia. We have some concerns about this, because the proposed new legislation—section 14ZY—does not place a time limit for the Commissioner of Taxation to make a decision allowing or disallowing an objection.

The old legislation did not do this either. However, under the current section 189A, if a taxpayer, having received an objection decision from the Commissioner, advises the Commissioner to refer it to either the Tribunal or the Court, and 60 days have lapsed and the Commissioner has not complied with the request, the taxpayer may give notice in writing to the Commissioner requiring the Commissioner to see that the referral is made and the Commissioner shall, within 60 days after receiving the notice, comply with the request.

Under the proposed system, the Commissioner can take as long as he likes to make a decision on an objection, with no time limit at all. We feel it is desirable to have a safeguard in terms of a time limit. We flag that in another place we will be proposing an amendment to insert after proposed subsection 14ZY(3):

(4) If after 60 days from the date of lodgement, the Commissioner has not caused to be served on the person a written notice of the Commissioner's objection decision in relation to a taxation objection, the person making the taxation objection may give notice in writing to the Commissioner requiring the Commissioner to treat the taxation objection as having been disallowed.

(5) Where a notice has been given to the Commissioner requiring the Commissioner to treat a taxation objection as having been disallowed, the taxation objection shall be taken to be disallowed as from the date of the notice.

SPEECH.PARA: I give the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mr Bilney), who is at the table, a copy of those proposals to alert him to that situation.

PARA.TAB: In the brief time remaining I want to address the question of registered organisations. The amendment being put forward by the Government denies registered organisations the right to maintain franking accounts. I am not sure what is meant by a `registered organisation' and it is not defined in the Bill or in the explanatory memorandum. Perhaps the Minister could enlighten the House and me on that.

There are several other minor technical amendments regarding the wool tax and the definition of a `registered laboratory' in the Wool Tax (Administration) Act 1964. There is another clarifying amendment in which several minor amendments are proposed to clarify the operation of certain deduction provisions which are expressed to be subject to the same limitations on deductibility as section 51. The changes make clear what the provisions mean.

Overseas employment income is another matter which receives some minor technical amendments from the Government. The Income Tax (International Agreements) Amendment Bill (No. 2) is quite a significant Bill in its own right. I am disappointed that there is not sufficient time for all of the relevant issues to be canvassed, because that Bill provides legislative backing for agreements for the prevention of double taxation and tax avoidance with India and Poland. I have recently returned from India; it was encouraging to see just how India is emerging as a nation and moving into higher technology fields.

It is important that these international agreements with India and Poland receive attention from the Government. I am pleased to see this Bill going through the House. I hope that the Government has it right because it is important to future trading arrangements with both of those countries. I for one would certainly like to see Australia in a strong position to continue its trading with India and Poland and to accelerate its trading with India, which is rapidly emerging as a country where Australian products can be traded, particularly in the primary industries area and in the field of high technology. I am sure those hold many opportunities for Australia and I would have liked further time to discuss this legislation. As I say, the Government has treated the Parliament with contempt by debating all these Bills in such a short time. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon we have quite a raft of Bills for consideration in this cognate debate. I want to speak specifically on two of those: the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1991 and the Income Tax (Deferred Interest Securities) (Tax File Number Withholding Tax) Bill 1991. As has been suggested by the Opposition spokesman who has just contributed to this debate, the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Reid), these Bills range fairly widely. To do justice to a consideration of each and every minor detail, one would need more than the time that has been allocated this afternoon.

PARA.TAB: There are one or two important points that need to be made in relation to these Bills. In particular, the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) gives effect to the announcements of the March industry statement that tax concessions for research and development will be retained as a permanent feature. We also have a Bill which will exempt from tax the pay and allowance of members of the Australian defence forces allotted duty in Iraq and Kuwait—something which I am sure is of particular concern to the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mr Bilney), who is at the table. Other amendments contained in this legislation support the existing tax file number arrangements. Relief for small businesses will be provided for in this legislation by way of the deferment of the initial payment of company tax in respect of the 1990-91 income year.

A range of other matters are contained within this legislation but, as I have indicated, the two particular areas that I wish to talk about in my contribution are those areas which are relevant to the tax file number arrangements. As honourable members will recall from debate in this place and elsewhere about appropriate measures designed to combat the rorting of the tax system—rorting that has gone on for quite some time, under whatever government is in control in this country—there have been efforts to combat the level of tax avoidance. For example, we had discussion about putting an Australia Card in place. For various reasons we saw that proposal hit the fence.

What we did see emerge from all of that discussion was the putting in place of a tax file number system. I am pleased to say that certainly in examining that issue the Parliament played a very real role in putting forward a number of suggestions as to how that particular proposal might be implemented and improved. After all, it was through the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration, which has inquired into a number of aspects of the Australian taxation system over the last three or four years, that certain suggestions have been made to government and picked up. I also say that the tax file number proposal was unanimously supported by all honourable members on that Committee.

The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) will amend the income tax law to provide for the assessment and collection of a tax file number withholding tax where an investor has not quoted a tax file number for certain deferred interest investments. This is picking up a potential loophole in legislation, again aimed at making much fairer and more simple the collection of tax which is due and payable to the Australian Government. It comes back to the philosophy of why taxes are collected—to pay for the services demanded of governments, whether they be Federal, State or whatever, by people living in this country. Of course, in that respect we need to ensure that the appropriate levels of tax are paid. The people who want the services should be prepared to pay their contribution towards them.

The Income Tax (Deferred Interest Securities) (Tax File Number Withholding Tax) Bill 1991 seeks to impose a tax file number withholding tax arrangement. These new arrangements, which certainly will not necessarily impact on the revenue, will provide that where a tax file number is not quoted by the investor for certain deferred interest investments, the tax file number withholding tax will be payable jointly and severally by the investor and the investment body. It is specifically geared to ensure that tax avoidance, tax evasion or simply tax deferment—which is a clever way of doing things—is not deferred indefinitely.

Investment bodies which pay the tax file number withholding tax for a deferred interest investment will be able to recover such payment from the investor. As a result of industry consultation which is, of course, a hallmark of this Government, we have decided that the new rules will apply only to investments made on or after 1 February 1992. This will give investment bodies sufficient time to make any necessary changes to their existing practices to give effect to these arrangements.

Of course, the new withholding tax will not represent a new source of revenue to the Government. I think that needs to be clearly understood. It is not a new source of revenue; it is not a replacement tax in any way. Rather, the measure will, in conjunction with the amendments proposed in the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3), support the existing tax file number legislation and ensure that an effective sanction is applied where a tax file number is not quoted for the deferred interest investments covered by the new arrangements.

The honourable member for Bendigo in his contribution raised some of the concerns he had about tax file numbers and the effect that they would have on pensioners and so on. I think it is fair to say that it is through arrangements such as those which this Government has sought to put in place over the last few years that we have seen a massive reduction in taxation evasion and avoidance and the rorting of the system that were certainly characteristic of the past. Therefore, to suggest that certain classes of people should be exempt, I really do not think is appropriate. When the Government chose to put in place a number of other considerations, particularly in respect of pensioners, there were claims that this would be dreadful, that lots of pensioners would be picked up and that their pensions would be affected. Of course, that simply did not happen. I think that the assets test is a classic example of where that measure applied.

Finally, I will comment on foreign source income. It was through the work of the Committee to which I referred earlier that we saw some very meaningful contributions to this particular matter. Foreign source income legislation was introduced by the Government some 18 months or so ago. It sought to crack down on the use by Australian residents of overseas tax jurisdictions for the purpose of minimising or, indeed, completely subverting their taxation responsibilities in this country; in other words, the use of taxation havens. Through the foreign source income legislation we have seen the Government deeming certain countries with comparable tax regimes to be appropriate for Australian taxpayers. Of course, we extract the appropriate company tax rate from people investing in those jurisdictions who do not have comparable tax regimes.

As a government we have always been willing to finetune this legislation to ensure that its operation is a lot smoother. This is exactly what this legislation seeks to do. Three of the amendments proposed in the legislation will operate to relieve double taxation that can arise under the measures that were proposed. This goes to the heart of fairness of the tax system. All Government members should be seeking not to impose onerous taxation burdens on people but to extract what is their fair and reasonable share of taxation commitment to this country because, at the end of the day, people want the services provided by governments.

In the first instance, relief from double taxation is to be provided in relation to an Australian controlled foreign company that has changed its residence from a low tax country either to Australia or a listed comparable tax country. Secondly, corporate unit trusts, public trading trusts and superannuation trusts will be treated similarly to other resident taxpayers by being granted an exemption from Australian tax for distributions from a controlled foreign company out of income previously attributed to them. Finally, the third amendment will ensure that taxpayers are not disadvantaged by the operation of the rules for the conversion and carry forward of foreign losses incurred before 1990-91.

However, we are determined as a government to act against attempts to erode the integrity of the foreign source income measures. Therefore, one amendment will deny taxpayers a tax advantage they have sought to obtain by changing the residence of a controlled foreign company from a comparable tax country to a low tax country. These taxpayers will be denied foreign tax credits on dividends paid by the company out of pre-1990-91 profits accumulated in the comparable tax country. It is all geared towards ensuring that fair, justified and reasonable taxes are paid to the country which, after all, people enjoy for the provision of services to which I referred earlier.

As I have indicated, the Bills are appropriate inasmuch as they tidy up some loose ends associated with legislation already before this place or legislation which has already been passed by this Parliament. They go to the heart of the question of equity and fairness and ensure that taxation revenue to the Government is not minimised by people who seek to arrange their corporate affairs so that they get some benefit, which ordinary PAYE taxpayers cannot afford to do. Accordingly, I believe that it is justified. These particular Bills go part of the way to ensuring that that is the case.

TALK.START.PARA: —Again this Parliament—the place where everything is expected to be put on public show, and where people of Australia can get some idea of what the Executive Government is up to; otherwise termed `keeping the so and sos honest'—has been put under time constraints with each and every piece of legislation under the guillotine. After the discussions we had in previous sessions, I thought that the Government could talk to its bureaucracy, get its house in order and have this sort of legislation passed with proper debate.

PARA.TAB: We have seen the results of the last session: massive amendments have had to be brought to the Parliament because of legislation not being properly considered in this place. But here we are again. We have five pieces of legislation being debated cognately and under the guillotine, but with barely two hours granted for their debate. We have that length of time only because of debate being curtailed in the matter of public importance.

I wish to refer to some of these Bills, particularly the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill, which comes to this place each year. It deals with the applicable thresholds under which individuals—married couples, single parents and others—are exempt from the levy. I note that this year the income threshold for individuals is unchanged at $11,745. But there has been an increase in the appropriate area—married couples and sole parents—where, if the family income does not exceed $19,674, parents will not be obliged to pay the Medicare levy. The income threshold for those people will continue to be increased by a further $2,100 for each dependent child or student. As the Minister Assisting the Treasurer (Mr Free) pointed out in his second reading speech, that would lift the threshold for a family with three children to $25,974. That is of some assistance to people whose income is under great pressure in the present economic climate, which of course has been created by this Government.

In all of this we have to say that the Medicare levy is almost fraudulently presented to the Australian people as the cost of the Medicare service. I am almost sure, without checking, that the levy still stands at 1.25 per cent, and probably something less than $3,000m of tax collections. It is a far cry from the massive cost that has been imposed on the Australian people by the introduction of Medicare—a cost that is doing nothing for the people. It seems that there is only one parallel in the whole operation, and that is that the queues waiting to get into hospitals are growing at the same rate as the expenditure. One would expect the queues to get shorter once the expenditure increased.

Recently I went to the Australian National University where I addressed a group of students on their particular concerns as to the lack of funds available for education these days. It is interesting that we have a common situation in hospitals and universities: in both cases there are now massive waiting lists. People who otherwise qualify—in different ways of course; one group academically and the other because they are sick—are waiting to get into the particular institution concerned.

I looked at the 1983-84 Budget outlays and took out some figures. Today health expenditure is almost all consumed by Medicare. I know that a following speaker could say, `Medicare—the Health Insurance Commission—only spends this much'. But let us face it, it nearly all goes into supporting our universal so-called free health service, which is supposed to be funded by the Medicare levy.

Health expenditure in the 1983-84 Budget represented 9.72 per cent of the total tax dollar. In other words, 9.72 cents in every dollar went on health. At that time, 9.04 per cent of the tax dollar was spent on education. Today, education gets 9.06 per cent of the tax dollar—up 0.02 per cent—and health gets 15 per cent of the tax dollar. So, in the lifetime of the Medicare levy, the percentage of the tax dollar spent on education has stayed practically the same while that spent on health has fast approached a 100 per cent increase.

If I were one of those young students being denied further education because there are no places, or one of these people with elective surgery problems, some of which are pretty serious—recently in my State a woman had her toes amputated because she had been unable to get appropriate attention for a so-called `elective' type problem of circulation difficulties in her leg—I would be pretty annoyed to think that this Government has been so inefficient in its management of the health dollar that, having practically doubled the outlays, it had in fact increased the size of the waiting lists, which were practically non-existent when Medicare was introduced.

It is an amazing situation. Time and time again the Government was at pains to tell us about the two million people who were uninsured. I do not know what insurance has to do with the price of fish. Those people were not unprotected; they had access to all medical services. Of course, it was unnecessary for many to be privately insured; they were simply able to get the medical services they needed, and when they needed them. They were not like women who wrote to me during my time as shadow Minister for health. I remind the next speaker that I did complete a health policy. If the Government had taken some notice of it at the time, it would not be facing the dreadful consequences of disruption within its own Party.

TALK.START.PARA: —Your lot knocked it on the head, not us.

—I am making the point because I am frequently criticised for not producing one—I produced one all right. The simple fact is that my health policy tried to address the problems now confronting the Government, which has a tiger by the tail and does not know how to let go. In fact, the tiger has managed to give the Government a couple of severe nicks and a bit of a mauling, but it still has hold of its tail. This is the problem confronting the Government: it forgot the first concept of human nature. It created a universal system. It practically created a licence to print money for the providers but thought it would not happen.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. M.J.R. MacKellar)—Order! I am reluctant to interrupt the honourable member, but I remind him that the Bill is about the threshold level for payment of the Medicare levy. I would like him to bring his remarks back to the subject of the Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you want me to protect you?

—No; I will fight on. Mr Deputy Speaker, please remember that I quite consciously took you through all the details of this legislation at the beginning and gave you all the figures so that you were well informed, but I thought—
—I have been listening very attentively to the honourable member. I now ask him to get back to the subject of the Bill.

—The subject of the Bill is the levies applicable to people and the consequent costs, and I am going down the road of the real costs. The implication in this piece of legislation is that people with incomes under this threshold pay nothing for health. My point is that the Medicare levy from which they are exempt is a fraction of their health costs. As such, they should be warned that life is not as good as the Minister's second reading speech would tell them. That is my real point in raising these other issues relevant to the system.

PARA.TAB: Therefore, it is an appropriate time for me to give the Government a bit of advice on how to rectify the situation so that this legislation is truthful; in other words, gives the full story. These people of lower socio-economic circumstances who think they are not being taxed should, in fact, not be taxed.

We hear a lot about hidden taxes in this place. We have the wholesale sales tax—totally hidden. We have excise in fuel—totally hidden. And, of course, we have health costs—totally hidden, notwithstanding what the people are told. People on a particular income level—for instance, $25,974 for a family with three children—genuinely believe that they pay nothing for health. But, with the massive growth in tax for health expenditures which has occurred in the life of Medicare, those exempt people are paying a lot of money.

But being exempt does not entitle them to get into hospital. That is another point that I am trying to make. The Government has made a mess of it because, in doubling these expenditures and in applying taxes to these people who think that they are exempt, the Government has provided no service. Of course, this Government lacks the honesty of the New Zealand Government. During my time as shadow Minister for health I attended a conference where a Dame Dorothy Fraser was the keynote speaker. Reading a speech, a copy of which I have obtained, she said that there are 50,000 people on waiting lists for public hospital admission in New Zealand, and that waiting lists are the means by which public hospital services are rationed.

She then went on to complain about the administration of waiting lists, pointing out that those in the know in the public service or politics were able to get pushed up the list. She did not for a minute complain about the fact that the Government rationed public hospital services. The difference between that lady and this Government is that this Government keeps telling us that waiting lists are all a myth, that it has the thing under control. Yet, of course, honourable members opposite in their own Caucus fought tooth and nail—and did not find a solution. In fact, their $2.50 solution will get them nowhere and will, of course, create more distortions.

The people who got this threshold exemption today really have substantial reason to complain, because they are still paying if they are paying any tax at all. Of course, some people with family incomes of $25,974 would be paying substantial personal tax. The other day I employed a young man at $500 a week. In handing him his first cheque, I gave him something like $415. I said, `Goodness! My wife'—who does the pay in our family—`must have taken out more than was appropriate'. This bloke has a wife and two kids. I thought that this could not possibly be the amount of tax that he has to pay—but it is. He was more up to date than I was. He said, `Oh, no, that is what I was expecting'. That is $85 a week tax on a young man with a wife and two young children. Of course, of that $85, 15 per cent—he is below the threshold; he would just scrape in—is going off to fund his health services. If he is not listening to me today, I intend to go back and tell him that, because I think that that is a matter of great importance and interest.

This is the point we make: the Government got it wrong. It should never have attempted a universal service, and it should never have attempted to create the situation that exists and then blame the providers, as it has done. Whether the Government blames doctors, pathologists or pharmacists, the Government is at fault, firstly for attempting the impossible and secondly for complaining about the number of doctors in the system. It is pretty obvious what will happen when people see a system in which there is no limit to the amount of business one can get.

Doctors have a great advantage over most business people; if they say to us that we had better come back next week, we usually go back next week. They are not to be blamed for that, any more than we should blame the doctor who feels it necessary to give substantial pathological services because he believes in his mind that he should take all those steps. Of course, in these days of great litigation, one might wonder how many steps a doctor should take. That is his problem. Nobody wants to encourage abuse but, if one creates a system such as that created by this Government and then expects that there will not be a growth in the number of providers, one does not understand the fundamentals of human nature.

In relation to health, I will stop with that particular point because I would like to make a couple of remarks on some other areas. Briefly, we have some fringe benefits tax amendments which, as I understand it, raise the levy somewhat. But I wonder whether the Government, which is now very concerned about resource projects and about giving people jobs, realises what it is doing in relation to the amount of construction in remote areas—which is even more labour intensive and probably more rewarding for workers who are able to get that work—and how the fringe benefits tax has killed the development of our north.

When I was a young man everybody said that we had to develop the north in case some of our northern neighbours did it for us. I do not know whether that threat is past, but I know this: when we have diamond mines and other mining developments with only a token resident work force, with people being flown in every couple of weeks, we will never get development. The thing that has done that is the fringe benefits tax.

Whilst the fringe benefits tax might have been applicable to luncheons and to taking the wife and kids out on a tax free dinner, I think it was very foolish for the Government to apply the tax to those remote areas. As I recollect, the coalition has always said that it would review that situation. The tax is killing the north. If one goes to Argyle Diamonds, one will find hardly one permanent resident. All of the new developments are now based on flying people in and flying them out, because flying people in and out of their job is not a fringe benefit. But the minute one gives them a house, it is. It is easy to say that they should build their own houses. What? In the middle of the desert? They are not likely to do that. That is killing the north-west and it is killing our remote area development. If we are not prepared to populate those areas, maybe some of those predictions of people from 20 or 30 years ago will come to pass.

I draw the matter to the Government's attention because I think it is time that it realised that what seemed to be a rather simple thing in fact is not. The fringe benefits tax was built around the bloke in the Mercedes driving past the people in the tram—as the then Treasurer, the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating), described it—who had their lunches in their brown paper bags. It sounded very convincing. Of course, when one looks at the tax statistics it is interesting to note that, a bit like the people who are being told that they are exempt, those workers in the tram have not since then got one extra sandwich in their brown paper bag—not one.

TALK.START.PARA: —And he is not in the tram with them, either.

—The honourable member can say that again; if the car had dark windows, it would probably be the former Treasurer's. All of that tax was levied, but there are no more sandwiches in the brown paper bag, and the biggest losers from the current economic situation are, of course, those same people. These people have little to thank the Government for in respect of the fringe benefits tax. The tax did not provide the benefits to the people for whom the benefits were supposed to be provided, the low income workers, as is the case with the Medicare legislation.

PARA.TAB: We heard a couple of remarks about income tax international agreements. In terms of these international agreements, one of the great concerns of government these days—and I think rightly so—is one which the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Martin) happened to mention: tax havens. They include the Cook Islands, the Bahamas—you name it. I have always wondered why, when the Government brought in its imputation proposal, it chose to retain the tax on companies and let them pass franked dividends to shareholders. I still believe that if the Government reversed that it would find nobody in the corporate sector needing a tax haven, because corporations would not pay tax.

I do not believe that corporations enjoy profits. I believe that that is a myth we have created for ourselves. We hear of BHP, the big Australian. BHP is a piece of paper. It is the shareholders of BHP who should be making the profits. But, funnily, the first benefits of any great corporation go to the staff and the people for whom it creates jobs. I think that those corporations ought to be given every opportunity to provide those benefits and to do away with their search for tax havens; when they transfer money out of their business for any reason, it should be taxed appropriately—and I would be quite brutal on people who tried to turn that into some sort of tax rort.

Finally, I note that the tax file number was mentioned by the honourable member for Macarthur. People have been saying to me for some years now, `There is not much difference today between the Labor Party and the Liberal Party'. I say back to them, `If you believe that, go and try to open a bank account'. A policeman rang me recently to tell me that he walked into his local bank to open an account for a blue light disco and he was told, `Constable, we need some identification'. He said, `Here is my police identification; it has my picture on it, my full description, my signature and my police number'. He was told, `Well, that is worth 35 out of 100. What else have you got?'. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps I will be distracted from what I intended to say by the comments of the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey).

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. M.J.R. MacKellar)—But your remarks will be relevant to the legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —They will be relevant to what he said. He is correct in suggesting that as shadow Minister for health he did cobble together a health policy which, conceptually, I think had many aspects of merit. The basic thrust of it was that the well and the wealthy would have to pay more for their health care. Unfortunately, he could not get it past the Opposition leadership. There was a difficulty for him because the well and the wealthy would have had to make a significantly greater contribution.

PARA.TAB: The Medicare levy does not cover the costs of health care in this country, and I believe the honourable member for O'Connor is correct to say that the perception in the community is that it does cover the costs of health care. We need to understand that whether health care is paid for by the private sector or by the public purse, it is expensive. I am one member on this side of the House who supports the view that the levy should more closely represent what the actual costs are. I have put that view many times. I believe that if the levy more closely represented what the actual costs were, the vast majority of people—or many of them who believe that the levy represents their health insurance—would have a closer understanding of how expensive health care is and what the actual costs are.

But the honourable member for O'Connor is wrong to suggest that in the halcyon days of the 1970s there were no hospital queues. I was working in the public hospital sector in Perth at the time and very often I was responsible for handling waiting lists for outpatients and for surgery. Those have been a part of our public hospital system for a long time—they existed in the 1960s, too. To run an efficient hospital it is important to have some sort of a waiting list. I am not suggesting that waiting lists as they stand at the moment are desirable, but it is important to understand that the people who are on the waiting lists are waiting for elective surgery, not for emergency treatment or treatment that must be given straight away. It does not do us any good to talk down the health care system in this country, because it is a very good system and one that provides a substantial service.

The honourable member then suggested that in some way Medicare has created an oversupply of doctors at the moment. The cause and effect relationship is a pretty tenuous one. All those people who are now practising medicine, having just joined the system, went through a five- or six-year training course and two years in the hospital. They are a result of decisions made even before we came to government, because of the time it takes to train a doctor and for him to become registered.

I would think that things such as the closed shop mentality that exists in the specialist colleges has something to do with supply and demand in particular specialities and the waiting lists that we have. I think immigration has something to do with the number of doctors, and the policies of medical schools have something to do with the number of doctors. So in all of those areas the cause and effect relationship that the honourable member is trying to draw is very tenuous and it would not stand up to much scrutiny.

The co-payment is part of a structure which will bring about a change in the way in which medical services are delivered. My view is that the co-payment should exist for all classes of people. The co-payment is not a new concept; it was part of the original Medicare structure for some patients. We have extended that, and my view is that it should be extended to the gamut of those who want services. It is not a view that is supported by the Government, but I think it makes sense; intellectually, it is a consistent argument. I will not get distracted any more, Mr Deputy Speaker, because I understand that you are concerned about the way in which this debate has become wide ranging and the way in which the honourable member for O'Connor ranged into the area of health care.

A number of other pieces of legislation are before us, and many of them deal with taxation measures which are of concern to constituents. In respect of changes in the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill 1991, the legislation extends the threshold of the levy and gives some relief to people on low incomes. I think that is a desirable thing.

The Fringe Benefits Tax Amendment Bill aligns the rates. Presently, fringe benefits are taxed at 47 per cent, whereas the top marginal rate is 48.25 per cent. That represents the marginal rate plus the levy. The aligning of those two rates is something which simply brings some consistency into the way in which the legislation operates.

The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill deals with a large number of aspects of taxation. For example, tax deductions will be available for expenditure incurred for environmental impact studies, which gives fact to the commitment of the Government in respect of the environment and the necessity for environmental impact studies to be undertaken by many people who are involved in developing projects. By this legislation, the plant and the articles that are required for environmental impact studies are, appropriately, eligible for taxation relief.

There are a number of other changes within the Bill. One deals with the capital gains tax cost base. It allows taxpayers to offset non-deductible costs such as interest, repairs, rates and taxes and insurance premiums which are not part of the acquisition costs of the particular item but are part of the costs of holding those items. I believe the capital gains tax legislation, which is an important part of making our tax system fairer, is being improved by these amendments.

What the honourable member for O'Connor said about there being a gulf between the Opposition and the Government is portrayed starkly by our position on the capital gains tax legislation. It has been our view—and I think it is a view that is internally consistent—that capital gains, in the year that they are realised, represent income; as such, they should be taxed along with other income. The position that obtains on the other side of the House is significantly different from that, and this represents one of the seminal aspects of taxation law on which the Government and the Opposition are significantly different.

An example which I have given before is of somebody who sells a package of shares or a property and earns a $30,000 capital gain, given indexation for inflation and other factors that are taken into account. I believe the suggestion that that should not be taxed whereas the wage-earner earning $30,000 in the same year should be taxed is an absurd one. It is clear that we should treat all income realised in any particular year the same. The capital gains tax changes within this Bill improve the legislation, something that those of us on this side of the House would argue is required.

As was mentioned by the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Martin), there are amendments within part of the legislation before us to support the existing tax file legislation. This again represents an area of taxation law in which the starkness of the difference between our view and the view of the Opposition is put under the microscope. It is clear that the tax file legislation represents an opportunity for the Government to collect large amounts of taxation which previously went begging, and our reinforcing the legislation by introducing this Bill today is an important part of our legislative structure. We confirm the tax concession for research and development at a rate of 125 per cent—something that I am sure honourable members opposite will endorse and see as a positive measure which reinforces our position on encouraging research and development.

As also mentioned by the honourable member for Macarthur, the Income Tax (International Agreements) Amendment Bill (No. 2) brings into effect prevention of double taxation and provides a level of security for the tax rules for arrangements between Australia and India and Australia and Poland. Indeed, the allocation of taxing rights between contracting countries over different categories of income is part of the way in which we go about this. It allows us to specify rules which will resolve complaints and claims between the residential status of a taxpayer and the source of income. Indeed, this piece of legislation is important from the point of view of improving the way in which we tax those people who have interests in other countries and in Australia.

It provides also for the prevention of avoidance and evasion of taxes on various forms of income between the treaty partners. It is something which, as the honourable member for Macarthur and Chairman of the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration has mentioned, has been reviewed by that Committee. It is an important area of tax policy which enables us, in a very correct and proper way, to make tax law understandable, simple and understood for those people who have interests in other countries and in Australia.

There are a large number of pieces of legislation in this package before the House. The first speaker from the Opposition, the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Reid), suggested that the Opposition was looking for some minor amendments, but I think I can summarise by saying that, as a whole, he suggested there was very little that was opposed by the Opposition. It is the case that, while the time for debate on these pieces of legislation has not been as substantial as we would have liked, essentially there is a great deal of accord between the Opposition and the Government in respect of them and they have my support.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to address myself briefly to the fringe benefits tax amendments in respect of this whole group of taxation Bills which unfortunately is being brought down, once again, under guillotine. It is a shame that time and time again we come into this House and talk about the relevance or lack thereof of parliament. Parliament as an institution, it seems to me, is increasingly under attack by this Labor Government. This is not a view that I brought to this House of Representatives, because I came here with no firm understanding of the mores of parliament, of its institutions, or of the basic mechanisms within which it operates. I came to this place, if you will, with an open mind seeking to learn and participate as a representative of the people of the electorate from which I was sent.

PARA.TAB: However, over time, it has come to be my view that Executive Government drives this place and those of us who rise to speak to an empty chamber do so with increasing irrelevance. Executive Government treats us, firstly, with contempt; secondly, with disdain; and, thirdly, with lack of any consideration for any of the views we might put or the points that we might make. The Labor Party controls the numbers on the floor of the House of Representatives. The Labor Party disdains the value of its committee system, which is supposed to operate on a bipartisan basis. I have made speeches in this place before regarding the relevance of parliament and how I believe that we could improve that relevance if we gave more power and a greater ability to consider to the bipartisan committee system. If we allowed it even to examine legislation before this place, perhaps we would put more pressure on the bureaucracy, on the civil servants who draft the legislation which frequently comes before this place flawed and lacking input from the people.

We have this week visiting the Parliament the first parliamentary committee from the New Zealand Government. That committee parallels the committee of which I am a member, except that those committee members call their committee Education and Science and ours is Employment, Education and Training, tracking DEET. It was interesting today in our first meeting on this historic occasion that we learned that New Zealand's committees are actual statutory authorities; that is, they are enabled by Act of parliament, not just enabled by the House of Representatives or in fact allowed continuance by the Speaker.

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. M.J.R. MacKellar)—Order! I have allowed the honourable member considerable latitude. I would like him to address his remarks in a way that shows that he is considering the Bills under cognate debate at the present time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I appreciate your drawing that to my attention. I suppose I headed in that direction only because I decry the fact that, once again, we are debating Bills under the gag. I did rise to speak briefly about the fringe benefits tax. I guess it relates to what I said a few minutes ago regarding my conceptions of this place when I came into Federal Parliament. It is the fringe benefits tax brought in by this Labor Government that essentially brought me to this place. It was not, I would remind the House, the incidence of the tax itself so much as the attitude of the bureaucracy to it.

PARA.TAB: Late one day in my office in private industry, in private enterprise where real goods and real services are produced, where wealth is created, I sat down to read a document put out by a gentleman by the name of Trevor Boucher entitled Guide to employees on a fringe benefits tax. I very seldom get angry, but that day I became particularly angry not at the tax, not even at the unfairness of taxing one body, a corporation, for the tax of another man, the individual, but because the document itself, in bureaucratic-speak, said, `We do not believe that those who are in business, industry or commerce produce goods or services wanted by the public; rather, we believe you're all there just to rip people off and this is why we are bringing in this fringe benefits tax. We are going to catch'—as the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) said —`these people out there who rip the system off by living in remote areas of Australia where it is dry and hot and the flies surround you day and night, and a company has the audacity to let them have a house at reduced rent, and we are going to charge the company fringe benefits tax because that is a benefit to the employee'.

I think honourable members on the Government side of the House got it all wrong. I think probably they got it very right when they decided that we needed to consider fringe benefits as part of the overall tax system. The honourable member for Perth (Dr Charlesworth) said, `In all these Bills we are attempting to make the tax system fairer'. On this side of the House, I would say, `We would like to make the tax system more fair'. So, when we address ourselves to the fringe benefits tax, there are a number of other issues that arise cognately.

If one looks at Austudy, the family allowance and the family allowance supplement, one finds that the basis for means testing those benefits to Australian citizens is taxable income. Taxable income does not take into account fringe benefits. But the tax law takes into account fringe benefits because it says that, if one individual is given a vehicle to use as part of his work requirements, that individual may use the vehicle for personal use and the company may then pay a tax for his use of the vehicle for personal business. That is called a fringe benefits tax.

Let us take Joe Bloggs, and let us make him an employee of the XYZ Mousetrap Company. Joe Bloggs gets a salary of $10,000 a year. He also gets a free vehicle that he drives in his work, which is a few miles a year, and he drives it many miles a year on personal business. He pays no tax on that vehicle because the company pays it on his behalf. Joe Bloggs also receives from the company an allowance to send his children to a very expensive private school. Joe Bloggs pays no tax on that allowance to send his children to the very expensive private school, because the company pays the tax on his benefit. Joe Bloggs takes out a low interest loan from the company and borrows $50,000 or $100,000 at one per cent interest. Joe Bloggs pays no tax on the value of the interest that he would have paid had he taken the loan in the marketplace; instead the company pays a fringe benefits tax on his behalf. All of these items realistically add to Joe Bloggs's ability to live, to eat, to purchase and to consume; but Joe Bloggs is not taxed, the company is taxed.

So we tax the wealth generators—that is, businesses—which do real things to make real products and provide real services that society demands and requires. That is why we are in such a mess today, is it not? It is because the former Treasurer, the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating), decided to tax individuals and companies almost out of business. We do not have as many companies paying fringe benefits tax now; there are far fewer companies in this country to pay that tax.

The point that I am trying to make, as succinctly as possible, is that if we are to means test Austudy as a massive benefit to students in Australia, to assist them with their living expenses while they study in a senior secondary, post-compulsory environment, why do we not include the benefits that an individual receives through fringe benefits as well as through taxable income? Why do we not do so? And I would like an answer to this question if possible: why do we not include fringe benefits for family allowance and family allowance supplement? I can give the answer. The answer lies at the heart of the reason why the fringe benefits tax was charged to the company and not to the individual, which was, and continues to be, that it is so difficult to charge the individual and the individual is unlikely to report to the Government the true value of fringe benefits received by him or her from the company. It is too hard, and people will rort the system; but we can trust companies, so we trust the companies to pay the fringe benefits tax for benefits which they give to employees and which they do not enjoy themselves and for which they receive no taxation advantage. It does work pretty well. In fact, the Government frequently boasts about the millions of dollars collected each year in fringe benefits tax. The Government boasts that the amount has increased substantially. We should have known at the beginning—

SPEECH.PARA: These amendments propose some minor alterations to the provisional tax and dividend imputation arrangements proposed by the Bill. The amendments also propose changes to the capital gains and losses provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act to overcome problems facing holders of shares in companies which are in liquidation. The amendments are not expected to have a significant impact on the revenue.

PARA.TAB: Regarding provisional tax, the amendments will simplify the provisional tax amendments in the Bill which affect those taxpayers who are required to pay provisional tax in 1991-92 because of a shortfall of at least $3,000 in pay-as-you-earn tax deductions from 1990-91 salary or wages income.

The amendments proposed in the Bill would have required the preceding year's provisional tax credit for those taxpayers to be split between salary or wages and other income. The effect of the amendment being proposed is that, in determining whether taxpayers come within the provisional tax system because there is a shortfall in tax instalment deductions from salary or wages, the whole provisional tax credit will be excluded. This exclusion will overcome potential problems for taxpayers which would have arisen if the provisional tax credit was split as proposed in the Bill.

The Bill also proposes changes to the imputation provisions that will result in companies receiving franking credits when they pay their tax and not when the tax is assessed. The amendments being circulated are of a technical nature and will provide for further franking debits and credits to arise to a life assurance company when its original assessment for a year of income is made.

The amendments are necessary to ensure that the franking capacity of a life assurance company, that is attributable to initial and further payments of tax, is calculated on the basis of the company's tax liability for the year of income to which those payments relate. Without these amendments the calculation would be made on the basis of the preceding year's income.

The amendments will provide a mechanism to convert the basis on which a life assurance company's franking capacity is affected by an initial or further payment of company tax or any reduction because of a refund from the tax liability of the preceding year to that of the current year.

Regarding capital gains tax, the proposed amendment to the capital gains and losses provisions will address community concerns by allowing shareholders in companies in liquidation to realise capital losses on valueless shares. The proposed amendment will apply where a taxpayer owns shares in a company in liquidation and the liquidator has indicated that there is no likelihood of shareholders receiving a distribution in the course of winding up a company. In these circumstances, if the taxpayer makes an election, the taxpayer will be taken to have disposed of, and immediately reacquired, the shares for no consideration at the time the liquidator's statement was made.

This amendment will overcome the particular problem facing holders of shares in companies which are in liquidation. Due to the operation of the corporations law these shareholders are prevented from transferring their valueless shares and realising a capital loss. Full details of the amendment are contained in the supplementary explanatory memorandum being circulated to honourable members. I commend the amendments to the Committee.

DEBATE.TITLE: STATES GRANTS (TAFE ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1991[COGNATE BILL:HIGHER EDUCATION FUNDING AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1991]

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 17 October, on motion by Mr Baldwin:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Jenkins)—I understand that it is the wish of the House to debate the States Grants (TAFE Assistance) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1991 concurrently with the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1991. There being no objection, the Chair will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Dr D.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to address the first part of my remarks to the States Grants (TAFE Assistance) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1991. This Bill is introduced in the context of active debate about the future role of TAFE. This debate raises important issues of policy about the future of training in Australia and of Federal-State relations. The main issues are, first of all, the relationship of TAFE to schools, universities and colleges and private providers of training; secondly, the establishment of full and adequate measures of key competencies required in the workplace, that is, the outputs of education and training; thirdly, ensuring that TAFE operates in a regulatory framework which gives institutions the flexibility they need to respond to the requirements of students, industry and the local community; and, finally, providing adequate funding to meet the growing demand for TAFE services over this decade.

PARA.TAB: While TAFE is principally the responsibility of the States, the current Government has, I regret to say, done little that is constructive in this area during its term of office. It has generally resisted the effective monitoring and assessment of the outcomes of education and training, attempting control through what one might describe as the input side—control over institutions themselves.

The accord has prevented any support for the effective removal of industrial relations rigidities. Indeed, it has given active encouragement to drawing training issues into the industrial relations arena. It has sought to achieve performance by the imposition of central performance indicators without any long term framework or strategy. It was criticised for this last year by the Skills Formation Council. Finally, the Government established the unified national system of higher education without any proper consideration of the relationship of TAFE to the new institutions or of what the ending of the binary system might mean for TAFE.

The October 1990 report of the committee on training costs, the Deveson Committee, described Australian training systems as arguably `at the back of the pack' internationally. The coalition has advocated for some time the reform of TAFE, making it a more flexible and competitive sector responsive to consumer demand. Our approach is very different from the approach which the responsible Minister on the Government side of the House, the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services (Mr Baldwin), has taken. He seems to believe, in relation to TAFE, as he believes in relation to higher education—and one suspects in relation to schools—that the only way one can achieve quality and performance is through increased central regulation. In the one area where he has had free rein, the effect has been a disaster. The coalition policy supports—it supports the Government in this—wider scope for fee paying courses, significant autonomy in staffing matters, increased autonomy to raise funds from non-government sources and, where possible, the provision of subsidies to students through TAFE study grants of one kind or another.

In the past 13 months the Government has received the reports of two independent inquiries into training, each of which addressed aspects of the role of TAFE in Australia's overall education and training systems. The Training Costs Review Committee, chaired by Ivan Deveson, submitted its report, known as the Deveson report, in October 1990. The Australian Education Council's review committee on young people's participation in post-compulsory education and training, the Finn committee, presented its report in August this year.

The Deveson report recommended the development of open and flexible training markets and the development of TAFE as institutions focused on training the trainers. The Chairman of that Committee, Ivan Deveson, then Chief Executive of Nissan Australia, warned—in words which were clearly directed towards the Government—in the foreword to his report:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . it is critical to the future success of training and award restructuring that union/employee demands relative to training costs must be maintained at reasonable levels—
and that—
. . . the whole subject of training must not become excessively burdened with the rigidities of the industrial relations system.

The report recommended, firstly, that people, not courses, should be subsidised. Such an approach would better identify the subsidy element. Secondly, it recommended that the development of a national training market required national recognition and portability of skills. The method of accreditation at present varies from State to State. Thirdly, it recommended that there should be greater flexibility for TAFE to charge fees and that the Commonwealth should remove its current regulations which prevent these fees. This would end the bewildering array of fees and charges. I am pleased to say that, with the bipartisan support of the Opposition, the Commonwealth did move in this direction.

PARA.TAB: The report further recommended that a deferred fee or HECS type scheme could be discussed, although the equity and practical problems with such a scheme should not be underestimated. It recommended as an alternative the provision of loans to needy students. It suggested that the Government should encourage TAFE to substantially increase its role as a provider of training services to industry, mainly on a cost recovery basis, and that this should include the provision of training support. It suggested that TAFE should develop new, more flexible staff employment relations and financial and administrative arrangements which enable TAFE to compete in the market, and recommended the setting of targets for entrepreneurial activity—that is, externally raised income. The report further suggested that TAFE needed increased funding—in fact, real increases of some 5 per cent over the next five years with a substantial proportion going into the promotion of equal opportunity objectives—and that Austudy benefits for TAFE students should be reviewed.

The Committee chaired by Brian Finn of IBM recommended significantly increased participation in and the development of target attainment levels for post-compulsory education and training. The report noted that there was a particular need to strengthen the role of industry and to enhance the status of TAFE as a post-school option. I am bound to say that the emphasis that the Government has given in its education and training policies has not been conducive to raising the status of TAFE in the eyes of the community because in the whole process of reforming the higher education system there was clearly no consideration given to how TAFE might successfully interact with that system. In fact, the implication was that if one was not going on to higher education after school one was not undertaking a satisfactory option. I think the Government carries a burden of responsibility for the problem that TAFE now faces in raising its status in the eyes of the community, but it is most important that that happens.

The Committee recommended the establishment of a set of new national targets for post-compulsory education and training which encompass schools, higher education, TAFE and other training, and which identify target levels for attainment as well as for participation.
