We may well take these words to again be pointed very much at the fact that throughout its term of office the Government has emphasised the numbers of students in the system but done precious little, if anything, to monitor effectively the levels of attainment that students are reaching, either in the schools or in the training systems.

In essence, the Finn Committee proposed that almost all young people should take sufficient post-compulsory education and training to complete year 12 or some other initial post-school qualification and at least half should go on to higher levels. More specifically, the Committee proposed the following set of targets: at least a level one traineeship or participation in year 12 for all 18-year-olds by 1995; at least a level two traineeship or progress towards a higher level vocational or academic qualification for almost all 20-year-olds by the year 2001; and at least a vocational certificate level three or progress toward a vocational qualification above level three or a diploma or degree for at least 50 per cent of 22-year-olds by 2001.

This set of targets can be distilled into a single summary target that by the year 2001, 95 per cent of 19-year-olds should have completed year 12 or an initial post-school qualification or be participating in Education or training. To support this target, the Committee proposed that governments should agree to introduce a post-compulsory education and training guarantee whereby all young people would be guaranteed a place in school or TAFE after year 10 for two years of full time education or training or its equivalent part time for up to three years.

The Committee recommended that the State or Territory governments should introduce a uniform compulsory requirement to attend school unless exempted at least to the end of year 10; the current entry level training arrangement should be reformed; and that a new entry level training system should be developed which extends these reformed arrangements beyond the existing apprenticeship and traineeship occupations.

In 1990, total national expenditure on TAFE was some $1.6 billion, of which the Commonwealth contributed $375.1m. Meeting the TAFE participation target would undoubtedly require a significant expansion of TAFE funding, although demographic factors will restrain this growth. The Committee estimated that, on current trends, TAFE expenditure would reach $1.95 billion by the year 2000. The target for expenditure under the Committee's proposals would be $2.19 billion. The Committee concluded that TAFE's current dependence for some 80 per cent of its funding on the States would mean that the TAFE system would continue to be squeezed.

The Finn report was welcomed by the coalition for its emphasis on the better reporting of educational and training outcomes as a guarantee of quality rather than an emphasis which would have reflected, I regret to say, the Government's approach on the central regulation of inputs. Nevertheless, a signal shortcoming of the report is its failure to address some of the vital structural issues involved in lifting incentives and improving morale in education and training institutions.

A broader, more far reaching approach would have set an agenda for reform which emphasised the need for more autonomous and flexible institutions, with the capacity to respond to the student market and to the needs of industry. It would have emphasised the need for industrial relations reform and the devolution of staff training matters to TAFE institutions and greater independence of management in the schools and TAFE. Neither of these vital structural reforms was considered by the Finn Committee. I regret to say that, in the flurry of announcements and briefings to the press that have been given by the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) in the lead up to the Special Premiers Conference, there has been a great deal of reference to the willingness of the Commonwealth to centralise funding and control over TAFE but, so far as I can see, there have been no announcements and no recognition on the public platform of the need for the structural reforms in TAFE that are absolutely fundamental to improving the accessibility, performance and status of these institutions.

The recent Government proposals that are being put before the Premiers effectively adopt the Finn No. 1 option for the Commonwealth to assume funding for TAFE. The proposals have received a mixed reception. They have received some positive comment from the business community and from Mr Finn himself. I noticed that the New South Wales Minister for Further Education, Training and Employment, Mr Fahey, was quoted in the Sydney Morning Herald of 18 October as calling the proposal blackmail and saying that it was unacceptable. According to the Australian of 16 October, South Australia's Labor Party Minister for Further Education, Mr Rann, said that his State would reject any East German centralist model for TAFE. One can only endorse those sentiments because he has seen such a model imposed on higher education.

Even within the Minister's own Party, I think there is clearly a perception of his centralist tendencies and their deadening effect. No doubt there will be much sympathy on the back benches of the Party for these kinds of comments. It is common knowledge that the Dawkins model for higher education has been a disaster, with the destruction of the binary system, the destruction of institutional autonomy and the destruction of collegial relations within those institutions. There is a hidden agenda for higher education in relation to enterprise bargaining which was revealed by Mr Paul Hickey earlier this year in Darwin. I am sure that members of the public are grateful to him for revealing that secret agenda. He is a very honest public servant. It certainly gave the lie to the nonsense which was put about both by the senior and the junior Ministers in this area when that matter was raised as an important item for reform by the Opposition.

Clearly the issues involved are politically complex. We will learn much from the discussions at the Premiers Conference. But, whatever the outcome of that conference, the coalition will continue to recognise the key role of TAFE in Australia's training system. We acknowledge the need for the building up of the TAFE system over future years.

The coalition will not oppose this Bill, but I foreshadow an amendment which I will move criticising the Government for its failure to recognise adequately the role of technical and further education in Australia's education and training systems, its continuing emphasis on centralist solutions and its failure to recognise the need for more flexible TAFE institutions which can be more responsive to student and industry demands.

The Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No. 2) provides grants of financial assistance to the States, the Northern Territory and higher education institutions. Among its provisions is the transference to the Commonwealth of Victoria's share of the responsibility for funding the higher education program at the Victorian College of Agriculture and Horticulture so that it is funded entirely through the Higher Education Funding Act from next year.

The VCAH is a multi-campus institution, now amalgamated with the University of Melbourne. The college is unique throughout Australia because only one other college that I am aware of, the Darwin college, provides advanced programs and TAFE programs under the one umbrella and, by all accounts, is successful. Having visited that institution and having spent some time on a number of its campuses, I have been impressed with the quality of the programs that it puts forward.

The funding announced in this Bill also includes expenditure for commitments announced in and since the Budget by the Government. The post-Budget announcements attempt to address the enrolment and overcrowding pressures being felt in institutions. The present Bill makes no attempt to alter the legislative framework established by the Higher Education Funding Act 1988 as amended. One must, therefore, note that the Bill provides that a maximum allocation of funds is set for each program but that ministerial discretion will still determine the actual amount to be granted and the conditions under which those grants will be made. Phrases such as `in the opinion of the Minister' and `the Minister may approve' appear throughout the legislation. To many in higher education, those phrases will be redolent with meaning as they witness the system being administered under this eastern European-style framework, subject to constant exercises of discretion by the Department and the Minister.

It is a political system for the allocation of resources. Importantly, it was described as fundamentally flawed by the Industry Commission on that ground because, as the system is structured at present, it has very little capacity to respond to the demands of those seeking its services.

It is important to say in this debate that the current problems of unmet demand and overcrowding are, to a significant extent, a result of the rigidities imposed by the Government's regulatory framework for higher education. Institutions are limited in their admissions by quotas imposed by the Government and have restricted access to capital for development; student charges, other than for amenities, are determined entirely by the Government; course profiles require Government approval; and there are serious rigidities in the employment conditions for staff. These restrictions distort demand and prevent institutions from responding adequately to such patterns of demand as they perceive.
As I have said, the system of funding higher education has drawn strong criticism from the Industry Commission in its August 1991 report, Exports of Education Services. The Commission concluded:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . it is evident to the Commission that the current arrangements for funding higher education are flawed. The most obvious manifestation of this is the growing number of qualified Australian students who are unable to gain entry to Australian universities.
In its report, the Commission noted:

Without a mechanism which takes better account of the costs and value to society and to the student of education services, decisions by the Government and institutions as to how many places there are and how they are allocated will very likely be wrong.

Those are not the words of the Opposition; those are the words of the Government's most authoritative advisory Commission. That Commission has said that, under the system established by the Government, resource allocation decisions will very likely be wrong. Of course, that would have to be said of any system which depends ultimately for those decisions on political and bureaucratic discretion.

PARA.TAB: The Commission recommended that the Government accept the need to alter current arrangements so that qualified domestic students are not precluded from a place in public universities and that a reference be sent to the Industry Commission on appropriate means to meet the need and rectify the current system. The report further noted:

SPEECH.PARA: The Commission's concern is that there is a need for a public inquiry to determine what arrangements would be most appropriate for the provision of funds for higher education, including the mechanisms by which this might be achieved. It does not accept that previous inquiries are sufficient: there has been clear evidence during the course of this inquiry that there are a wide range of inconsistencies, inequities and inappropriate incentives present.

The Minister for Employment, Education and Training has of course already indicated that he does not support such a reference; he does not intend to loosen the Government's political and bureaucratic grip on the nation's universities, even if it means that some 30,000 qualified students are excluded, and even if it means that next year a greater number will be excluded because of the measures the Government has taken in relation to overcrowding.

PARA.TAB: Anticipating the refusal of the Government to provide a reference—and we hope there will not be such a refusal; I am still waiting on the decision of the Treasurer (Mr Kerin) on this matter—the Commission recommends immediate implementation of one of the discussed options, which overcomes the serious problem that qualified students who do not have a funded place are prohibited from public university study. I submit that makes a complete mockery of any claims of equity in the existing arrangements. And what does the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services (Mr Baldwin), a self-styled man of the Left, have to say about this? When asked on Face The Press what values from the Left he brought to his portfolio, he replied:

SPEECH.PARA: People who come from disadvantaged backgrounds should have the maximum access to higher education.
Yet the policy that he puts forward has been a policy which has denied an enormous number of students from disadvantaged backgrounds access to higher education.

TALK.START.PARA: —What would you do about it?

—We have said what we will do about it. We will allow the universities to do what they wanted to do to allow those students into the universities on the same terms as the Government insists the universities admit students from other countries. This Government has no problem whatever with getting the universities to charge fees for students from other countries—and there are some 15,000 of them in our universities—but it has an ideological opposition to allowing Australian students entry to Australian universities on the same terms. That is pure ideology of the left wing of the Labor Party. The Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services, in his higher education statement, has slammed the door on higher education for some 30,000 Australian students, and that will be the political epitaph of that particular junior Minister—that he was not prepared to show the courage to open the doors of higher education in this country to Australian students, most of whom, despite the fantasies of the Left, are not the students of the rich; they are the students with the lower TE scores, and sociologically those students will tend to come from the more disadvantaged areas of this country. They could get industry sponsorships. There are institutions in Australia which have told me they will admit those students and will get industry sponsorships for them and put additional funding into our higher education, but the Minister will not allow it. Why will he not allow it? For ideological reasons.

PARA.TAB: The October statement by the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services has done little to address these problems. In fact, I have described this statement as laughable, and I repeat that: these measures that he has put forward are not measures for the 1990s; the half-life of that statement is about six months. There is no perception on the part of that Minister or the Government of any strategy to build up the universities in Australia over this decade. We waited a year for that statement and when it came down it was a damp squib; it failed completely to put forward any intellectual justification that was worth a carrot against the arguments that were spelt out at great length by the Government's own advisory body—the Industry Commission. The main initiative in that statement for the decade was a $70m fund which would be distributed amongst institutions according to whether they were using their resources well or not—another centralist initiative which will set up someone to decide whether the institutions are administering their resources well or not.

The Minister has suggested that the universities will be consulted on this and that this somehow or other is a recognition of their needs as independent institutions. It is a proposal which reflects the very philosophy which is leading Australia towards a second- and third-rate higher education system, and it shows the total bankruptcy of the Government's approach to the management of higher education in this country at the present time. In view of this, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
`whilst not opposing the provisions of the Bill, this House condemns the Government for—

PARA.TAB: (1)its failure to adequately recognise the role of technical and further education in Australia's education and training systems;
(2)its continuing emphasis on centralist solutions to issues arising in relation to technical and further education; and
(3)its failure to recognise the need for more flexible TAFE institutions which can be more responsive to student and industry demands'.

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the amendment and reserve my right to speak.

—In stark contrast to the Opposition, the Hawke Government does have a philosophical stance when it comes to education and training. Again, this Government, in stark contrast to the Opposition—especially as indicated by the comments of the honourable member for Goldstein (Dr Kemp)—is about driving the debate with ideas and not glib one-liners about opportunistic, short term outcomes. East German centralist models! Be serious, please. Again, in stark contrast to the Opposition, this Government is not being paralogistic, arguing in circles or begging the real question and is not failing to see the wood for the trees. The Opposition strains at the gnat, and swallows a camel.

PARA.TAB: Whenever this House debates education, employment and training—even the Opposition backbenchers know this to be true—the Opposition front bench greets the debate with derision and the big yawn. Where does the Opposition stand on the matter of training? It is really there for all to see. Honourable members opposite resort to word fencing, chicanery and pettifogging. In other words, they are muddled, confused, woolly headed and very prone to unwarranted conclusions.

The purpose of the States Grants (TAFE Assistance) Amendment Bill (No.2) is to provide Commonwealth funds for TAFE colleges in 1992 and to provide cost supplementation for 1991 grants. The Bill provides an opportunity for members of this House to focus upon the significance of vocational training to meet the current and future needs of this nation. The Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins), in a speech on 1 October to a joint session of the Australian College of Education and the Australian Council of Deans of Education, made the very strong point that Australia needed to be a clever country certainly, but it also needed to become a capable country.

In fact, way back in 1968 the OECD recommendations to Australia were to dramatically increase year 12 retention rates up to 80 per cent or 90 per cent, to increase tertiary participation to around 30 per cent and to involve a significantly increased percentage in vocational training. In 15 years of neglect, Opposition members when in government virtually all but ignored those recommendations, placing this nation at a huge disadvantage in the international economy. They went for the resources boom. Does the House remember their reliance on a small elite and a huge, largely unskilled or semiskilled work force, and how they forgot about the most important resource and attribute—the one between people's ears?

An examination of the current education, training and employment scene is enlightening. There has been a dramatic increase in year 12 retention rates from 40.6 per cent in 1983 to over 70 per cent in 1991. There is an ever-increasing requirement for skills in the work force. There are declining full time employment opportunities for young people in the age range of 15 to 19 years. In 1966, 59 per cent of this group of 15- to 19-year-olds were in full time employment, compared with just 28 per cent last year. Not all of this change is accounted for by increased participation in education. Substantial numbers of young people are attempting to enter the work force without post-school education or training. Right at the moment, 30 per cent of young people do not complete year 12. Half of this group proceed with some sort of training, mainly apprenticeships. However, the other half—15 per cent of the total group—are at great risk in the labour market. Over 40 per cent of those in the 15- to 19-year-old age range enter the work force without formal post-school education or training.

These figures, which form the background to the Finn report commissioned by this Government, highlight dramatically the extremely limited opportunities for two-thirds of school leavers. That is particularly true, and disproportionately so, for school leavers in electorates such as mine of Port Adelaide; many young people do not enter higher education. Apprenticeships have not increased as a proportion of the youth population since 1980. Full time TAFE places account for less than 3 per cent of 15- to 19-year-olds. The apprenticeship system is also highly gender biased with fewer than 10 per cent of apprenticeships being for females. Most of them, of course, are hairdressers.

Almost all of the growth in educational participation has been in schools and higher education. From 1983 until 1990 participation trends in TAFE have hardly changed; growth rates have averaged 2.8 per cent per year. This Government has been responsible for a revolution in retention rates in higher education. However, there is still a long way to go, particularly in regard to vocational training and the State responsibility of primary education. The two areas of vocational training and primary schooling are still Cinderellas and the poor cousins. Under the current predominantly State funded regime, the TAFE and the training sector have suffered the major resource constraints since the middle 1980s, thus leading to serious barriers to access and a chequered pattern of growth.

In the six years to May 1990 the number of 15- to 24-year-olds in TAFE colleges rose by 38,000 nationally, at an average growth rate, as I said before, of only 2.8 per cent per year. I clearly acknowledge that in the interests of this nation that growth rate is not good enough and needs to be addressed. By comparison, over the same period, growth in universities—funded almost exclusively by the Commonwealth—meant that numbers rose by 112,400 nationally at an average growth rate of 7.3 per cent per year.

From 1983, while the number of 15- to 19-year-olds in higher education increased by 80 per cent, the numbers in TAFE rose by less than 12 per cent. As I said earlier, together schools and universities have accounted for virtually all the growth in education and training amongst 15- to 19-year-olds since 1983. In the vocational skills sector, as in primary schools, which is almost exclusively a State government responsibility, long term strategies are patently required. Finn pointed out very clearly and very powerfully that there needs to be a growth of between 35 per cent and 50 per cent in vocational training. In 1983 education and training pathways for young people recorded the following facts: 15 per cent were at university; 25 per cent were in vocational training; but 60 per cent had no post-school training. That was the track record and the legacy of the Opposition when it was in Government.

In 1991, 25 per cent of young people were at university—an increase of 10 per cent; 30 per cent of young people were in vocational training—representing some increase but not enough; but there were still 45 per cent of young people with no post-compulsory training. Finn sets out ambitious new vocational targets for young people to be achieved by the year 2000. He said that 95 per cent of 19-year-olds should complete the equivalent of year 12; 30 per cent of the post-year 12 group should attend university; and 50 per cent—this is the key—of that group should be involved in post-compulsory vocational skills, education and training.

Two major strategies are enunciated by Finn to support those targets. Firstly, there should be an education and training guarantee to give young people guaranteed access to TAFE similar to that which they already enjoy in relation to schools. Secondly, there should be a reformed and extended entry level training to expand opportunities for young people who do not go to university.

The community in general recognises the importance of education and training. I remind the honourable member for Goldstein that since 1984 ANOP has noted a large shift upwards in the importance which parents, young people and the wider community place on education and training. In fact, the Minister pointed out recently that in 1990 more than 91 per cent of parents endorsed the view that all young people should complete 12 years of education and training, compared with about 70 per cent in 1984. The ACTU, the Confederation of Australian Industry, the Business Council of Australia and the Metal Trades Industry Association have either endorsed or supported the broad thrust of the Finn targets and strategies and the Commonwealth's preferred response.

The Commonwealth's offer is a positive proposal to meet the needs of TAFE, which is facing a shortfall of 145,000 places nationally in 1992. In a recent edition of the Australian, in an article headed `TAFE expansion urgent', the President of the National Union of Students, Ms Brigid Freeman, is reported as saying that centralised funding would allow students to move more freely between State systems without being penalised and that students wanted better links between TAFE, universities, industry and the workplace. Knee-jerk reactions by some people in regard to greater Commonwealth involvement in TAFE is somewhat pre-emptive. Australians expect their State and Federal politicians to raise themselves above political point scoring at a local level and to come to grips with this country's problems.

There is a bit of an attitude in this nation of knocking everything just for the sake of it. When the announcement was made that the multifunction polis—most of it in my electorate—would get the green light to proceed, some individuals and sections of the community came out almost immediately against the project even before they could possibly have known what concepts were involved. That sort of behaviour has frustrated the innovative and creative people in this country for decades.

The education proposals by the Commonwealth do not represent a plot, as some have said, for a power grab. As with the MFP, the proposals encapsulate a vision and a commitment to planning for the future rather than just letting it happen willy-nilly. Why should we not plan for the future? Resource implications of the Finn proposals are substantial, but they are not impossible to meet. At the highest end of Finn's estimates, the increase in annual recurrent costs to governments between the years 1991 and 2001 would about $4.4 billion. Capital costs over the decade would be of the order of $3.2 billion. The greatest proportional increase would be in TAFE. Expenditure in TAFE would increase by between 37 per cent and 48 per cent. Expenditure on higher education would increase by 18 per cent to 28 per cent. Schools expenditure would increase by 12 per cent to 21 per cent. All these increases would depend on wage growth assumptions.

Finn has also noted that, under current funding arrangements, TAFE has become a poor cousin to the other sectors. I add that this also applies to primary schools. This is most clearly shown in the contrast between substantial growth in higher education funded by the Commonwealth and recent declines in TAFE funding by the States. Recent State budgets offer no immediate prospect of an expansion of TAFE. State budgets in Victoria, Tasmania, and my own state of South Australia have restricted TAFE to no growth in financial resources.

South Australia in fact increased TAFE fees by up to 40 per cent. Tasmania introduced such severe fee arrangements in 1991 that enrolments in some vocational courses fell by over 30 per cent. Queensland is the only State which is increasing its funding to TAFE; but that is not a good story either, as the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Gibson) would well know. Queensland's participation in TAFE is 23 per cent behind the national average.

TALK.START.PARA: —We're getting there.

—That is good to hear. The Special Premiers Conference this month provides a historic opportunity to ensure that Australia's future needs for skills and training is nationally led, ideas driven and does not fall between the cracks of inter-governmental relations. The Government's preferred position is for the Commonwealth to assume full funding responsibility for all publicly funded education and training beyond year 12 or its equivalent. That would mean effectively increasing the Commonwealth's contribution from about 10 per cent of the total now to about 70 per cent. Obviously, this would require a constructive partnership of the States to provide the financial boost needed to take vocational education and training into the next century.

PARA.TAB: However, it is important to note that this approach relates to funding responsibility—not administration, not planning and not a policy setting role. For example, a large Commonwealth funding role in TAFE would not mean a diminished State administrative and planning role. I commend the TAFE Assistance Bill to the House.

The Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No. 2) provides, firstly, for the implementation of Budget decisions to provide additional funding in 1992 over and above normal triennial commitments for enrolment growth; capital funding, including a renovations program; a pilot scheme for joint funding of places with industry; advanced engineering centres; additional research grants; normal cost supplementation, including salary increases; and a small offset for a HECS increase. Secondly, it provides a wider definition of capital projects to encompass major investments in course material and equipment which substitute for capital. The recent Government statement Higher Education: Quality and Diversity in the 1990s sets a new direction for the development of higher education policy, centring on the development of a comprehensive set of measures to further enhance the quality of higher education teaching and provision.

The statement's measures, which were mentioned by the honourable member for Goldstein, include the provision of $70m annually from 1994 for a quality enhancement program, whereby participating institutions will receive additional funding on the basis of good performances in the use of all their available resources to attain the best quality in their programs; that is, participation by institutions will be voluntary and there will be no intention to use the new performance initiatives to redistribute the normal operating grants. There will be the formation of an independent national quality assurance structure, encompassing all stakeholders in the system, to report and comment on the application and effectiveness of quality enhancement measures developed by institutions. Also taken into account will be the establishment of a national centre for teaching excellence in higher education to examine and disseminate information about good teaching practices.

I am sure the honourable member for Goldstein would remember the book by Professor Gundy, The Buck Stops Here, in which I think he described the quality of teaching in our higher education centres as abysmal and in our equivalent CAEs as just slightly above abysmal. As well, there is a reference to the Higher Education Council to explore the characteristics of quality in higher education.

The Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee described this proposition as `a positive, major initiative'. The Opposition has attacked the initiative as a slush fund. I suppose this implies that the Opposition has no real concern for quality and would withdraw these funds from the system to meet its budgetary objectives.

The Commonwealth-funded student load has increased by 40 per cent between 1983 and 1991. Recent decisions will increase the Commonwealth-funded load by a further 9.3 per cent between 1991 and 1994. As a share of the 17- to 64-year-old population, Commonwealth-funded participation in higher education has increased from under 3.5 per cent in 1983 to 4 per cent in 1990. With recent decisions, it is projected to exceed 4.2 per cent in 1994 and beyond.

Growth in 1993 and 1994 is explicitly designed to maintain opportunities for undergraduates, and to increase postgraduate places in response to increased demand for postgraduate qualifications and a projected shortfall in the academic labor market during the 1990s. In 1991, there has been an unexpected level of overenrolment by institutions, leading to a problem of overcrowding in a number of cases. This problem reflected a number of factors, but in a number of cases it appeared that the admissions process had not been monitored closely enough.

To assist institutions to deal with this problem, the Government is prepared to be flexible on the achievement of the commencing and total load targets set for each institution. From 1992 additional flexibility will be provided, allowing institutions facing the likelihood of exceeding total load targets for reasons beyond their control to adjust their commencing load by up to 5 per cent. Unfortunately, press coverage implied that this may result in 5 per cent fewer commencements in aggregate than provided by the Government. This is not expected to be the case; it is expected that the higher education sector will, in aggregate, enrol close to its commencing target.

The State distribution of Commonwealth funded places has become more equitable as the growth in places has been allocated to States according to relative needs. For example, in 1983 participation in higher education as a share of the 17- to 64-year-old age group ranged from 3.1 per cent in New South Wales and 3.2 per cent in Queensland to 3.8 per cent in Western Australia and 3.9 per cent in Victoria. By 1993, the range will be from 4 per cent in New South Wales and South Australia to 4.2 per cent in Queensland and 4.4 per cent in Victoria.

Queensland, for example, is receiving 23.6 per cent of the increase in places above the 1991-93 triennium—well above its population share of 16.9 per cent in 1990. In contrast, Victoria has a very high participation rate—an expected 4.4 per cent of the 17- to 64-year-old population in 1992 compared with the national average of 4.15 per cent. To assist in improving the national balance, Victoria will receive about 22 per cent of the places over the 1991-93 triennium—below its population share of 25.8 per cent in 1990.

In summing up, I think it is quite clear that this Government has had a real and much admired commitment to education and training in this country. This is evidenced by particular gains in higher education and secondary school enrolments. That the focus now should be on vocational training is proper and correct. I hope that the States will take some lead in the future, too, and redress the problems that they have with the very foundation years of education—those spent in primary school.

TALK.START.PARA: —I note that the speech of the honourable member for Port Adelaide (Mr Sawford) was essentially directed at trying to defend the Government's position. I want to make it abundantly clear to the people listening to this debate that this Parliament is tonight debating an issue which is of crucial importance—that is, young people's lives, and equipping people who are interested in training and getting better skills with the ability go on and take up a particular vocation.

PARA.TAB: But how much time are we allowed by the Government? Are we allowed free time to debate this issue? No, we are not. The Government had to guillotine a debate about education. Yet we have speakers from the Government telling us that this is an important debate. But it is not an important debate if the Government is willing to guillotine it. That is the first symbol that we ought to recognise. The Government is not genuinely interested in this debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —It shows what they really think.

—As the shadow Minister says, it shows the priority that the Government really accords to this issue. Secondly, the Government's real priority for and interest in this issue can be shown by the speakers list. Let us look at that list very briefly.
—A very clear message.

—It gives a very clear message. It shows that 10 or 11 people from the Opposition will speak on education, even though the debate has been guillotined. Even though it has been guillotined, this number of people want to debate this issue. For the Government there are three speakers. Time and time again in this Parliament—
—Three quality speakers, though.

—I am not denying that they may be quality speakers, but I am saying that the clear indication to the Australian people is that there are only a few people in the Government genuinely interested in the education and training future of Australians.

PARA.TAB: This debate centres on one key theme, as far as I am concerned. I see it as a debate concerning whether the Government can provide the funds for the necessary training and education of our younger population. When we look at that question, what we notice about the present Government is that, in those areas where we have to generate wealth so that industry, businesses and people can be taxed so that we can provide for services such as education, there is a great stifling effect on development and progress in generating extra money.

The cake has been put into a clamp. The amount of revenue which can be generated in this country has been throttled so that now we are faced with a crisis in a crucial area. As a nation, we want our young people to be better trained, but over the last five or six years the Government has given no incentive to those businesses that really want to get on. I think of Coronation Hill—and, back in my area, a proposed world class pulp mill for Wesley Vale. That went down the tube. It had the capacity to generate extra taxation revenue for this country.

In this country now we see a squeeze coming on with the demand of so many young people. I give the Government credit for encouraging people to stay on at school, but the Government did not provide properly for those young people as they stayed on. The Government did not provide extra money so that extra classrooms could be built for year 11 and year 12 students, particularly in my area. The Government did not provide extra money for TAFE education so that the tooling necessary for developing the skills for the 1990s and into the 2000s would be there for the young people.

I know why the Government cannot provide these resources. It is because it is not generating the revenue. I say to the Government that it cannot expect Australia to be a clever country while at the same time it creates an atmosphere of disincentive for investment. We have to get these two things together. If we want to provide good government services in this country, first of all we have to generate the taxes and the revenue to do it. If this Government had been wise in 1985 and 1986 when it told us that there needed to be reform of the industrial relations system, the waterfront and shipping, and had gone on and done it, the revenue would now be available for our universities and 30,000 young people would not be locked out.

That is the other debate. We are at the end of 1991 and the Government is telling us—it is not the Opposition's figure—that there are 145,000 people wanting to go into training for whom there are no places. There are 30,000 young people sitting outside the doors of our universities who cannot get in. That is the nub of the debate. We can have lots of figures about what has been achieved, but the fundamental line is that—145,000 people wanting to be trained who cannot be trained.

There are 30,000 young people who want to get into tertiary institutions. They have done year 12 studies—12 years of studying in our schools. They are qualified, but the Government cannot provide the assistance for them to go in. Yet it provides, as the shadow Minister said, opportunity for overseas people to come in. They can pay their way into our universities. Why cannot Australians, if they want to, pay their way? What is wrong with paying one's way to get a better education?

The Government members sit opposite with glum faces—because there is nothing wrong. There is nothing wrong with paying one's own way. If people want to do it, why can they not have that freedom of choice? Why should governments in Australia have rules and regulations that prevent people from being better educated? What right has a government to do it? No government has such a right. But, of course, the Labor Party in Australia has these ideological views that must not be transgressed, whether young people's lives are being affected or not. That is the Government's attitude to this matter.

I was interested in the comment of the previous speaker that this was not a plot to centralise control of TAFE education. Maybe it is not a plot, but, on the basis of experience of Labor governments, the reality is that if they get their hands on the money they want to control the whole show.

Let us look at our experience in regard to higher education and the universities just recently—the latest experience that Australians can look to. Surely that must be the most credible example because it is recent. In the legislative framework we find two little phrases used in regard to grants: `in the opinion of the Minister' and `the Minister may approve'. Those phrases occur repeatedly in the Act. The universities are told that they can be independent. We can remember the debate here. The universities and the CAEs were to be totally free to choose whether they joined. Were they? They certainly were not. They were forced, cajoled and herded together, to put it simply.

We have people saying to us tonight that this is not a plot in regard to training and TAFE. It certainly is not a plot, because a plot is usually something which is secret. But in this sense the Australian people can see right through it. Minister Dawkins—and therefore this Government—has failed to address the training needs of Australians, and we now have a requirement for 145,000 places not met.

TALK.START.PARA: —And what would you do?

—Honourable members opposite are the Government. They have been the Government for eight or nine years. It is their responsibility to have provided for these 145,000 people. I will tell honourable members opposite what is really in the mind of the Minister, and the Government. The Government has been able to move up the retention rates in schools very nicely. As I said, I support the Government in that. It is a good goal and we should continue to do it.
—And in higher education.

—And in higher education there have been certain things; nevertheless, let us remember that 30,000 students have been prevented from continuing their education. The figures show that higher education has done well, education in the schools has done well, and retention rates have gone up but, by golly, there is a gap in the unskilled and the working class of our community. Traditionally, they have been good Labor voters, but the crunch is that there is a terrible gap. In the area in which the Government should have provided for many of the people, it is patently obvious that it did not care.

PARA.TAB: The Government says, `We have to move the figures before the next election so that we can say we have been doing a great job. We have kept retention rates for years 11 and 12 and we have moved them up and we will continue to do the same'. When we think of the strategy which this Government has undertaken in education, particularly under Minister Dawkins, it is a bit like a nice coloured balloon—a big air balloon, colourful and exciting. When that balloon begins to have difficulty, another balloon should be ready so that when it crashes to the ground and looks a pretty awful sight another colourful balloon is going up. So people's eyes are drawn away from the mess of the balloon which is falling to the ground to the new balloon which is going up and, hopefully, they will be so distracted that they will not see the difficulties that exist.

I will give the House a few examples in my own electorate in regard to TAFE education. This Government has been good in regard to education. It has continued to put money into education. Why is it then that in my area, while the Federal Labor Government has been espousing that rhetoric, in my home State, under another Labor Government, classroom after classroom, floor after floor, campus after campus is being abolished and closed down? It is ridiculous. We can walk into beautiful buildings whose rooms are full of material which is not being used because of the inadequacies of the Labor Administration. Maybe the reason is centralised power. The industrial relations system in education and the TAFE area is also greatly debilitating to this country. The sooner this country breaks down that industrial relations system in education, the better our young people and this country will be.

Many things that this Government has done in regard to education have been fundamentally flawed. The reason is that it is centralist in its approach. The Government wants to back the teachers' unions in this country above young people's futures. An honourable member said in this House that there will be some sort of assessment or measurement of standards. I remember that we tried to do that in schools in 1978 or 1980. A survey was conducted on how to maintain standards. Who shot it down? The Australian Teachers Federation. Who is it backed by? The Labor Government. That is the situation. The people who have worked in those circumstances know it well, but it is unfortunate that the Australian Teachers Federation will not accept measurement standards in this country.

I agree with the shadow Minister for education, the honourable member for Goldstein (Dr Kemp) that the industrial relations system in education has to be broken down and freed up so that our young people, and their parents, feel that they are getting a better education. There is a great need to do that. A total of 30,000 people are not getting a position in our universities and 145,000 are not getting appropriate training. This Government has been in power for the last eight years and it is a great tragedy that its policies have failed to such a mammoth degree.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to speak on the two Bills before the House, namely, the States Grants (TAFE Assistance) Amendment Bill (No. 2) and the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No. 2). It is mainly the latter Bill that I will concentrate on this evening.

PARA.TAB: Australia's higher education system has undergone a period of unparalleled growth and structural change since the release of the Government's White Paper on higher education in July 1988. Unlike the Opposition and, particularly, the shadow education spokesperson, the honourable member for Goldstein (Dr Kemp), this Government is of the belief that all Australians have the right of access to all services that our society offers, including, of course, quality higher education. Both of these Bills build on this social justice philosophy by funding a greater number of places in post-school education.

In response to the contribution made by the honourable member for Goldstein in this debate, I can assure him and the House that I am happy to be a captive of an ideological position which encompasses a vision and a philosophy for the future development of our nation's education rather than a captive, as he is, of a failed and discredited past which had no direction, no vision and no future. That clearly describes the Opposition's position on education.

The honourable member for Goldstein had the hide to suggest that the pre-1972 system of full fees for all university places, with a system of scholarships to allegedly assist disadvantaged groups, would somehow improve equity and access to tertiary places. I was a university student during those dark days when that was the system and it was clearly evident, as backed up by statistical information, that numbers of students from low income families and disadvantaged groups were much lower than they are under the current system. It was an elitist system then and if it were reintroduced it would be a regressive and elitist system again.

The Hawke Government has achieved a great deal in the higher education sector and these Bills will continue to build on these achievements. The Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No. 2) provides for enrolment growth; capital funding, including a renovations program; a pilot scheme for joint funding of places with industry; advanced engineering centres; additional research grants; and normal costs supplementation, including salary increases. Funding for the third year of the new triennium will include funding for an additional 2,845 intakes, a further increase in capital expenditure to $277m and approximately $75m for a new quality enhancement scheme.

The Government is continuing its commitment to quality in accordance with the statement, Higher Education: Quality and Diversity in the 1990s, which was released last month. The amendments to the Higher Education Funding Act 1988 will allow for the implementation of the Budget decisions to provide additional funding in 1992 over and above normal triennial commitments. One measure is the inclusion of some $70m annually from 1994 for a quality enhancement program whereby participating institutions will receive additional funding on the basis of good performance in the use of all resources to attain the best quality in their programs.

The Bill focuses on a comprehensive set of measures to maintain and enhance the quality of higher education teaching and provision. The extra funds will be used to reward institutions for making the best use of all their available resources. As outlined by my colleague the honourable member for Port Adelaide (Mr Sawford), institutional participation in the new quality assurance arrangements will be voluntary and the allocation of normal operating grants will be unaffected.

The Government's approach to quality assurance balances institutional autonomy with public accountability. It is based on self-assessment by institutions rather than relying on external assessments of quality. It relates the monitoring of quality to the goals of individual institutions. It involves assessments which include both qualitative and quantitative indicators.

The Bill allows for comparisons to be made against the different circumstances of institutions, including the composition of their student population and their performance over time. It will, therefore, encourage diversity and innovation while confirming public confidence in the higher education system and reinforcing its international reputation.

In addition, there will be a comprehensive review of modes of delivery in higher education to look at how technology can best be harnessed to improve access to, and the quality and efficiency of, higher education. In this respect, the Government is taking the lead internationally in providing a funding incentive to institutions over and above funding for student load to promote the highest possible level of quality in higher education.

With the release earlier in the year of the report of the Australian Education Council Review Committee, Young People's Participation in Post-Compulsory Education and Training, more simply known as the Finn report, there has been a greater focus on credit transfer between TAFE and the higher education sector. This report confirmed that employment opportunities for people, especially young people, are severely diminished when their access to education or training is limited. The report argues that economic imperatives and the resulting work force changes mean that almost all young people will require some post-compulsory education or training. The Finn Committee advocated greater transfer arrangements within TAFE and higher education institutions and recommended that money be allocated to further the credit transfer process.

The fundamental conclusion of the Finn report is the need for a major expansion in the provision of vocational education opportunities over the coming decade. The TAFE system is the major provider of vocational education services in this country and is funded principally by the States. By contrast with the higher education system, the TAFE sector has suffered major resource constraints for a number of years, including funding cuts, leading to serious barriers to access and unprecedented and unacceptable levels of unmet demand.

In my State of Queensland, the TAFE sector was underresourced, poorly managed and unable to reflect the needs and aspirations of Queensland's young people during the dark years of Liberal-National rule. It has been only in the past 18 months that real increases in TAFE funding have been provided by the Goss Labor Government to redress this previous neglect. But there is still a long way to go to catch up and reach the national average, let alone the funding levels required to achieve participation targets recommended in the Finn report.

Nationally, the rate of growth in State funding for, and therefore participation in, TAFE has not matched demand and certainly has not matched the growth that has occurred in higher education. In the six years to May 1990, the number of 15- to 24-year-olds enrolled in TAFE colleges rose by 38,000 nationally at an average rate of only 2.8 per cent per year. Over the same period, the number of 15- to 24-year-olds in universities rose by 112,400 nationally at an average rate of 7.3 per cent per year. Since 1983, while the numbers of 15- to 19-year-olds in higher education increased by over 80 per cent, numbers in TAFE rose by less than 12 per cent.

Recent State Budgets in Victoria, South Australia and Tasmania have restricted TAFE to no growth in financial resources. Queensland is the only State which is increasing its funding to TAFE, but its participation rate in TAFE still is 23 per cent behind the national average, because of the starvation of funds that TAFE suffered under the previous government.

As a nation, we are confronting a basic choice: do we continue on our present course of the Federal Government upgrading the capacity and resources of our universities while the vocational education and training system, under the administration of the States, continues to decline in its capacity to address the needs of our young people and our work force or do we strike a new balance between the two sectors and accord equal esteem to the two main education pathways to employment for school leavers?

The Finn report has put forward the view that, if we are to live up to our aspirations as an advanced nation providing real opportunities for all, we have no choice but to significantly upgrade our vocational, education and training system as a matter of urgency. This will require a commitment of resources by both the States and the Commonwealth and a national approach to skills recognition, accreditation and articulation. Existing structures and institutional arrangements in TAFE and training will need to be reviewed and in some cases radically altered. A new partnership will need to be forged with industry, especially in the key area of structured entry level training. New links will have to be developed between schools, TAFE and universities to promote mobility and portability of skills across different sectors and between employment pathways. Most importantly, a change in community attitudes will be essential if vocational skills education is to receive the priority which our national interests demand.

In the university sector, the Commonwealth Government has pledged further commitments for growth which will take us 94 per cent of the way to the ambitious targets for higher education set by the Finn committee for the year 2001. In the vocational skills area, there would need to be growth of between 35 and 50 per cent over the next decade to reach these targets. The Finn committee has estimated that to meet its targets an additional $814m per year in current prices will be required by the year 2001 to fund the running costs of an improved vocational education training system. Capital expenditure needs will increase this figure to about $1 billion per annum. A new report released just last Friday indicates that this figure may well be a considerable underestimate of the costs of implementing Finn's targets. The State governments will have to face the reality that new funding arrangements for the vocational education sector will have to be negotiated in a realistic and meaningful way if real equality of employment pathways after school is to be achieved. We can no longer rely on parochial arguments about control if we are serious about providing expanded training opportunities.

Increased participation in higher education has always been a major goal of this Government. Commonwealth funded student load has increased by 40 per cent between 1983 and 1991. The recent decisions by the Government will see an increase in the Commonwealth funded load of a further 9.3 per cent. However, growth in places in tertiary education needs to be accompanied by growth in capital funding if overcrowding is to be avoided. The higher education system has experienced some particular stresses in recent times as a result of high levels of overenrolment and overcrowding. The Government has announced in the Budget a range of measures to deal with these problems. They are an acceleration of the capital program, the introduction of renovation grants on a matching funds basis, and additional recurrent funding to help cope with enrolment pressures.

The State distribution of Commonwealth funded places has become more equitable as the growth in places has been allocated to States according to relative needs. This has been good news for my own State of Queensland. Queensland has for a long time faced a funding imbalance in terms of provision of tertiary places. Queensland is receiving 23.6 per cent of the increase in places over the 1991-93 triennium. This is well above its population share of 16.9 per cent. This continues the pattern of the past seven years where the Federal Government has moved Queensland's share from 14 per cent of places in 1983 to 16.3 per cent of places in 1993. We will have to move further to catch up, but there is a clear commitment from the Federal Government to address this past neglect.

The impact of this increased funding can clearly be seen in the statistics for the Nathan campus of Griffith University, which services my electorate. In 1983, Griffith University's enrolment in terms of effective full time student units was 2,045. By 1991, this had risen to 5,268—an increase of 158 per cent. The additional capital funds will allow the Government to make early decisions on new capital projects to commence in 1993 in order to facilitate the proper planning of these developments by institutions. The Government has increased capital funding every year it has been in office. This has meant that between 1983 and 1992 there has been a fivefold increase in the level of funding—up from $48.9m in 1983 to $265.8m in 1992.

The Bill before us includes provisions to extend the definition of higher education capital projects to encompass projects other than merely building projects. These provisions will mean that the Government will be able to provide greater funding towards equipment and course material. The wider definition recognises the potential for new technologies and alternative delivery modes to improve delivery of and access to higher education.

The Bill also provides funds for a Commonwealth program to establish three advanced engineering centres in partnership with host institutions and industry. The focus of the centres will be advanced undergraduate and postgraduate education and training. This is a tremendous initiative, as many honourable members will agree that we are suffering as a result of a dearth of engineers. This measure will not only increase the number of engineering graduates but also make them even more compatible with industry, and it should be welcomed by all sides. These advanced engineering centres will provide courses for industry and technical and further education teachers. They will also provide professional retraining for experienced engineers and applied research and design services for industry. This initiative will mean that engineers and graduates from a related field will be more compatible with industry. The Commonwealth is providing just under $10m over the triennium for the establishment and ongoing costs associated with this initiative.

The Government has committed itself to spending some $12.9 billion on higher education over the 1992-94 triennium. Continued growth in the system will provide expanding opportunities for Australians to participate in higher education and, with the Government's new measures to further enhance the quality of higher education, teaching and provision, Australian students can expect to receive a higher education which is the equal of any in the world. I commend the Bills to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted tonight to speak to this pair of Bills, but will confine my remarks this evening to the States Grants (TAFE Assistance) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1991. There has been a great deal of discussion in recent weeks about the Finn report—a report entitled Young people's participation in post-compulsory education and training. From time to time we also mention its predecessor, the Deveson report, which looked into the costs of training. But I would like to quote from a book written by Michael Porter, of Harvard University, entitled The Competitive Advantage of Nations. Professor Porter said:

SPEECH.PARA: There are respected and high quality forms of higher education besides the university. A high percentage of students who attend university is not necessarily a sign of the most effective human resource development. A system for vocational, technical and specialised industry training is a central priority in any advanced economy.

Professor Porter was right and most of us entering the debate in this country today would not question that finding. Brian Finn's committee said, amongst many other things, that it supports absolutely the convergence of general and vocational education and an increasing emphasis on vocational training in senior years of secondary school and in TAFE, and that because of our history and our method of development we have encouraged a small portion of the population from both advantaged and disadvantaged backgrounds to enter university—generally less than 30 per cent.

PARA.TAB: We have controlled that largely by the number of places, not by any mechanism of funding. We have said, `There are only so many of you who can go, regardless of how many of you wish to go or regardless of how many of you are competent'. We then set up, alongside that, a separate system of vocational training, but somehow we got it wrong. We got it wrong in that we tended to value apprenticeships, which represent only a very small portion of vocations in our country, but we did not value other forms of vocational training, to the point that vocational high schools in my own State, and in the State of New South Wales in particular, eventually folded because of community pressure. The community said that the vocational high schools provided a second-class education and people did not want that for their children. The children said, `Look, nobody pays much attention to us; the school is scungy, it is second rate, the teachers are second rate'. So eventually we gave up.

That sort of dual system has worked well in Germany. It has worked terrifically there. Germany has produced some of the most skilled artisans and trades people in the world. But it did not work for us in Australia. Finn said, and most of us who talk about this topic today reckon, that we have to move vocational training back into the senior years of high school. Increasingly, as our youth value education, we must encourage them to stay on—not because they are receiving Austudy, not because there are no jobs or not because there is nothing else to do, but because there will be useful outcomes for them when they leave school. Finn recommends that by the year 2000 some 50 per cent of the young student population at age 19 should still be in some form of training or education or in a job. I would support that target.

The Finn report recommends that TAFE must increase its concentration on broad based pre-vocational or entry level courses—that is to say, many of us have been critical of some parts of TAFE for trying to be everything to everyone. Basket weaving 3 and pottery making 27 may be terrific courses, but they are not what we are on about when we talk about being a clever country. I think we all agree on that.

The Finn report says that industry must take a more active role in the development and support of training activities in schools, in TAFE, in university and in industry itself. There are lots of reasons why industry in Australia has not participated in training programs, in vocational training, to the extent that industry should have been a participant. One reason is the fact that we have not really allowed industry courses to be certified by the public bureaucracy, which largely has been responsible for training. It was three months ago that the first of the private training institutes run by industry was certified to provide a certificate to students which said that their courses were as good as they would have received in a TAFE, even though they may have been several times better. So we have not encouraged industry to develop its own training programs. We have encouraged the public sector but not the private.

We also have the added disadvantage that many of our major companies are overseas owned. For whatever reason they have expected us, because of the nature of our public funded system, to supply the training for them. Obviously that has not worked. So we would support industry's taking a more active role, and we would hope that it does. I have to say that the training guarantee levy has not been successful in the slightest in encouraging industry in that direction.

I would support the broad thrust of Finn on participation targets, of which there are several. I would think that those targets themselves should not be the end but only the means, because at the end of the day we are looking for quality. To the largest extent possible we want the entirety of our youth to be well educated or trained directly for a job in industry. Of course, increasingly training is becoming a lifelong experience worldwide, whether it is education generally or specific skills acquisition for specific tasks in the world of business, industry or commerce.

I would support Finn's recommendation that the concept of 12 full years of guaranteed full time education or training be provided in either schools or TAFE so that we can say to all our young people, `Firstly, we require you to stay on at least for 10 years in all States, and we would like you to stay on for 12 years'. Whether we provide vocational training in senior secondary colleges for the final two years of high school or we provide it in TAFE along with general academic courses really matters not. It is a matter for the individual States, and I would encourage diversity and competition because the more competitive we are and the more models we have which work well, the better chance we will have of arriving at the best quality.

A number of us—in fact three of us sitting here in this chamber tonight—have seen some of the best examples in Australia today of merged general academic education with vocational courses in senior secondary colleges, that is, those with just years 11 and 12 which basically merge TAFE and academic courses together. Those models have worked very well particularly in the State of Queensland, as the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Gibson) would know.

I would support the principles of a new entry-level training system. Finn talks about new entry-level training. I am not sure that everyone knows exactly what that means. It is important that we visualise it accurately because today entry level into the world of work is basically through an apprenticeship, which means a craft, or through the Australian traineeship system, which largely is dedicated towards the retail industry, or through the old system of youth wages, where people left school at the Leaving Certificate or before and, from the age of 14 onwards, progressed through industry at increasing wage rates on birthdays. Put together, all of those really have not provided a satisfactory answer for us. So when we talk about entry-level training, we talk about the training mechanism that allows everyone to have a job or, at least hopefully, have entry to a job and training on the job in industry or in business.

It seems to me that one of the problems today with the apprenticeship system is that it is still based on a concept of master-slave relationship, which is no longer appropriate in these dying years of the twentieth century. Increasingly we talk about competency based training. The apprenticeship system is based, very parochially, on a time based system—generally four years of off-the-job and on-the-job training. So when we talk about a new entry-level training system, not everyone is talking about the same thing. I think we need to develop our thinking to a much greater extent. Australians have valued the apprenticeship system and may not value a new system, so we must ensure that what we propose will be acceptable to the community before we try to force it down its throat.

One other thing the Finn report discusses is the national project on the quality of teaching and learning of the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) as being an appropriate forum for development of strategies for raising the standards of teaching. I would reject that proposition. That national project has personnel on the committee who are either bureaucrats or members of the Teachers Union. I would have thought that was the least appropriate mechanism to decide how we should go about improving the quality of teaching in our country. It seems to me that the users desperately need a place in that equation.

One major difference that this side of the House has with the other side of the House when we talk about higher education and, increasingly, about Finn and funding for TAFE, is that of bureaucratic control. The current Minister for Employment, Education and Training has a model which literally has DEET as the big father over all the education system. The bureaucrats control the outcomes and try to control quality and the inputs, all by controlling funding. I reckon that is an inappropriate mechanism because I believe that we will get better quality through better diversity if we fund the student. By funding the student we give him the choice and introduce choice into the equation. Choice was always decided pretty well in the marketplace. If one puts Cadbury Schweppes up against Hersheys in the Australian marketplace, Cadbury Schweppes will win every time. The reason is that the Australian public wants its products.

The university that provides the highest quality education will attract the most students and deserves the funding to continue its programs. I support the honourable member for Moreton in calling for increasing credit transfer links between schools, TAFEs and universities. We talk about pathways. The honourable member for Port Adelaide (Mr Sawford) is not very happy about this description about pathways. That bothers him a bit—I can cope with that—and it bothers me too. I think we talk in cliches far too often. What we are talking about is credit transfer. If students take carpentry courses in their two senior years in high school, surely there should be a mechanism in place which gives them credit for the course work in TAFE? This will reduce their apprenticeship term by a year. Students should at least get credit for the work that they have done.

For many courses in TAFE the university should be able to allow TAFE to give the student credit which the university will accept, as long as the university has some control over the quality of the outcomes and, therefore, the quality of the input of the students it is receiving. If the university finds that someone who has a certificate in business studies from a TAFE college is not able to cope with its advanced level programs—in the tertiary or fourth year—then surely it should have the right to tell TAFE, `We are not going to accept that credit any longer?'. But to the extent that it is advisable that we extend this credit transfer mechanism, then I support what the honourable member for Moreton had to say in that context.

The Finn report was big on national assessment standards. I support the Finn committee 100 per cent when it talks about assessment because that is another major difference between the Government and those on this side of the House. The teacher unions, together with parts of the bureaucracy, have been to the forefront in rejecting the concept of testing to prove the quality of outcomes for a whole host of reasons which, unfortunately, I no longer have time to go into tonight. Finn very strongly recommends national assessment and national testing to national standards, and I support it absolutely.

I encourage further the evaluation of mechanisms to increase participation in education and training by the disadvantaged because there are still pockets of our society which are disadvantaged and still do not have the educational opportunities that others have. I know that we can argue about this, but I have said over and over again that some of the most disadvantaged in Australia today are those who just miss the entry requirement at university. This year's cut-off score may be great, but next year's cut-off score must be higher because we do not have the physical places any more, which is what is happening. So we throw tens of thousands of Australian students on the educational scrap heap because the Government cannot afford or does not have room for them at university. They could go if they could pay for themselves, but we refuse them a place while at the same time allowing overseas students to come and pay for a place. Talk about educational disadvantage. Tens of thousands of Australian students are truly disadvantaged in that respect.

I encourage an expansion of the careers education program. It is important that we give our youth every opportunity to understand what we call the real world of work in so far as it is humanly possible. Over the past decade, for one reason or another, we have tended to devalue the dirty jobs: the jobs in process industries, in the steel mills, in the chemical plants or in the mines. We have not valued them. Our schools have valued the jobs in law, in bureaucracy, in the State and Federal governments and in medicine. But we have not valued engineering or science. Unfortunately we have not valued teaching either because we have not kept pace with the pay scales in the teaching profession. We have allowed the unions to control the agenda to the point that that profession is no longer as respected as it once was.

The Finn report makes two recommendations basically in respect of funding. Those recommendations are important. One essentially says that the Commonwealth should take full funding responsibility; the other says that States will take full funding responsibility. In the former, Finn calls for the Commonwealth to guarantee all the funding and, in the second, he calls for the States to pay for everything after the first 12 years. It is my belief that, if we are going to be able to get the number of places in TAFE that are desperately needed, we need to find urgently the funds available to expand TAFE and we need to devolve the responsibility for TAFE to the colleges themselves, as I would propose that we devolve responsibility for universities back to themselves. Another area in which we disagree with those on the Government side is on the profiling process, the mechanism of funding places. I think that is a critical difference in the way in which we view, increasingly in the future, arriving at a quality outcome in both education and training for all our youth and all Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crawford Ms M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak in support of the States Grants (TAFE Assistance) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1991 and the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1991, but I shall devote most of my time to the former. Many honourable members who have spoken on this legislation have been actively involved in the skills training inquiry as part of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training inquiry process. They are also currently in discussions with members of the New Zealand select committee on education and science who are currently visiting Australia. This is a first for both parliaments. Indeed, the whole notion of training, education, and the role of the technical and further education system within the community is very important.

PARA.TAB: As many other honourable members have pointed out, we have passed a number of milestones in this area in recent times, not least of which has been the report on young people's participation in post-compulsory education and training, commonly known as the Finn review. A number of other processes are currently in place which assess the needs and demands of Australia as it moves into the twenty-first century. As well as that, we had the change of Australia's role in the international scene, the demands that are being made on Australia as it pursues markets in the Asian area and loses its traditional markets in Europe, and the once dominating role that Britain played. As it moved into the European Common Market, Australia had to find a different role for itself in the world.

Enormous technological changes have occurred in the last decade and have impacted upon the community in which we live and work and on the demands which are now placed on our students, our children and industry itself as we attempt to unravel and work towards the kind of education system which we feel is required for our children as they move into the twenty-first century. The equity officer of the Queensland Education Department, Dr Elanor Ramsey, whom I heard speak some nights back, told us that by the year 2015 the kind of jobs which many of our young people would have are currently unknown and are yet to be developed. She predicted that as much as 70 per cent of the kind of employment which people who are young now will have in the year 2015 is yet to be developed.

We are preparing people for a changing world. The only thing which we will know and understand in that world is change.
