For all of us, particularly those in the political spectrum, we know and understand that change is the most difficult aspect of life for the community. Most people respond to change very badly. They have a view of the past which is coloured and rosy; they view the past as being somehow superior to the present. Perhaps they yearn for a knowledge of what is happening; often they yearn for their youth.

However, I think there are very few people who would yearn for the kind of state which our TAFE system is currently in. Most of us are well aware of the figures in which we have seen un-met demand increasing. It is estimated that in 1992 the shortfall will be in the region of 150,000 places. That surely comes at a time when the Government is pursuing its clever country ideal and, hence, we are no longer prepared to accept such a shortfall. It is in this context that the proposal to the States was placed. As well as that, the resourcing and the re-vitalisation of TAFE comes at a time when the community moves into that whole fabric of society where we have changed.

We are currently discussing the nature of education and the role of education for society in general. Very many argue that as we pursue entry level training, as we pursue a more technical approach to training, and as we pursue school retention rates to year 12 and encourage students to take the kind of accreditation courses which we believe our young people need and should have, we are doing so at the expense of what has become known as general education. There are very many people in the community and in the education sector who believe that all of us need a wide and purposeful education and that that cannot be delivered by so-called vocational training. Some of us here would argue most rigorously about that and say that there is a role for both in what is a well constructed, well resourced and intelligently thought out 12 years of schooling for our young people. Some people say that it is possible to create a general well-rounded individual as well as someone who will have skills to take directly into the labour market work force. The 1987 Commonwealth Schools Commission report entitled In the National Interest: Secondary Education and Youth Policy in Australia said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . there are good grounds for believing that the levels of education and training in a population are important factors in international competitiveness amongst developed economies. Recent OECD . . . figures show that, in the early 1980s, Australia ranked fourteenth out of eighteen OECD countries in the population of 17-year-olds enrolled in either full- or part-time education . . . The gap at that time was substantial between Australia, with only 59 per cent of 17-year-olds enrolled, and . . . countries like Japan, West Germany, US, Netherlands, Austria and Switzerland all of whom exceeded 80 per cent . . .

As Australia attempts to look at itself in an international world, as it attempts to look at its Australian students not just in a competitive sense but as individuals in general education, we must move towards the kind of retention rates which we have heard talked about tonight.

PARA.TAB: That dramatic rise in retention rates has been filled by the kind of works that have been done here and by a recognition by the community that, as society becomes more complex and more complicated, children are deserving of a knowledge and understanding of that. It is the objective of the Government to move quite a deal further down that way. The target of 65 per cent that was set for 1992 by the Schools Commission report has been exceeded in many parts of the country. The ACT leads Australia with its school retention rate, which is virtually 100 per cent. Queensland, where I live, was one of those slower places but it has moved further down the track.

When we look at the kind of tensions that occur, the way in which education operates and the demands which are made, inevitably we have to recognise that TAFE, for whatever reason, has been left behind. In what have been enormous strides in the 1980s in secondary schooling, universities and our largest industries, which have moved towards training councils, the one sector that has not coped with change, responded to change or been flexible enough has been TAFE. It is partly the fact that TAFE has been controlled by State systems. It has been under-resourced, and one must ask why. Obviously, for many people it had a very low priority. TAFE was seen as second rate. We have heard a number of other speakers talk about the demise of technical colleges as they were seen as being for those people who were less able.

Yet our schools have continued to pursue a syllabus for 30 per cent of their population. What a nonsense! Thirty per cent of our schools' population currently goes on to university and yet every child in those schools and in that system is geared to getting the inevitable tertiary entrance score. We are condemning and saying to 70 per cent of our young people, `Sorry, folks, we don't care about you. We know you'll fail before you start because only 30 per cent of you are going to get the kind of end result which we are working for here'.

TAFEs did not participate in this change. As the university sector has grown, TAFEs have simply marked time and slipped backwards. Apprenticeships have continued along their path. It was a case of the master/slave, as envisaged in medieval times. We saw evidence of time based programs—`It does not matter if you could learn in four months, four weeks or 14 months what you needed to know to be a highly skilled trades person. Ah, no, you had to serve your time because that was the way it was in the good old days'.

Many of our young people are rejecting apprenticeships. Industry is saying, `It's too costly. We're not going to do it. We don't want to participate in it'. People are saying, `I know I'm a trades person; I know somebody gave me four years of my time, but in the 1980s, when greed was good, we found a whole range of business people could not be bothered'. The kind of people who had traditionally used the TAFE system and had been part of it diminished as a percentage of our population. It is those kinds of factors which we must now change.

We have had a number of dynamics come together. Industry has recognised that if it is going to make money and if it is going to be part of our competitive world then it has to have a skilled work force. Part of developing that skilled work force is a change in the apprenticeship system, a change in the way in which we view our labour—not simply as people to be exploited but as people whose skills are valuable and can assist us down the profit path.

We have seen massive restructuring as well within the unions and the union movement. The Metal Trades Union has been leading the way in developing programs and training which will in fact take us into the twenty-first century. Gone are the incredible disputes; gone are the problems that arise when people develop only one, single, tiny base skill. We have multi-skilling; we have modules; we have competency based training. People show that they are able to do it and they are in fact then accredited. Indeed, this requires also the support of industry. What is it that industry wants; what kind of work force does industry need? Let us give it to it.

We see not TAFE systems per se but rather some individual TAFE colleges responding to that challenge and saying to industry, `Participate; be part of us.' We have seen schools where that happens too. I can cite Oxley College in my own electorate, which was a very old physical high school with a falling population but is now a dynamic, moving, educational centre which provides TAFE courses for its students and responds to the needs and demands of the adult population within its area. It also provides a whole range of courses in literacy skills and so on. It is responding and working with the local TAFE college because it is happening on an individual level. I am sad to say it is not part of a systemic approach. Indeed, that is where we must go. We must look to the operation of a tripartite system between industry, unions and government if we are to meet the challenge together.

As we look at the way in which we must work and develop, we have to ask, `What is it that we want for our young people? What is it that we as a community need? What is it that we have to create to become the clever country and to maintain a standard of living which all of us wish to maintain?' As I have said—and others have articulated it here—Finn is very clear that the hope for the TAFE system lies in enormous resourcing. Who has promised this resourcing? This Federal Government. It has promised $1 billion a year. What do we see the States doing? They are walking away from it because they are still too territorial. The nonsense of States rights and the nonsense of territorial pride has denied 10,000 Australians the chance of a TAFE place in 1992 because the States are not able to be bigger and to look to what are national goals.

In the course of inquiry by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training, we have travelled throughout the length and breadth of Australia and we have read many reports. Tonight, we have heard speakers from both the Government and the Opposition speaking about TAFE, entry-level training and the demands on the system, but not one speaker has cited a need for the States to maintain their territorial control. Indeed, industry has made demands that we need to be national, that a person who starts his or her course of study in Mackay in North Queensland should be able to travel to Melbourne and have it accredited; that a person who trains in Perth for the mining industry should be able to take his or her qualifications and work equally in Mount Isa. It is a nonsense in a country with a population the same as that of the Greater London Council that the States still manage and still wish to maintain control of what they know and recognise as an under-resourced and an underfunded series of separate entities, a TAFE system in this country which is denying our young people access to what is the most important facet of their education, which can take them into the twenty-first century.

Along with Finn, the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) and others, I exhort the States to take the money to enable the young people to participate in education and I exhort them to provide for those 70 per cent of young people in our school system whom they are trying to channel into a fifth-rate tertiary course. It is simply not good enough.

Hence, the Commonwealth is spending a good deal of money and time, and engaging in administrative channelling, as we move to a national curriculum, as we move to look at national assessments, and as we move to look at the whole range of areas that are offered in our TAFE system. As I have said, some of our unions have led the way in developing national courses and a national framework in which to operate. They see industry as being national. In fact, industry in this country is multinational. We have mining companies that operate not only here but throughout Asia. Indeed, BHP is even currently mining in the USSR. Of course, it is nonsense to suggest that the States should continue to control the system and say that only people who do these courses here are going to be able to be trades people in this little square of the world. As the world becomes larger and larger, all of us have to become part of it and participate in it.

As we consider this States Grants (TAFE Assistance) Amendment Bill, which is enabling the transfer of recurrent funding and capital funding for 1992 as well as developing some further recurrent funding for the coming year, we have to say that it is in the TAFE sector that we want growth and we demand growth. Our young people and our community see the greatest need for change in this area. It is there that industry and unions are trying to work towards an Australia that will take us into the twenty-first century. We must demand change not just for the individuals involved but for all of us as a community.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to address this House on the States Grants (TAFE Assistance) Amendment Bill (No. 2) and the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No. 2), which go to the vital question of education and how we are to fund and restore it to as healthy a level as possible in an Australia that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) himself has said must become the clever country if we are not to slide into some sort of obscure banana republicanism. The first of the two Bills seeks to provide TAFE for 1992 with the sum of $157m for recurrent funding and $215m for capital funding. The second provides for grants for financial assistance to the States, for the Northern Territory and for higher educational institutions.

PARA.TAB: It is unquestionably time that we paid greater attention to educational matters in Australia, and none of the speakers who have gone before me tonight have in any sense denied that. In recent times we have seen considerable debate about both university and TAFE education in this country, and that is entirely appropriate. Whilst it is true that these Bills raise no great policy issues in themselves, they do present an important opportunity to raise some issues of educational policies and of the future of Federal-State relations, as mentioned by the previous speaker.

Higher levels of education and training are, to a very great extent, the keys to lifting our productivity and efficiency and halting the slide in living standards and employment prospects that flow from our increasingly poor economic performance and burgeoning debt. Indeed, they need to be seen in the context of a need for a new and more enlightened approach to our workplaces and all that we do in them, including the way that employers and employees relate to one another.

The higher levels of skills accumulation, which are so badly needed in our workplaces, are, of course, in themselves very largely dependent upon opportunities existing for adequate job training and retraining and with it the willingness of employees to take advantage of those opportunities. Given that our living standards have slipped badly in comparison with those of other Western nations with whom we might like to think we share some sort of sense of equality or kinsmanship, there should be a sense of urgency about addressing these questions. I would certainly say that, given youth unemployment levels of up to 30 per cent, depending on where one goes in Australia, there must be a sense of urgency about retraining and offering better training opportunities to young people if we are to offer them and ourselves a future.

We cannot escape the fact that Australian levels of labour productivity growth have not been up to OECD averages. This has impacted rather badly on us, particularly over the last 20 years. Whilst it may be true that productivity has been increasing in terms of our relatively poor performance in past years, the fact is that when our performance there is examined against other similar economies a very poor record shows up.

During the years of the accord, labour productivity improvements have averaged only around 60 per cent of OECD improvements. This poor and relatively declining rate of labour productivity growth has had, and if we are not careful will continue to have, a serious long term impact on living standards and on our international competitiveness. It must be understood that as long as productivity increases are not forthcoming there can be no real growth in wages levels. I was interested to hear the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) concede that to be the case in this place a couple of weeks ago in response to a question that I put to him. Regrettably, it is a brutal reality that the ACTU seems determined to hide from its constituents in its unrealistic pursuit of real wage increases, apart from productivity based increases, in the current environment. It seems to me that the ACTU needs to be exposed; it is cheating both itself and its constituents.

It is against that realisation that we must heed Ivan Deveson's warning—and I have heard his report referred to many times here tonight—that the development of TAFE institutions must focus on `training the trainers'. We must seek to encourage a more enlightened, a more flexible and a more realistic approach to providing training in a rapidly changing economic and social environment. Deveson continued on to say that it is critical that the whole subject of training not be excessively burdened with the rigidities of the industrial relations systems in this country. It seems that it is vital that regulation and control over training courses be applied, again in Deveson's words, `with a light hand, lest the local circumstances and needs not be overlooked or circumvented'. Regrettably, although I see tremendous signs of progress on the part of some honourable members opposite, there seems to be precious little evidence that the Government, at least at a formal level, has caught this message.

This question of local circumstances is of great importance in rural Australia, and it is to rural Australia that I now turn my attention. Nowhere is greater freedom and the need to tailor-make training to the particular needs that might prevail more vital than in regional Australia. For example, Australia's farm sector traditionally not only has been highly efficient but also has managed to outperform the rest of the Australian economy in the vital area of productivity improvement. In the past, farmers and their families developed a wide range of skills and abilities in the pursuit of their family operations. They knew all about multiskilling, workplace flexibility and all of those wonderful concepts long before the ACTU even heard of them, let alone began to embrace them, or at least pay lip-service to them as being desirable.

Skills were passed down through families and between neighbours, adaptation to new methods and technologies were embraced enthusiastically, and it was all very effective. You, Mr Deputy Speaker, would know all about it, with your own background in the very heartland of my own electorate—the mighty centre of Baan Baa. Baan Baa is quite a metropolis. Currently, there has to be real concern that that outstanding performance that has been the hallmark of Australian agriculture is now slipping away, and there is no doubt in my mind that that is largely the result of a declining involvement and interest in ongoing training programs.

I was interested to learn that in the United States some 40 per cent of farmers account for 60 per cent of farm production. All of those 40 per cent have engaged in further education and the opportunity to upgrade their skills in farm management. That clearly highlights a direct link between high productivity and farmers with further education, an illustration that can be extended way beyond the realms of agriculture.

Primary production continues to be one of Australia's most productive industries and it should be noted that it is also one of the most internationally exposed—not for primary industry the featherbedding enjoyed by so many other sectors in our economy to this very day. I want to point out that it is essential to ensure that we remain a competitive force and make the appropriate alterations to our traditional farm management training to cope with ever developing business strategies and technological changes. No longer can our rural youth rely upon the accumulated skills that have been handed down as being sufficient for the operation of a commercially viable business. That, of course, is what farming is all about.

To ensure that Australian primary production stays in touch with the levels of those of our competitors, young rural Australians must begin to widen their knowledge of business and marketing practices. Regrettably, the figures are indicating now that only some 25 per cent of Australia's farm work force has advanced further than year 10 at secondary school. Whilst it is true that many have subsequently been heavily enrolled in relevant short courses and so forth, the reality is that much more will be needed in the future. We will simply have to address the need for adequate mechanisms to fund TAFE well enough to allow it to offer the courses and training that will keep rural Australia competitive. Again that is an illustration that extends far beyond agriculture. The honourable member for Braddon (Mr Miles) earlier tonight referred to the estimated 145,000 young people locked out of access to TAFE and related courses in Australia, and the 30,000 university student places that are simply not there.

Returning to my rural concerns, I want to speak briefly about the TAFE in Gunnedah, which is my own home town. Gunnedah is located on the Liverpool Plains in the north west of New South Wales. It is a town which services the surrounding farms, which are primarily wool, beef and grain oriented. There are three potentially major coalmines located in close vicinity; in fact it is estimated that the Gunnedah Basin contains some 42 billion tonnes of coal reserves. Significantly more coal lies under that basin than in the whole of the Hunter Valley. A substantial proportion of the population of the town and surrounding district is employed in one of those above mentioned industries.

I was amazed to discover that as of next year the following courses will not be provided by TAFE in Gunnedah as a result of funding cuts: stage 2 of the wool classing course, the associate diploma in accountancy course, an open-cut mining course, a coal processing course, a meat inspection course, and a shopkeeping course. Worse, each of those courses is a two-year certificate course, of which only one year has been completed by students currently enrolled. One year is yet to be completed and the only alternative remaining for those students if they are to gain the appropriate certificate or diploma is to travel miles to another TAFE where the relevant courses are still being offered. Alternatively, they will have to wait for the courses to be reintroduced in their home town, and to be quite frank I do not like their chances very much.

The question must be posed: just how much will this really cost the local community and, ditto, how much does this sort of penny-pinching exercise cost Australia at a time when it needs every export dollar that it can raise? We need to keep in mind that we are still talking about a situation in Australia where only around 20 per cent of the population live outside metropolitan Australia but they go on producing something like 80 per cent of the nation's export wealth.

Worse, it is my duty to record that other courses are to receive the chop. Reception duties and secretarial courses will go; the fitting, metal fabrication and welding course directed at the coalmining industry is to go; and the hospitality course providing training in cellar and bar work accompanying the hotel-retail management course is to go—I do not know how much use there is for that in Gunnedah, but perhaps that was to be an escape mechanism for those who wanted to leave. The farm bookkeeping course is to go—a very retrograde step. Training in explosives for both mining and agricultural application is to go. The post-trade refresher course for motor mechanics is also to go. Of course, that is to be deeply regretted, given the importance of the motor vehicle industry to remote areas—country areas—the rapidly changing technology that is involved and the need to ensure that there is a good pool of local mechanics who are abreast of technological developments.

Each and every one of those courses can be directly linked to the wool, beef, grain, mining, transport or meat processing industries which are an integral part of that Gunnedah community. The Gunnedah community is part of that 20 per cent which is responsible for 80 per cent of Australia's exports, which I talked about a moment ago.

We stress the importance of developing further skills in the farm sector. Here is a perfect example of how we are ensuring that it just cannot happen. Each of those courses is in high demand, not only by the students but also by the industries and the community as a whole. In fact, what is happening is that opportunity for development of skills and training, as is so typical across country Australia, is often simply not available. The capacity of each industry to grow and to compete internationally, to develop those hard earned and desperately needed export opportunities that this country needs so badly, is being curtailed. Gunnedah TAFE, along with so many regional colleges, has shown the initiative necessary to ensure that its service is flexible and able to cater for the rural vocational requirements of its students. But it is not able to continue to do so.

As I draw my remarks to a close, I want to turn briefly to the question of the Government's willingness not only to fund TAFEs but also to allow local TAFEs to enjoy the sort of autonomy that they need to develop the sorts of courses that are relevant in their particular situations. I want to express a concern that in the current debate about the need for greater levels of Federal funding for such institutions we not lose sight of the need for that individual, localised sort of flavour in the development of courses. I think that this is a critically important area. I do not really dispute the remarks of the previous speaker, the honourable member for Forde (Ms Crawford), but by referring to the Government's reluctance to let go of its centralised control, as seen in the other Bill before us, the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No. 2), I want to express my concern in this area.

The Industry Commission has described the current approach to regulation and funding of higher education as fundamentally flawed. It has said that, as a result, the Government and institutions have tended to make incorrect decisions about the number of tertiary places and how they should be allocated. In fact, the Commission proposed five policy options to enable supply to better keep up with demand for places in higher education. Those five options were: increasing government funding to institutions—which is the one the Government has picked up to some extent; charging up-front fees for non-funded Australian students; charging full fees with deferred payment through the tax system; varying HECS to meet un-met demand; and introducing a voucher system.

Like other speakers in this debate, I do not deny the need for increased Federal funding input for TAFE or higher education but, by the same token, I do not accept the need for maintenance of centralised control. The current problems of un-met demand and overcrowding are seen to be the result of the recession and record numbers of those aged 16 to 24 seeking access to higher education. Access to education in institutions is currently being restricted by quotas, unrestricted access to capital for development, government controlled and ever increasing student charges, bureaucratically determined education profiles and rigidities in employment conditions for staff. All of these restrictions remove key incentives for quality, efficiency and appropriate courses and adequate student places.

Therefore, I think we need to lift the ideological blinkers on this whole debate. In short, the attitude of both Government and Australians generally needs to be changed in two areas: firstly, we should not blindly accept that centralised control is acceptable and wise and the only way to go; secondly, we need to change the `She'll be right, mate; this is the lucky country' attitude.

The editorial in this morning's Sydney Morning Herald drew attention to that. It pointed out that there seems to be a belief, especially among student groups, that the educational process is somehow corrupted if students are required to make a financial contribution to it. An argument is mounted that when a system is free the notion of providing a service to clients—in this case, students—tends to be overlooked. The editorial goes on to say that not everybody ought to be requested to pay, that it is very important to maintain the principle that there are safeguards for those people who cannot afford to pay.

TALK.START.PARA: —They should have to pass, though.

—That would be a help. It is all a question of attitudes. But students perhaps would benefit from the additional money raised by TAFE if TAFE were to go down this road a little further. For instance, in New South Wales it may be possible to provide some more of those 90,000 estimated extra places that are needed but which are now not available because of budget considerations. The editorial goes on to say that most TAFE students want an education that is oriented to workplace skills, that if we were to go down that road the culture of TAFE might benefit and that the payment of fees would give students `greater access and influence on the power structure of the TAFE system' itself. I conclude by saying that we must be prepared to be more flexible and more open in our attitudes to these questions because in Australia in 1991 we cannot afford not to be.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jakobsen Mrs C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Other speakers in the debate on the States Grants (TAFE Assistance) Amendment Bill (No. 2) and the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No. 2) this evening have tended to concentrate on the Finn report and on the future of technical and further education, together with educational trends among young people in recent years. I guess in a way I will do that also. I would like to concur with the comments of my colleagues who have spoken previously in the debate, the honourable member for Port Adelaide (Mr Sawford), the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Gibson) and the honourable member for Forde (Ms Crawford), on these questions.

PARA.TAB: Vocational and educational training demands upgrading and national attention if young people across the country are to have their rightful aspirations and expectations addressed in a realistic way by government. However, I would like to take the House back briefly to a report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training entitled The Restless Years, to highlight that report's recommendations in relation to TAFE and vocational training transition for the post-compulsory years of school where students do not wish to continue on to higher education in the guise of a university. Of course, many people currently consider higher education to be related only to university. A number of points were made in chapter 14 of this October 1989 report of an inquiry into year 12 retention rates. The report states in chapter 14:

SPEECH.PARA: Every Australian is entitled to a senior secondary education. Devising means of ensuring this entitlement is a real option for young people ought to be the objective of all governments—both Commonwealth and State.
I am sure that honourable members would wholeheartedly underwrite that statement. In a second point, it is stated:
The Committee acknowledges the completion of senior secondary education by all young people would have significant and wide-ranging implications which are not at present well understood.
Of course, that has funding implications attached to it. The third point states:
To achieve the objective of year 12 for all, the community must focus on improving educational opportunities and outcomes for young people from educationally disadvantaged groups.
I interpose here to say that many of those disadvantaged groups are the kids who end up going to TAFE. The report continued:

The Committee found that the provision of financial support to young people from low income families can help remove some of the barriers to participation in education. Accordingly, it is important that financial assistance schemes be maintained and that support continue to be provided to those most in need.
We can read there `Austudy'. The report continued:

Family background can play an important role in influencing decisions about staying on to years 11 and 12. Efforts must therefore be made to ensure that the value of senior secondary education is widely appreciated in the community.

That is something the Federal Government has worked to achieve. Another aspect of the report which relates particularly to TAFE and to the discussion this evening is paragraph 14.9 of that chapter, which states:
The provision of relevant and appropriate courses in the senior secondary years is vital if young people are to be allowed to maximise the benefits of staying on—
that is, not to stay on for staying on's sake. It continues:

This means that schools must offer a broad range of practically oriented courses and that the traditional emphasis of Years 11 and 12 exclusively as preparation for tertiary entrance must be broken down. Necessary elements of this process are:
(a)that education authorities emphasise, and higher education institutions accept, that school-designed courses are educationally sound and can be used for tertiary entrance; and
(b)the wider development of school/TAFE links and school/industry links.

I think that those little points are worth mentioning at this juncture in the debate because, as the honourable member for Forde so eloquently said in her contribution to the debate, for far too long in Australia we have concentrated in our secondary schools on equipping students with the qualifications for tertiary entry when probably only 30 per cent of those students would pursue a tertiary life after school. Many of the students have another orientation, and that other orientation is, in fact, better accommodated by the provision of courses through TAFE particularly, or by other sorts of courses. That is quite crucial, and we should not forget it in this particular debate, as I know the honourable member for Forde has not.

PARA.TAB: It is also important to acknowledge that that particular report came well before the Deveson report and well before the Finn report, but it was not a report on TAFE. Of course, both the Deveson and Finn reports were much more oriented towards TAFE. As has been indicated in the debate already, the Finn report is the most recent contribution to the debate on young people's participation in post-compulsory education and training. In particular, Finn makes a point about the convergence of general and vocational education. He says:

SPEECH.PARA: Both individual and industry needs are leading towards a convergence of general and vocational education. There is an increasing realisation internationally that the most successful forms of work organisation are those which encourage people to be multi-skilled, creative and adaptable.

We would all agree with that. But also that was something which was said quite loudly and consistently by employers who discussed post-compulsory education with the Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training when we did the report The Restless Years in 1989. In other words, whilst employers have requirements of individuals once they join their work force, they most specifically want capable young people who have had a general education and possess an understanding of the world at large. We do not want to see people streamed in a very narrow way vocationally. We want to see them have access to vocational education at the same time as they have access to a general education so that they will not be captive in a very narrow area for the rest of their lives, which obviously is of no value to either the young person or, in the long term, to the employer or the economy. The Finn Committee, on national targets, stated:

. . . these imperatives should be recognised in the establishment of a set of new national targets for post-compulsory education and training which encompass schools, higher education, TAFE and other training, and which identify target levels for attainment as well as participation. In essence, the Committee proposes that almost all young people should take sufficient post-compulsory education and training to complete Year 12 or some other initial post-school qualification, and at least half should go on to higher levels—
I am sure they will. The Committee also proposed the following:

. . . governments should agree to introduce a post-compulsory Education and Training Guarantee whereby all young people would be guaranteed a place in school or TAFE after Year 10 for two years of full-time education or training or its equivalent part-time for up to three years.

That was also mentioned by other speakers in the debate. Finn also made mention of, and gave some degree of concentration to, the need for national curriculum principles, which was another area commented on by the Employment, Education and Training Committee in the report The Restless Years. We said that we must have a system in this country whereby we have recognition of certificates across the nation so that a student or an older person who goes through an element of training comes out with a certificate at the other end of that training which is recognised across the country. A national curriculum is also required.

PARA.TAB: The Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) is to be congratulated for his endeavours, and indeed his successes, in getting the State employment and education Ministers together to achieve some understandings in that regard. It has not been without some pain, I am sure. But it is a totally ridiculous situation to find that a person who is a podiatrist, for instance, in New South Wales and who travels to Western Australia has to re-sit podiatry exams. Often it would be a person in an older age group. Such people ought to be able to take that qualification—a very necessary one, I would suggest; with our ageing population it is probably one of the expanding areas of practice these days—from one State across the State boundary to another State without having to sit a new examination. They are not foreign countries, and that is something the States have to remember in this whole debate on qualifications.

Irrespective of the side of the House that we sit on—and I know that there are some people who disagree on one or other aspect of the TAFE debate—I am sure that we all agree that TAFE must not be seen any longer as the poor relation of higher education. It should be about skills, qualifications and competency, regardless of who administers it. I hope, indeed, that we are entering a new era for TAFE. Whilst there might be some resistance at the State level to the suggestions by the Federal Minister that the Commonwealth take over the funding of TAFE, I hope that the States are able to overcome those objections because it does make a lot of sense for the post-compulsory area of education in the higher education and TAFE regimes to be funded federally and for us to have the same goals and objectives for the TAFE system as we have for the higher education system in so far as 70 per cent of our young people are more likely to end up in that system than in the higher education and university system.

These days there has been a complete change in the ethos of higher education away from smaller colleges and towards larger universities through amalgamation and other sorts of changes, so it makes sense for the Commonwealth to take up the funding option for TAFE as well. The Minister, in a letter that he wrote to the State Ministers for education and employment, has quite openly stated:

SPEECH.PARA: It is important to emphasise that this approach relates to funding responsibility, not administration, planning and policy setting roles. In relation to TAFE, for example, a larger Commonwealth funding role would not mean a diminished State administration and planning role.

I think that the States ought to take note of that very small paragraph in the Minister's letter and realise that all that is involved is a change in the emphasis of the funding to ensure that national responsibilities for training are able to be met through funding of TAFE by the Commonwealth.

PARA.TAB: I was able to perform a very pleasant function on Friday last week when the Federal Minister was meeting in Melbourne, I believe, with State education Ministers. Instead of him, I was able to open a furniture trades complex in Balga, which is just on the fringe of my electorate. It was at the Balga campus of the North Metropolitan College of TAFE in Perth. The Commonwealth Government had contributed $12m to this new furniture trades facility which was planned and constructed in close consultation with the local furniture trades industry and which incorporates the most technologically advanced equipment in Australia and possibly the world. The Western Australian Government contributed $1.4m. I think that serves as a good example of the ways in which the Federal funding can make advances in TAFE that might not be able to be made otherwise because of the cost of capital works and the cost of keeping our training standards and equipment up to a level that makes the people who go through that training eligible for employment when they leave it.

In Western Australia the furniture trades industry itself does not have some of the equipment that is available at the TAFE furniture trades complex and it will be sending its own people there out of hours to learn how to use the equipment and probably to run some business from there. So that TAFE complex is able to use the equipment and the funds of the Federal Government in a very good and enterprising fashion. Under the new rules that apply to TAFE, it will be able to keep any money that it earns in that way for the expansion of the facility and the campus. I think that is also a very important change. For the benefit of the House I will read into Hansard a passage about the Balga TAFE furniture trades complex, as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . A combination of technical excellence, imaginative design and expert construction has created a furniture trades learning centre which can claim to be second to none in Australia. . . Designed and constructed by the Western Australian Building Management Authority for the Department of Technical and Further Education, the project is the first of three stages towards the full redevelopment of the existing Balga campus, which is located centrally in the northern suburbs. . . The 7,000 sq. metre Furniture Trades Department. . . is the largest of its type in the southern hemisphere, boasting a training facility for every aspect of furniture making under one roof.

Students who attend the Balga TAFE will be able to acquire an advanced certificate in furniture studies, which has been developed as a result of the cooperative efforts of the furniture trades study area of TAFE and the Furniture Industry Training Association. I was very pleased to see at this launch that the furniture trades unions were represented, the furniture trades industry was represented and, of course, the State and Federal governments were represented.

PARA.TAB: The new equipment in this project is worth about $2m, and computer controlled machinery valued at about $1m has been installed in the flat panel area. These machines were purchased under a joint industry-TAFE venture with an industry contribution of $10,000 to provide equipment for TAFE under the Commonwealth skills for Australia funding. That funding is another element of money from the Commonwealth which TAFEs have taken advantage of where it has been available to them.

As well as the traditional training, some emphasis in the new facility is on CAD-CAM—that is, computer aided design and computer aided manufacture—because of its important influence on the efficiency of manufacture in this day and age. Training will be provided for 430 apprentices doing cabinet making, machining, woodworking, upholstery, french polishing, saw doctoring and wood-turning. Also, 36 pre-apprentices and 110 advanced certificate courses in furniture studies will be catered for, as well as some industry requirements. About 15 people will be assisted through industry restructuring, customised courses, CNC training and CAD-CAM. There will also be provision for 24 persons from special interest groups, such as disabled, unemployed, community programs, TAFE and Aboriginal Access.

The BMA, which is the State government building authority, was awarded first prize at the Excellence in Construction Awards for the main building and was also a finalist in the same awards for refurbishment. The actual structure was quite revolutionary and has a unique design providing a flexible structure that can be altered in the future because there are no load bearing walls and the roof is supported on steel pylons and wires. So the industry will benefit—as will the trainees of the area, particularly of Perth—from this excellent facility which has been mainly funded by the Federal Government.

The industry is continuing to see technological development causing alterations to the manufacturing process and it needs to adopt many of these practices to maintain pace with the international marketplace. Given that many of the processes are now available to Australia as a consequence of this particular TAFE training facility, we will be able to undertake those processes in Australia, whereas previously certain elements of furniture manufacture would have had to be brought in from overseas. It will be an import replacement facility to a large degree and, because of the nature of the equipment that is now available, apprentices will be learning how to structure furniture in the way in which it is structured overseas. It is a rather revolutionary complex and one which I was very pleased to be associated with on the Minister's behalf. My colleague the honourable member for Stirling (Mr Ronald Edwards) probably would have been there also if he could have been, because it is on the margin of both of our electorates.

Colin Andrews, the Chairman of the WA Furniture Industry Association, was at the opening, as was Malcolm Goff, the Director of the North Metropolitan College of TAFE, which has another new campus, an open learning centre, in Joondalup in the northern suburbs of Perth. So there is quite a lot going on in Western Australia in the TAFE area. The State Minister has recently announced that there will be more money going into further places in TAFE this year, which I am very pleased to acknowledge and to thank her for. Nevertheless, the discussion over the future of TAFE must be resolved, and I certainly hope that it will be resolved in favour of TAFE as opposed to being in favour of either the Federal or the State government, because we want to ensure that whatever the outcome, it is the best for the students and the people who will use TAFE in the future. Of course, I would favour the Federal funding option. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Listening to the honourable member for Cowan (Mrs Jakobsen) one would not really understand the crisis that this country is facing in higher education at the moment. Listening to other members of the Government who have spoken on the States Grants (TAFE Assistance) Amendment Bill (No. 2) and the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No. 2), I found the optimism that they seem to exude quite surprising. My observation is that rather than moving towards becoming a clever country, we seem to be almost daily moving further away from it.

PARA.TAB: Earlier tonight the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Gibson) was taking up that hackneyed theme that we hear from the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) that the great achievement of this Government in education has been improving participation rates in high schools. There is no doubt that Government members can point to significantly increased participation rates; but when we look at the real reason for that, there is no doubt that most of those kids, or the great majority of them, are being forced to stay at school because they know that there is nothing for them when they leave school. There are no jobs available for them. That is the great legacy of this Government. I think it will take years for Australia to recover from the present position, in which jobs for young people have virtually disappeared. Almost in desperation, some of them are now staying in school.

Unfortunately, the school system has yet to entirely cope with their staying there beyond the post-compulsory years. Even for those who do stay, do learn and do want to go on to higher education, the cruel joke that is being played on them is that when they leave school they cannot get into universities or TAFE colleges. We find that awful figure of some 30,000 students leaving school and not finding university places available to them.

I always find it rather quaint when I hear the Minister and Government members trumpeting their great success in keeping kids at school, when the great irony is that they have done nothing much in practice to do that, other than to create an economic environment which means that kids are frightened to leave school. Their expectations of having access to higher education have been heightened; when they finally face the prospect, those hopes are dashed. I think that is a cruel situation and that the young people of this country have been badly let down by this Government. The problems that that will create for us in the future are almost immeasurable, and it will be a great challenge for the next government of this country, which will be a coalition government, to come to grips with them.

It is interesting that there has been quite a bit of discussion tonight about the Minister's proposals to take a greater interest in TAFE, if we could describe them in those terms. We are not quite sure exactly what he wants to do because he has not made it clear. As we read it, there is some intention to take greater control of TAFE. Of course, whilst he might have had some success in getting the Ministers to come together to agree that a national recognition of qualifications is desirable, that was a relatively easy project for the Minister to take on; it was one, of course, that made a lot of sense. We are pleased to see that there has been a recognition of the importance of that particular concept. I wish the Minister good luck in respect of his intention to take a greater degree of interest in or control over TAFE.

I see that already the education Ministers in the various States have pretty much given him his marching orders in respect of that particular proposal. The New South Wales Minister for Further Education, Training and Employment, Mr Fahey, was quite forthright in calling the proposal blackmail and describing it as `unacceptable'. The Bill that I am most interested in making a few comments on tonight is the States Grants (TAFE Assistance) Amendment Bill (No. 2). TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for McPherson (Mr Bradford) for giving me these few minutes, which I hope to use in the best possible way. Both the States Grants (TAFE Assistance) Amendment Bill (No. 2) and the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No. 2) deal with the funding of our tertiary institutions; namely, TAFE and the higher education establishments, being our universities and others which of course are almost totally funded by the Federal Budget these days.

PARA.TAB: However, I thought this was a good opportunity considering the focus on TAFE—although I think many of my remarks are very similar in both sectors—to put the simple question: why, in the area of vocational training, is it necessary for the Federal Government to be the arbiter of how things are done and, more importantly, whether we look at a TAFE college or a university, why does the Government have to own the shop?

In the case of TAFE, one of the more enlightening visits that I remember was to the Repco school for apprentice training in Melbourne—a basically private organisation doing wonders in the vocational training of young people. Nobody is there because he or she cannot get a job and has been shunted into the education system because kids can get Austudy when they are 16 but not the dole. Nobody is there doing that. They are all kids in employment; they are all being paid; and their employers have worked out that keeping them in full time training represents a better result than having them go one day a week to TAFE—and they are funding it.

But if the Commonwealth Government and the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services (Mr Baldwin) recognise the need for additional TAFE places—130,000 or something being a figure that is cast around—why are they not funding the students? Why does the Minister have to take the institution over and have it to himself to apply his great administrative skills? He is the guy who took nine years to get an economics degree and he wants to take over the running of all these institutions.

The best institutions I have seen are the ones that are run by the private sector. So why can we not have funding in these areas for students—for people? Why do we have to pack it all into an institution that then takes decisions that may not be in people's vocational interests? It is a fact that when we look into many of the programs offered in some universities and particularly at TAFE, which is aimed at vocational training, we find that some of them are not really the sort of training schemes that keep anybody in a job but the teacher. I am not sure that people would take those sorts of decisions themselves if in fact they received a government grant. Government grants, of course, are then applied to all others.

The honourable member for Goldstein (Dr Kemp) in his speech made a point that I make continually, and I thank him for making it again in this debate: why cannot Australians pay for an education when any foreigner can? In the current process we fund the institution, and the point I have made and wish to make again is that, if we fund the students, they can all be funded according to their individual academic achievement. If that is lower than the standard required, they either take a course that is less expensive or they add to that from their own resources. History is full of people who did just that and succeeded at very high levels, possibly because they carried that extra burden and it sharpened them up.

I think these sorts of points should be taken into account. But why do we say to Australians, `You have passed your exams, you are qualified to go, but unless you fit our system, because we have not provided enough places, you are not allowed to pay for an education'. Then we have the ridiculous arrangement of excellent universities, like the Bond University in Queensland, meeting high standards of education in a very small way. Students go there and they are told, `If you go to that dreadful place, you can't have Austudy'. Is Austudy a grant to universities or is it a grant to students? When I supported the legislation in this place, I thought it was a grant to students—I really did. But apparently a student cannot have it if he or she wants to go to a nasty old private university.

We have an amazing situation where I support the Labor Government in Western Australia. It gave the Notre Dame people a block of land, and my constituents and everyone have gone crazy. I have written back to say, `If you can get a university for one block of land, that sounds like a very good deal for the taxpayer'. Let us have some private universities and let the students who go there get exactly the same treatment as the students who go to a public university or TAFE. We can do that by funding students and saying, `Here is your right, this is your entitlement; go and spend it at any approved institution, be it a vocational training sector or be it one of the academic universities'.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Financial Legislation Amendment Bill is an omnibus Bill which will make a number of largely non-contentious amendments. The principal amendments relate to the issue, issue price, standard weight and composition of coinage, plus minor amendments to the Financial Corporations Act and the repeal of the Special Employment-related Programs Act 1982. The main provisions come under the Currency Act 1965.

PARA.TAB: It is not often that this House has the opportunity to comment on the Currency Act. Let us cast our minds back to that little jingle: `In come the dollars, in come the cents, to replace the pounds, the shillings and the pence', which goes back 25 years. This year, the Royal Australian Mint commemorated that occasion by striking a special coin, and I will make some comments on that later in the debate. As I say, it is not often that we have the opportunity to comment on the production of currency in this country. I certainly remember the cartoon character called Dollar Bill, and the jingle, `Out with the old and in with the new'. I think every child in Australia knew that song on 14 February 1966. It was certainly an excellent promotion by the government of the day to acquaint people with the changes to decimal currency.

Part III of the Currency Act 1965 deals with the issue, issue price, standard weight and composition of coinage. The principal aim of the amendments proposed by this Bill is to empower the Treasurer to make statutory instruments relating to the issue, issue price, standard weight and composition of that coinage. The Act currently provides for the Governor-General to make regulations for those purposes. Constitutionally, in virtually all instances, Acts of the Governor-General are required to be made on the advice of the Executive Council. As such, Executive Council approval is required before any instrument made by the Governor-General under part III can operate.

It was said by the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Free) in the second reading speech to this Bill that the current Executive Council approval requirement demands considerable administrative effort and can involve time delays—I will be making some comments further about the time delays that do occur—particularly as the Executive Council only meets periodically. Such delays can create difficulties for the marketing programs associated with the launch of new coinage collector items. Some concern has been expressed by coin dealers about the marketing programs, and I will return to that topic later in the debate.

Clause 4 will allow the Treasurer, subject to disallowance by Parliament, to determine the composition, the standard allowable variation from that standard weight, the design and the dimensions of coins. Of course, we all recall the design features of the original decimal currency when it was first introduced, and the fine work that was done by the artist, Stuart Devlin, in association with the coinage at that time. In addition, the Treasurer may, subject to disallowance by Parliament, specify in a determination more than one standard weight, design or set of dimensions, in relation to a coin of a particular denomination.

The principal effect of clause 5 will allow the Treasurer to make and issue coins of a standard composition specified in the schedule to the Act provided they are of a standard weight, and of a design and dimensions, determined by the Treasurer.

As I said, the Bill has three main purposes to simplify procedures for approval of new coins issued under the Currency Act: currently the approval of new coins, including variations to the design, metallic composition, et cetera, necessitate regulations made by the Executive Council; these provisions will authorise the Treasurer to grant the necessary approvals; and parliamentary scrutiny via disallowance procedures will be retained.

The coalition does not oppose these measures. The object of the measures, of course, is to streamline the administrative procedures. Concerns have been expressed to me by people who are involved in the marketing of coins. The criticism does not come from Mr Athol Nicholas of Bendigo Coins and Stamps, but I am indebted to him as he was able to provide me with a little background on the marketing of coins, the way it works, the role that the Mint plays and the role of the larger coin dealers and building societies, which have recently been incorporated into the marketing arrangements of coin sales.

When a new coin is to be issued it is important that there are no delays in the implementation of the marketing strategy because the marketing strategy can be very crucial to the success of the release of that coin and its value on the coin market. It is very important that those delays are eliminated, adequate time is given for the marketing arrangements to be put in place, and that the coin dealers, building societies and others who are handling the release are not held up unduly with delays in the marketing of those coins.

One special coin was the Anzac coin which was struck to commemorate the seventy-fifth anniversary of Gallipoli. It was much sought after, and I am sure it would be highly prized by those who purchased them. It was quite a unique occasion. I understand that coins were made available to the veterans from Gallipoli who embarked on that epic voyage. I am sure that the coin will have a very special place in their memorabilia.

Earlier I mentioned that a special 50c coin was recently introduced to mark 25 years of dollars. I refer to an article which appeared in the Canberra Times on 24 January 1991. I was aware that our currency had been devalued, but I was rather struck by the headline: `Special 50c to mark 25 years of dollars'. Is the true value of the dollar these days back to 50c? The commemorative coin, quite appropriately, has a merino ram's head on it, and it is quite striking. Obviously it will be much sought after. I understand from the initial release that it was intended that the coin would be a fairly exclusive and that it would be a much sought after collectors' item. I believe there was a surplus of those coins and that they have now been put into circulation. To some extent the free market price of coin sales has dropped because of the large number that has been circulated. At the moment they are bringing about 75c to 80c provided that they are in good condition.

Twenty-five years of decimal currency is an important milestone for Australia and that coin, having been struck, has obviously been accepted very widely. It is interesting to reflect on that time, when the Federal Treasurer was the late Harold Holt. He announced that Australia would be moving to decimal currency, and one of the first names thought up for a unit of currency was the royal. It certainly stirred a lot of discussion at the time. I think the name was discarded after about five months of furore when the debate about what the new coin would be called raged across the front pages of the metropolitan dailies. Of course, it subsequently ended up as the dollar and Mr Holt subsequently became Prime Minister.

When we think back to that time, it was quite a remarkable achievement because the banks were closed for only four days before the conversion. That is all the time they had to adjust accounting machinery and other mechanisms. It was a quite remarkable performance when we think about it. I wonder whether, with the technology we have now, we could achieve that in four days. The conversion program was expected to take two years but it was completed in total—that is, all the coin-operated machinery, cash registers, parking meters et cetera were changed—in 18 months. I want the Minister at the table to listen to this final line—it came in $28m under budget. I think it was quite a special achievement for those days for a project of that magnitude to be achieved within time and under budget.

Time has moved on, and we have had the announcement by the former Treasurer, the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating), that the 1c and 2c coins will ultimately disappear from circulation in this country. Those coins have not been issued after 1 October 1990. I think the next stage is 1 February 1992, when they will be totally withdrawn and will not be able to be used at all.

We have seen quite a change with decimal currency. The collection of coins is a worldwide hobby. Australia has taken a very important place in the scheme of things with its issue each year of mint coin sets, which are uncirculated, containing one of each denomination of the currency. Then there are proof sets, which I understand contain more individual specimens. I believe they are much sought after.

The Royal Australian Mint, in its annual report of 1989-90—the most recent one I could find—indicated that it had coin sales revenue of $24m. This related mainly to collector coins and special coins which the Mint strikes. It mentions its retail outlets—the Australian Association of Permanent Building Societies is involved, and I briefly mentioned the building societies earlier. It also produces 350 million Australian coins which are circulated each year. It really is a very large business. It is one that obviously we want to ensure carries out its marketing function and is not hindered by any administrative processes. This legislation sets out to improve the efficiency of those administrative matters to enable better marketing to be achieved.

The Mint also plays a very important role in producing things such as Commonwealth Games victory medals and Commonwealth Games numismatic coins for collection. Apparently it has achieved 99.99 per cent accuracy of stores function. I am not quite sure what that means but I guess it is that not too many go missing. I thought that was quite impressive.

I wish to make some brief comments about the minor amendments to the Financial Corporations Act. They will allow the Treasurer to delegate to the Governor or Deputy Governor of the Reserve Bank responsibility for varying and publishing the list of non-bank financial institutions. I see that the Chairman of the Finance and Public Administration inquiry into banking, the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Martin), is in the chamber at the moment. Obviously there is now a lot more interest in non-bank financial institutions. This is possibly as a result of some of the events which occurred in Victoria with the Pyramid Building Society and the Farrow Group. People are taking a much more active interest in the sorts of things that are occurring in non-bank financial institutions.

This amendment authorises the Treasurer to publish the list other than in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette. I would imagine that that is to ensure that members of the public know what a bank is and what a non-bank financial institution is, and to have ready access to that information. I have a copy of all of those non-bank financial institutions. I did not have to look too far down the column to see that the list included the Bendigo-Sandhurst Mutual Permanent Land and Building Society of Victoria. It is one of the oldest building societies in Australia and, I am pleased to say, one of the most successful non-bank financial institutions. I looked a little further down the list and saw the Pyramid Building Society, Victoria, still listed there. It is currently in the hands of the receiver and will be listed there until that matter is resolved. The role of non-bank financial institutions is a matter in which the public is taking a great deal more interest than it used to. The coalition does not oppose the move by the Government to ensure that people are made aware of what role the organisations play and who they are.

The last section of the legislation before the House involves the repeal of the Special Employment-related Programs Act 1982, which had its origin in the drought induced recession of early 1982. The Government is inclined to overlook the important part the drought played in that recession. The Act appropriated $300m from the Consolidated Revenue Fund to direct finance and grants to the States for projects that `contribute to the generation or maintenance of employment within Australia'. Under section 5 of the Act, no payments could be made after 30 June 1984. The $300m allocated under that Act represented the notional saving from the implementation of the Salaries and Wages Pause Act 1982 and from a wages freeze in the Commonwealth funded education sector.

Of the proposed $300m expenditure, $100m was said to be allocated to welfare housing. My electorate was the beneficiary of some of that housing. The rest of the money was intended to go towards capital works and repair and maintenance of equipment, roads, buildings and other infrastructure. It was estimated that the schemes to be funded under the Act would lead to a net direct increase in employment of between 6,000 and 10,000, with multiplier effects adding to the total. That legislation has now run out of time and is obsolete. The coalition does not oppose the amendment which removes that from the statutes.

The changes which have been brought forward are important. They will be important for the coinage side of things. The amendments to the Currency Act which are being made by the Bill will be to the advantage of Australia and to the Mint in its marketing processes. I trust that the Bill has a speedy passage through the other place.

TALK.START.PARA: —As has been indicated by the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Reid), the Financial Legislation Amendment Bill is an omnibus Bill that will make a number of largely non-contentious amendments to legislation. The Bill will simplify the statutory procedures for approval of new coin issues under the Currency Act 1965; it will remove the potential ambiguities in the wording of sections 13 and 14 of the Currency Act; it will effect what have been described as two minor amendments to the Financial Corporations Act 1974; and it will repeal the Special Employment-Related Programs Act 1982.

PARA.TAB: In my contribution tonight I want to concentrate on that part that talks about the Reserve Bank publication of non-bank financial institutions which falls under the Act. It is important to make one or two comments about what, certainly at first glance, would appear to be a rather inconsequential change but one which I think in the fullness of time—out of Yes, Minister—we might find has some rather more important connotations. I do so having spent over 12 fairly long and detailed months looking at the Australian banking and financial industry. I come to this conclusion having examined in some detail the growth in this country of what has been described as financial conglomerates—that is, a blurring at the edges of what is a bank, what is a non-bank financial institution, where the distinctions are drawn and how we seem to be moving more and more towards the establishment of a group structure of a financial enterprise which, firstly, has a banking arm, secondly, a superannuation and a life insurance arm and thirdly, perhaps, plays the role of some non-bank financial intermediary or institution.

In this country we are also seeing the growth of NBFIs and the sorts of products and services which they are offering in the marketplace in direct competition against the banks. We are seeing the growth of institutions like building societies, and some were mentioned by my colleague from the other side during his contribution tonight. We have seen the growth of the St George Building Society, which rates as one of the top 10 financial institutions in this country, and yet it is ostensibly a building society based in New South Wales. Of course, it is not; there are other building societies under its corporate umbrella in Victoria and Queensland. So it plays a very real part in providing access for consumers to a variety of financial services and the provision of financial products which very closely resemble similar sorts of products that are offered by banks.

The legislation proposes something quite simple. It enables the Treasurer to delegate to the Governor or Deputy Governor of the Reserve Bank of Australia the responsibility for varying and publishing the list of non-bank financial institutions which fall under the Act. It is very simple and very straightforward. The legislation talks about putting those particular non-bank financial institutions into categories. Clause 8 amends the principal Act so that the Treasurer may publish the varied list of non-bank financial institutions which were exempt from the application of the Act in such manner and form as he or she determines and not be restricted to the Gazette. It will be published in a location different from the Gazette.

The honourable member for Bendigo referred to the Farrow Group and the problems associated with the collapse of a building society in his State. It has been suggested by some that, if there was a clear distinction in the minds of consumers and if there was a recognition that there was a spectrum of risk in our financial services industry, many people would not have gone down a particular road in their investment decision. It has been suggested, for example, that if there were appropriate levels of prudential supervision, if there were appropriate levels of risk and risk maintenance, and if there were appropriate levels of some sort of standards, whether they be capital adequacy or whatever, people would have a knowledge of the safety and soundness of the Australian financial industry and would have a knowledge of which particular level in that industry they wanted to invest their life savings in. That is something which we should be striving to achieve. It is certainly something to which the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration, when it is tabled in this place on the 26th of this month, will bring a great deal of attention.

Simply by publishing a list in something that has not been specified, in other than the Gazette, is perhaps developing at least a concept of greater disclosure by providing people with a list, in something which is more widely available than the Gazette, of appropriate and approved non-bank financial institutions. That is a step in the right direction. People's access to that information is critical in allowing them to make a decision as to which particular institution they should invest their money with—whether it be a bank, a building society, a credit union or whatever. If that information is provided in a comprehensible form, if it is provided as a list saying, `This is a non-bank financial institution which is safe and sound and in some way is going to enshrine some degree of competitiveness for people', that is an appropriate way to go.

I hope that this amendment to the legislation will enable that to happen. I hope it will enable us to take yet another step along the road to greater disclosure and make information available to consumers. Even if it is in the form of a published list of NBFIs which fall within the ambit of the Financial Corporations Act 1974, it at least says to people, `Here is a list of so-called and approved non-bank financial institutions'. While we are striving for greater disclosure about those sorts of things, it is an appropriate way for consumers to have that information and, accordingly, to respond in terms of their investment decisions.

If, as has been suggested by some, this particular amendment will simply allow the Reserve Bank from time to time to publish that sort of information, maybe in its monthly bulletin, rather than in the Gazette, it may be wasted, as the information may simply be available to some people who have a broader knowledge of the source of other information about NBFIs, banking statistics and so on. How to make that information available to all consumers is an issue which should be addressed by the Governor or the Deputy Governor of the Reserve Bank when considering this matter at some stage in the future after the passage of the legislation. It is something which I think is important.

TALK.START.PARA: —But what are the practicalities of that?

—My friend across the table is asking what are the practicalities of making information available. I do think that there clearly are some difficulties in ensuring that information is made available. At the end of the day, there are even more difficulties in ensuring that, once consumers have hold of that information and are armed with it, they still make the correct decision. Nobody should ever take the responsibility for consumers' decision if they are provided with information. At the end of the day, the consumer is the person who will have to be responsible for the decision.
