TALK.START.PARA: —I do not propose to detain the house with a long speech tonight, because it was only on Thursday that I drew attention to the fact that over the past six or seven years this Government has been legislating by exhaustion. Tonight we have a similar situation, where the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) is about to put through the appropriate motions that will result in no fewer than 22 Bills being dealt with between now and midnight on Thursday night. As I understand it from the papers that have been circulated, the House will sit until midnight tomorrow night, until around 8 p.m. on Wednesday and midnight on Thursday to deal with these 22 Bills.

PARA.TAB: The Government has been very cynical in the use of the guillotine and is debasing parliament. It is unfortunate that the Leader of the House, who I thought at the beginning of this session was going to correct the errors of the past, has fallen into the same habit as he developed a few years ago. I say this in a very sincere way. At the beginning of the session the Minister, at my request, made available to the House of Representatives a schedule of legislation. I asked the question of him so that we could get an indication at the beginning of the session of the legislation to be dealt with and hopefully put some discipline on the Government to ensure that the legislation was brought into the House in plenty of time to avoid this occurring. I am sure that you, Mr Deputy Speaker, and the Leader of the House will recall my saying that I hoped that the action taken by the Leader of the House at that time would lead to a guillotine-free session. I was very sincere when I said that.

But what is occurring now flies in the face of what ought to happen in a well-run parliament. I know that the Minister has said on previous occasions that this is necessary because of the cut-off date in the Senate for legislation to be dealt with before the end of the session, but he knows that that provision prevails in the Senate. Therefore, the legislation should have been drafted, should have been processed through Cabinet, should have been processed through the Government party room and introduced in time for proper debate to take place and for there to be no need for a guillotine.

The Government is treating parliament with derision and on each occasion when the Government takes its action we intend to voice our protest. We know it has the weight of numbers and it can force on parliament whatever program it wishes, but we will take every opportunity to let the public know that proper consideration has not been given to the legislation by parliament, and indeed by Government and Opposition members. Shadow Ministers do all they can to ensure that the Bills are properly scrutinised, but on many occasions legislation is introduced on a Thursday and debated on a Monday.

I believe that tonight, for example, we will be debating the State Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill. That very important Bill was introduced on Thursday of last week, and here we are on Monday evening at 10.45 about to commence debating that Bill, which still has not been to the Opposition party room. It has been through our shadow Cabinet, the shadow Minister has had an opportunity to discuss the matter with some other members of the Opposition parties, but we have not had time to even process it through our party room in the ordinary way. Mr Deputy Speaker, we oppose the motion moved by the Leader of the House and we intend to vote against it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to add some words to those of the Manager of Opposition Business (Mr Fife) because there is another aspect to all this which gives a clear indication as to why Australia is in the mess it is in. The Government could not run guts to a slow butcher.

PARA.TAB: The simple facts are that we are not dealing with matters of great complexity. What have we dealt with on the guillotine today? We have dealt with the Government's tax measures and its Budget measures—things that it must have been discussing for months before they came to this Parliament. Today under the guillotine we have dealt with issues in which the Government has literally changed the figures in a piece of legislation to lift the threshold in certain aspects of the Medicare levy. A really big, complicated exercise that the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) and his Government have held up till now! The Government has had to guillotine it through the Parliament, when many of these matters could have been pushed through immediately after the Budget and given reasonable time and consideration.

The last time this happened I stood up and said it was a bureaucratic conspiracy. I am no longer convinced of that. Every Bill here tonight relates to the Budget, measures relating only to financial adjustments, in many cases just changing the numbers in a law, and the Government has not had the time or the organisational skills to do anything about it.

Government members wonder why we are still waiting for a third runway. They can give us all the smart alec answers they like and talk about due process. `Due process' means to learn to run the place properly. If they cannot run this place, how the heck can they run the country? It is outrageous. It is outrageous when we look in the Notice Paper and again see the sort of measures they are rushing through this Parliament at the end of the session. They should know what happened when they did it last time.

Part of the first part of this session was taken up with amendments to Bills as thick as the Notice Paper. Why? Because the Government got it wrong the first time and it did not have an opportunity to get the assistance of the Opposition nor, for that matter, its own back bench, which has been denied the opportunity in many cases to make significant contributions in this place that, firstly, might help the Government in running the country and, secondly, might just give those on the back bench a chance to show their constituents—whose support they are going to need pretty soon—that they have some interest and qualifications regarding these matters.

The Government is treating our side with contempt, it is treating its own side with contempt and it is treating the Parliament with contempt. As I said, I could accept that when I thought it was some sort of bureaucratic conspiracy. But when I come in here and see the sort of stuff we are dealing with under the guillotine at the moment—the literal changing of numbers—I know that it is the Government's fault. I know that the Government cannot possibly do the sorts of things it claims it is able to do. As I said, one is not surprised to see one million people out of work and to see a country in tatters because the Government could talk but it could not run—it could not administer. I am fed up with it. I think it is outrageous.

In a constructive sense, I add that if the Government is going to keep people up until 1 o'clock or 2 o'clock in the morning, it might even look—I presume the Government might do that now for the rest of the session—at what I think is a reasonably successful arrangement of going right through on Thursdays and not having an official lunch break. The Government might try to gather some extra debating time—just to give its own fellows a chance to have a bit of a say about what goes on in this place to demonstrate to their constituents what they do here. The Government should not treat its own backbenchers like dirt. It never lets its own members ask questions about their own constituencies. They have all got to take their dorothy dixers. The Government has had a few revolts lately, but it has treated its own backbenchers like dirt.

I can see the Leader of the House making a note. If he is making a note to say that we used to do that when we were in Government, I can tell him that we did not. I have seen dorothy dixers go from one end of the table to the other because our members, firstly, had an interest in their own constituencies and, secondly, had questions they wanted to ask of their own Ministers to test them out to see whether they were doing the job for their constituents. They were not prepared to participate in this charade that this Government runs when all its poor folk, whom it calls its backbenchers, never get the chance to act as proper members of parliament. The Government, with its guillotine, never gives its members a chance to debate or to ask questions unless it suits the Minister on the front bench. Is it not about time that they learnt how to write questions? Half the time they write them, they are out of order. This is the way the Government runs the place.

I tell the Leader of the House—he will shortly not even be the Manager of Opposition Business because he cannot protect his 2 1/2 per cent—that I have had enough of it. He will be back at university giving lectures on how he worked in government. Fancy, those poor kids will be taught administration by the Leader of the House. Thanks very much. There are a couple of people in Western Australia who run the Government's health policy whom I would prefer did not operate on me. Please do not teach my grandchildren, because I think there are other people who would do it better. That is the message.

The Government is not bringing forward serious matters that have just come up; things that have to be introduced into this Parliament right now. The Government's money Bills do and they should have been lodged the same night that the Government delivered its Budget, if the Government had any ability to organise at all. It is about time that the Government took this on board and demonstrated that it has some administrative skills.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to join in the protest this evening at this further action on the Government's part to guillotine through a large proportion of the legislative program. It seems that year after year the Government dawdles through the legislative year and then brings on a bundle of legislation in the dying days and expects it all to be dealt with in a few minutes. It is all very well for the Government to claim that the legislation is important, it needs to be dealt with, or the Macklin amendment requires it. The Government is well aware of all those circumstances on 1 January when it plans its year. If the Government had any capacity to manage the Parliament, clearly, the legislative program would be brought on in an orderly manner. It is easy to come to the conclusion that if the Government cannot run the Parliament it is no wonder it cannot run the country.

PARA.TAB: I thought that the honourable member for Lyons (Mr Burr) received some very interesting information on 16 October in answer to a question on notice addressed to the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley), who is sitting at the table. The honourable member for Lyons asked on how many occasions the guillotine had been used in each year from 1976 to 1990. I thought that the answer was most illuminating. Let us go back to the year 1976. Guess how many occasions the guillotine was used that year? Nought. In 1977 it was used twice and in 1978 it was used five times. There is a similar story for every year right through until 1985. When the Labor Government arrived on the scene in 1985 the guillotine was used 26 times. That was more than the previous years put together.

In 1986 the guillotine was used 40 times. When we got to 1988, it was used on 93 occasions to force Bills through the Parliament. In 1989, the guillotine was used 59 times; in 1990 it was used 78 times. Is 1991 to be a new record? There is a fairly good chance because a large number of Bills were guillotined through in the middle of the year. More legislation has been guillotined last night and tonight.

This is not a satisfactory way in which to deal sensibly with legislation. Is it any wonder that a very large proportion of these Bills has had to be brought back into the Parliament at a later stage to have mistakes fixed up. It is natural that when Bills are forced through with 10 minutes or 20 minutes debate there will be an inadequate debate of the difficult issues involved. Often, there is no committee stage at all. In fact, I recall an instance during the May session when the time allowed for debate had expired before the Bill to be debated had even been brought on. There was no debate at all on that Bill, let alone any opportunity for the Opposition to raise its amendments, let alone any opportunity for any detailed scrutiny of the Bill.

I have noticed on occasions that the Senate looks a little more closely at legislation and finds some of the obvious defects in legislation brought before it. It is not just the Government that makes errors when it tries to bundle 93 Bills through in a very short period; the bureaucrats responsible for drafting them, in the pressure of those circumstances, make errors too. Therefore, the whole process has to be done again in a few months time. Surely it would be more sensible to bring these Bills into the House systematically, a few each day of the legislative program, so that proper consideration can be given to each of the Bills. It is really not good enough.

On each occasion the Opposition protests. Usually the Leader of the House indicates that he is unhappy as well; that he wishes it was not done that way and that he will try to do better next time. But each year the story is just as bad, and just as bad for Australia. It is not just that the Parliament is being treated with contempt but, what is worse, the people of Australia are being treated with contempt. Ordinary Australians who are affected by this legislation have no opportunity to look at it. They have no opportunity to make any kind of input; no opportunity to indicate to the Government where the legislation is flawed; no opportunity to raise with the Opposition improvements that they feel should be made. To allow 10 minutes, 20 minutes or 30 minutes for a debate is, quite frankly, scandalous. To allow 2 1/2 hours for debate on some of the important pieces of legislation is scandalous.

Let us look at some of the legislation that is around. There are Bills of great significance—Bills which the Government believes will significantly alter the way our country will progress. Surely, if the Government is proud of its legislation it would want it to be debated in the House and subject to considerable detailed examination by all Australians. The Government would want to take credit for what is good. Instead, the Government hides behind shoddy legislation by dumping it in here in a great heap, expecting us all to look the other way. That is not good enough.

Sadly, our words are empty because the Government has the numbers to continue this gross abuse of power. The Government's use of its numbers to force through legislation without proper consideration is the sort of thing one would expect from a hillbilly dictator. I protest. I think it is time that the Government did better. If the Government is not able to do better, I think it should hand over to somebody else who can.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was talking about the other days, you stupid clot.

PARA.TAB: Just talking about tactics a bit, since the honourable member has raised the matter in this debate, I recollect that when we were in opposition we would operate on the basis that we would have a sort of specialised front bench question period on perhaps one or two days of the week and the rest of the time—or at least one day a week—we would let the backbenchers have at least a hit at it, or else we would operate with only two or three front bench questions during Question Time and then for the rest of that Question Time the Opposition back bench would have a go. I have never seen an Opposition back bench so massively dragooned as the back bench of this Opposition. Perhaps when one looks at the contributions of the honourable member for O'Connor, one understands some of the reasons for that.

The point was made that we have been heavy users of the guillotine, and that is true; I would not run away from that. If honourable members opposite bothered to take out the statistics on closure, they would find that there was a distinct difference on the issue of closure between the period when they were in office and our period in office. It was the habit of honourable members opposite, in controlling the House, not to use a guillotine provision to finish off legislation but to close debate on each individual Bill as it came through. The net effect is the same. One can decide that one will announce the program for the week in advance and tell people when Bills will be on and that they will be debated for a couple of hours, and put through a guillotine. That is one way of restricting debate. If one works out one's own timetable and then at the end of each particular two- or three-hour slot one closes the debate, that will have the same effect. It will not actually produce a guillotined Bill. Nevertheless, it will produce just as much restriction on debate. That, of course, is the technique that honourable members opposite used heavily when they were in office. We happen to use the guillotine heavily; we think it is better.

We have also been under a pressure that honourable members opposite were not under. I have really given up arguing with the Manager of Opposition Business (Mr Fife), who always anticipates what I might say about the Macklin closure and says it for me. The point, however, is this: if honourable members opposite really have a serious beef about what happens to them in the House of Representatives, it would not be a bad idea for them one day to go and have a talk to a couple of their senators and suggest that they do not support the continuation of the Macklin amendment, because it is actually getting more and more ridiculous.

At first, as I recollect, the Macklin amendment used to come into operation at the end of the month preceding the time that people thought that Parliament would rise. So it would come in at the end of May on the assumption that Parliament would rise by the end of June; and it would come in at the end of November on the assumption that Parliament would rise by Christmas time. The Macklin amendment for this year, for some reason or other, applies as of this Friday, which is effectively half way through November, and it is being pushed back further and further into the period of sitting. The effect of that, of course, is to put us in the situation in which we absolutely have to have Bills to the Senate by earlier and earlier dates.

The honourable member for O'Connor suggested that we ought to have all of our legislation prepared when we put down the Budget. It is an interesting thought. Were we to achieve it, we would be unique; we would be about the first Australian government on record to have actually achieved that. In setting government hoops of performance to jump through, it is an interesting test; but it is not a test which anyone has managed to pass to this point as far as the operation of the House is concerned.

We then come down to the way in which the House operates and one advantage which those opposite have which we did not have. About four or five years ago, we decided that we would proceed with a pattern of sittings of two weeks on and two weeks off. I think the pattern is probably all right, but the net effect of that and one other development—which I will come to later—has been very bad for Government business. Even though, technically, under the Standing Orders we sit for the same number of hours under the two weeks provision as we did under the three weeks provision that is, of course, a nonsense.

What we had was three weeks with three days worth of sitting. We now have two weeks with seven days worth of sitting, but longer hours. Those three weeks worth of sittings of course provided opportunities to introduce—if one wanted to—regular Friday sittings. Upon suspending the 11 o'clock rule, one had nine days worth of 11 o'clock rule suspensions as opposed to seven days worth of 11 o'clock rule suspensions. Effectively, that difference of two days worth of 11 o'clock suspensions per month, of itself, amounts to almost a normal day's additional sitting—depending how long it goes. If we add in the Fridays as well—which, as I recollect, we frequently did—it gives us even more time.

We have further penalised ourselves in the management of Government business in this House by adding to what those opposite never did and that was provide an absolutely guaranteed regular private members' time. One thing was guaranteed when we were in opposition, and that was—

TALK.START.PARA: —I have heard the same speech five times. I am sick of it.

—I must confess that I have heard the same speech from the fellows opposite five times; so if I can put up with it, the honourable member can put up with it. We used to get grievance time when we were in opposition, and we would get it regularly. But grievance Thursdays were every second Thursday, not every Thursday. We would have a General Business Thursday every now and then, but generally it was knocked off. Yet we have a policy of never wiping out private members' business on a Thursday.

PARA.TAB: When one adds that together, even though technically the hours look the same, we have effectively rendered government time one-half to two-thirds what it was before. I would argue, nevertheless, that the House is a better place for that. I would argue that what private members have an opportunity to do in here, by virtue of the fact that they do have that guaranteed period on Thursdays, is actually useful given that the Executive controls this place. It opens up the possibility for there to be decent consideration of private members' legislation and it opens up the possibility that there be a guaranteed hearing of private members' motions. It means that there is at least a point in time when the Government loses control of the business of this place and hands it over to the people who operate it, enabling them to come at us about it.

I do not particularly want to see this very important change tossed over simply because it would allow us more time to consider the sort of legislation we are debating here. There is no doubt at all that the guillotine would be far less severe if we could have gone into that three or four hour slot either last Thursday or this coming Thursday in order to get the legislation through. Also, I think the fact that the two weeks on and two weeks off is much better for members of parliament, particularly those of us who come from more outlying areas. Honourable members get a better chance to do their business in their electorate when they have two weeks straight away from the Parliament, rather than when they are operating, effectively, with one week away from the Parliament in the month.

So on the whole I think that the business of the House is better conducted, but there are penalties, and this is the penalty. Opposition members should not kid themselves that they did not impose similar—but, I admit, not as heavy—penalties on the Parliament when they were in government, because, generally speaking, they had sufficient time to operate without guillotine but with closure instead.

By and large, I think the Parliament works better now, although it does not work perfectly. We still have a problem with private members' time in that we are still not in the situation where private members' material can come on for votes, and I think that is something we have to think about collectively on both sides of the House a bit more in order to improve the quality of that time yet again. But it will be this Government that has done it. It was never done by any members opposite when they had the opportunity to do it when they were in government. Furthermore, as the Manager of Opposition Business well knows, I think I am probably the only Leader of the House ever to have released the Government's program—

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to begin my remarks on the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill 1991 by adding my voice to the protests which have come from this side of the chamber about the way in which the Government has put itself in the position of railroading this legislation through the Parliament. This Bill is not a complex Bill. It provides for funding of programs which were announced in the Budget, and there is no reason whatsoever why this piece of legislation could not have been introduced into this chamber shortly after the Budget. Instead, the Bill was introduced last Thursday and brought forward for the resumption of the second reading debate today, the following Monday, before we have even had a chance in the Opposition to put this Bill through the party room.

PARA.TAB: The only conclusion that one can draw from the handling of this legislation is that the Government holds this chamber in contempt. It is not interested in providing the Opposition or the public with the chance to fully debate and consider a Bill which appropriates well over $2 billion for schooling in this country. This debate will close in some 40 minutes time, and that will be the only allocation provided to this House to consider this immensely important series of programs. It is to the lasting discredit of this Government that these procedures have been adopted.

The funding provided in this Bill is directed to Australian schooling, both government and non-government. Firstly, as to the programs that are funded in this Bill, the Government has failed throughout its term of office to provide an appropriate strategy to ensure that Australian students have access to world class schooling. Its approach has been centralist and bureaucratic, and it has manifestly failed to address any of these significant structural issues which have damaged and continue to damage schooling in this country. In particular, it has endeavoured to impose ever greater bureaucratic controls over schools, both government and non-government, through its intrusive accountability requirements and its obvious movements towards an imposed national curriculum in schooling.

The Government has constantly worked to tighten the grip of the centralised industrial relations system which has been destructive in its effects on the status of teaching, the role of principals, and on the management of schools. Indeed, there are very few features of Australian schooling which have not been damaged by the centralised industrial relations arrangements. Yet the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins), who is at the table, has constantly sought to further centralise those arrangements and to create a national award and national teacher unions, always neglecting the fact that this centralisation continually takes away from the school and from the principal. It takes away the autonomy and the independence needed by those who should be leading quality education at the grassroots in this country.

The Government, through this system, has consistently excluded parents from an effective role in the government school systems. It has imposed decisions, increasingly through the Australian Education Council, with inadequate consultation with non-government schools, school systems and parents. It has further restricted parent choice of schools through measures such as the so-called—and one must say ironically named—new schools policy, the principle objective of which is to stop new non-government schools actually being established. Indeed, over the lifetime of that policy, since 1985, the Government has effectively prevented some 30,000 non-government school places coming into existence. It has failed consistently to lower the financial hurdles in the way of parents, particularly low income parents, exercising their right to choose a school which reflects their values.

The Government has failed to provide the community with satisfactory and objective measures of the standards of attainment of students in Australian schools. It has failed to push this measure through the Australian Education Council. It has failed to take any constructive action with the States in relation to the better assessment of the standards of learning in this country. Why? It is for fear of treading on the toes of its bureaucratic and union mates. Finally, the Government has consistently poorly targeted assistance to educationally disadvantaged students and deliberately neglected the severe problems of the rural educationally disadvantaged.

In responding to criticisms of this kind, the Government has concentrated on symbolic measures which have little or no positive impact on Australian schooling. I cite as examples of such measures the so-called effective schools program and the project on the quality of teaching and learning. These are poor substitutes for giving the community the information it is entitled to have, the schools the flexibility they need to do the job, the teachers the professional independence they require, and the parents the effective right to choose their child's school.

The Opposition will not oppose this legislation, but I foreshadow a second reading amendment which will condemn the Government for its restrictive funding policies for non-government schools; its operation of the new schools policy and the bureaucratic accountability requirements; its failure to recognise the real problems of language and literacy in Australia; and its failure to adequately address the problem of retention in rural and remote areas.

I turn briefly to the issue of the language and literacy initiatives funded in this legislation. A number of studies have shown the disturbing trend in which far too many Australian students not only are falling further behind the standards of the students in other countries, but also are too often possessed of basic skills too inadequate to provide a satisfactory foundation for effective participation in the workplace or as citizens in a democratic society.

It has been conservatively estimated that over one million Australians, many young and mostly from English speaking backgrounds—contrary to the view that the Minister seeks to present in this House from time to time—do not have adequate literacy to function effectively in this society or in the Australian work force. It is a national problem of immense magnitude.

The coalition parties have already pointed to the serious deficiencies of the White Paper produced by the Government, which was universally condemned in the submissions made to the Government during its Green Paper stage. In its proposals, of course, we see reflected the weaknesses of the Government's entire approach in this vital area.

First, there is no satisfactory commitment to the objective assessment of language proficiency. The funds for English as a second language program are not targeted to the students whose proficiency in English can be demonstrated to be inadequate, because the Government refuses to undertake such objective assessment, so those funds are much less satisfactorily targeted to students on the basis of the language spoken at home. Of course, many of these students in fact probably have very satisfactory language proficiency, but the Government is not interested in targeting such enormous funds as are provided through this program effectively.

Secondly, the programs do not clearly distinguish between educational and economic reasons for teaching languages other than English at school, and there is excessively centralised decision making in the Minister as to which languages will be taught. The Minister has taken it unto himself to decide which languages will be priority languages and which languages will be learned in school. The Minister has never outlined, and does not outline in the White Paper, a satisfactory strategy for ensuring that there is available in the Australian work force a level of competence in those languages which will actually be of assistance to Australian exporters as they seek to break into international markets. No, the Minister decides that he will determine which languages will be taught in Australians schools at all levels, presumably on the assumption that somehow out of this there will emerge a sufficient number of proficient speakers of those languages which Australia requires for trade purposes.

There is evident in these programs the most extraordinary confusion on the Minister's part between the use of languages other than English for economic purposes and the importance of language for its educational value as a rigorous area of study.

Thirdly, the Government is unable to act in this area without the heavy bureaucratic hand, and I cite here the fate of the ethnic schools program, where it appears that as a result of the Government's decisions, there will actually be a reduction in foreign language teaching by substituting costly bureaucratic control over this program by the school systems in place of the low cost, efficient program provided by the communities through their insertion classes. The Opposition condemns the Government's approach in this area, and I am pleased to say that it has been effectively condemned, particularly by members of the Italian community, who have provided the wider community and indeed mostly students from non-Italian speaking backgrounds with an excellent service in a non-bureaucratic and low cost way. Unfortunately, what the Government is proposing here will disrupt the provision of these classes and impose a much higher cost framework on the provision of such courses.

Fourthly, there has been a comprehensive failure by the Government to address the problem of English language literacy for mother tongue speakers, because the one thing the Government does not want to find out is effectively where the problems lie. It has been talking about this problem for years. It has been introducing symbolic measures. But the one thing it does not want to have is an effective objective assessment of language proficiency, because that will be too politically difficult for it to introduce.

Against these severe shortcomings the coalition has an alternative approach which it puts forward as a proper basis for such programs. Firstly, there is an undoubted need to concentrate on encouraging best practice initiatives to address literacy problems and to teach languages other than English.

Secondly, there is a need to encourage independent initiatives at the school level rather than at the State and Federal bureaucracy level, and to encourage competition for funds on the basis of cost and quality through tender processes. These principles, of course, were fully reflected in the school level excellence program for languages other than English which the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) announced last week.

Thirdly, policy in this area has to be based on an objective assessment of proficiency levels. Finally, at the school level, it has to be focused on the educational value of languages other than English as a rigorous intellectual field of study, while targeting particular languages at the elite level for trade purposes. Programs in this area should further aim to promote the broader goal of structural reform of schooling in the direction of independent government schools, accountable to a parent market.

Properly structured Commonwealth specific programs in this and other areas can make an important contribution to such a development. Of course, the programs which the Minister has put forward, such as the program for the quality of teaching and learning, are structured around the Government's industrial relations arrangements and will do precious little to encourage developments of the kind which we actually need to see in Australian schooling.

Because there are others who wish to speak in this debate, I will conclude my remarks shortly. I want to make some comments on the non-government school programs, which are of enormous importance to parents' choice in this country, yet the Government has consistently taken the view that it will do little more than tolerate the existence of the non-government school sector. It has put in place policies, such as the new schools policy, and the accountability requirements designed to ensure that the non-government school sector operates under the sorts of bureaucratic constraints which the Government has been compelled to place on it by its mates in the government school unions.

The Government has provided a funding regime for the non-government schools which will ensure that the more expensive of those schools, in terms of the level of fees charged, will become increasingly elitist. At the end of the spectrum, where low income parents are seeking to exercise choice, the Government has consistently held back the appropriate capital funding so that the quality of the infrastructure available to schools catering particularly to low income families has consistently deteriorated. There are some special purpose programs which the Government has put in place to target particular areas. These do precious little to address the general problems of infrastructure which are emerging in the non-government school sector.

Wherever one looks across the balance of programs being provided by the Government and funded through this legislation, one finds a totally unsatisfactory approach being adopted, one which fails to acknowledge the essential structural issues in Australian schooling, one which constantly focuses on what the Federal Government believes it can do by concentrating control in its own hands and, thereby, doing further damage to the schooling system in this country. I move:

PARA.TAB: I said earlier that this Government is responsible for a revolution in employment, education and training in this country. Growth and attention given by this Government to higher education and secondary retention rates has been spectacular. However, participation trends in vocational training, although showing average growth of 2.8 per cent per year, have remained virtually unchanged. Similarly, focus on primary education, which is largely a State responsibility, has remained somewhat static. I am therefore delighted that this Bill rightly focuses attention on aspects of primary education.

The objective of the new national elements of the literacy and learning program is to foster development of language, literacy and learning in early years of schooling—that is, from reception to year 3—by supporting ranges of major cross-State system activities, including development and delivery of cooperative professional development programs for teachers. I am pleased to say that negotiations are currently under way with Curriculum Corporation to manage the funding provided in 1992.

If I can take a lead from the White Paper on Australian language, there is no doubt that effective literacy is the key to children's personal and vocational development in preparing them for further education and training, life in the community and the world of work. While the literacy development of children is a responsibility of the whole community, schools have a key role to play. The White Paper goes on to say that by international standards Australia has in fact an excellent record in basic literacy. However, as new demands emerge for higher levels of literacy competence, we can no longer be satisfied with the standards of the past.

The White Paper also says that the early period of schooling is critical to literacy development. There is no doubting the evidence that, if children are not making appropriate literacy progress by the end of the third year at primary school, it is likely that they may not make up the gap through the rest of their schooling. The theme of early intervention, that prevention is cheaper and more effective than cure, is a major point that needs to be made again and again.

TALK.START.PARA: —Dead right.

—I thank the honourable member for La Trobe for his comment. To support that contention that early intervention in the education system is more cost effective than prevention, that prevention is cheaper and more effective than cure and that quick-fix bandaid remediation is too late, too expensive and has a terrible success rate, I would like to refer to two examples acknowledged internationally.

PARA.TAB: The first one concerns the Inner London Education Authority's major four-year longitudinal study of primary age schoolchildren which was published in the Times educational supplement in 1986. The study states quite categorically that the effect of schooling on children between the ages of seven and 11 can make a substantial difference to a child's future progress and development and, more importantly, that primary schooling is far more significant than the child's race, sex, age or background. In other words, schooling for children aged seven to 11 is the most significant determinant of future success, regardless of race, gender or socio-economic background.

The other example I wish to refer to concerns Australia and the evolution of the Reverend Ted Noffs's life education centres. Ted Noffs realised that after 10 years of never ceasing crisis counselling on drug and related abuse, nothing would be ultimately achieved if the situation continued to be tackled solely at the dire and desperate end of the road stage, and that breakthrough of a positive, lasting quality could come only through preventive education of all young children from about 4 1/2 to 12 years of age.

Many people in education despair at the contribution of some educational bureaucrats in this country. I personally despair at what is often a decided lack of common sense and nous in dealing with issues that directly impact upon our young people. In fact, the contributions of the honourable member for Goldstein give me the same pain. We do not build houses with cardboard foundations and paper walls and then put in chandeliers.

If a person is setting up a new industry, he first pays attention to the infrastructure necessary for further success, because that is common sense, that is nous. If education, whether it be primary, secondary, vocational or tertiary, is to be successfully restructured in this nation, a huge dose of common sense needs to be applied. The good schools strategy announced in the 1991 March economic statement makes a great deal of common sense. The strategy has two stages. The first one is the effective schools project administered by ACER, which is an investigation of the features of schools which are successful in achieving measurable value additions and outcomes over and above that which would have been expected.

The information collection phase, which involves surveys of school communities, is complete and it is expected that the final report will be available early next year. In 1992 the good schools program will concentrate on themes which have already emerged from stage 1—educational leadership, student welfare and behaviour, discipline and school organisation. Subsequent years will build on the 1992 report and full account of the report will be able to be taken from stage 1. Five hundred thousand dollars has been made available to the national project and the quality of teaching and learning to help fund its national schools project, the objectives of which support the good schools strategy. The focus on early intervention and good schooling obviously leads to good teaching.

The introduction by this Government of advanced skills teachers is particularly significant because it is creating a career path for highly skilled classroom teachers. Highly skilled classroom teachers will now be able to continue their careers while teaching students in the classroom. There will be significant additional funding under the award restructuring assistance program from 1992. The Bill provides for an additional $124m over the $50m originally provided in 1990 and 1991 to meet the Commonwealth's share of further costs already incurred in those years and to continue the operation of the program in 1992. There is no doubt that the quality of the relationship between children, parents and teachers and schools largely determines the quality of the educational program offered to our young people.

Another important aspect of this Bill is the community languages element of the school language and literacy program. The community languages element will operate from 1 January 1992 or from the date of royal assent, whichever is earlier. The Commonwealth will no longer make direct payments to ethnic community organisations but, and I hope that members of the Opposition are listening carefully, all funds will be directed to government and non-government school systems. However, those systems will be able to fund ethnic community organisations if they choose to do so. Funding levels are to be increased by 30 per cent in line with an initiative announced in the White Paper on the Australian language and literacy policy. This increase in funding will assist systems with the cost of aligning the community languages element with mainstream language provisions. Community language programs in primary schools expose children to the possibility of further language study, not necessarily a community language.

The White Paper states that proficiency in languages other than English is important because it enriches our community intellectually, educationally and culturally. It also contributes to economic, diplomatic, strategic, scientific and technological development. However, the point does need to be made that the level of languages study in Australia has fallen in the last 25 years. In the 1960s about 40 per cent of final year students studied a language other than English. Today fewer than 12 per cent of year 12 students study a language other than English. At the higher education level it is even more dramatic—fewer than one per cent of all higher education students complete a language at any stage of their course. The Commonwealth will offer incentives for languages other than English to all schools with year 12 students. States and Territories have developed their own strategies for teaching languages other than English. Five languages are priorities in all State and Territory strategies—French, German, Japanese, Indonesian and Chinese—while Italian and Greek receive special recognition.

As far as our trading environment is concerned, Australian exporters have nominated another list—Mandarin Chinese, Japanese, Arabic, Indonesian, Korean, Thai, Spanish, German and French, in that order. Obviously, it is not feasible to expect that all languages can be taught on an Australia-wide basis. Accordingly, the Commonwealth will focus upon a core of eight languages to be nominated by each State and Territory Minister. The eight will be chosen from the following group: Aboriginal languages, Arabic, Chinese, French, German, Indonesian, Italian, Japanese, Korean, modern Greek, Russian, Spanish, Thai and Vietnamese.

The goal of the Commonwealth is to increase the number of year 12 students studying a language other than English by 25 per cent by the year 2000. To assist in achieving this goal the Commonwealth will offer incentives to all school systems who will have total flexibility in the expenditure of those funds. The grants will be calculated on the basis of $300 per year 12 student completing a priority language up to a ceiling of 25 per cent of all year 12 students in the preceding school year.
In conclusion, when it comes to education of young people this Government is still ideas driven and is still delivering improvements to the Australian nation. I commend the Bill to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I am disappointed that I am under the gag and have so little time to speak, but I am delighted that the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) is at the table and I hope he will take the opportunity in the five minutes that I have available to listen to the few brief points that I would like to make to him.

PARA.TAB: I think there are four issues that we could address in respect of this Bill: primary schools, secondary schools, the country areas program and the Minister's White Paper on language and literacy. It is my view that our primary schools are the engine of the education system and from them flow all that comes after it. But we tend, I think, somehow to concentrate on the secondary schools and on universities to the detriment of basic learning and basic understanding. I suggest that the Minister, through the Department of Employment, Education and Training, should encourage the States to develop programs very quickly that go back and address the basics in education, the basics in literacy and the basics in numeracy.

There was nothing wrong with the time, when, on the back of the dunny door, hung the paper with the times tables. There was nothing wrong, when we learned by rote how to spell. There was nothing wrong with the time when we could count, add, multiply and divide without the use of calculators, particularly when the batteries failed.

In my view, it all starts in primary school and it has something to do with testing, because over the last two decades we quit testing—that is not the fault of the Minister and I do not blame him for that—nonetheless, we quit testing and it is time that we started testing again, to find out where we are. If we do not, then we may fail a great percentage of our young people.

I remind the Minister of the Wickert study, which said that 15 per cent of adults in this nation are functionally illiterate. I remind him that we do not know—because we have not tested our youth since 1975—to what extent our youth are illiterate. We do not know to what extent our primary schools are still feeding the illiteracy problem. I suggest that it is time we did know and that we know accurately.

The second point is that secondary schools in this country have a great deal to offer. One of the major points of the Finn report, which I have read so many times I cannot count, is a point I agree with absolutely; that is, we must do a better job of incorporating vocational training within the envelope of secondary education. If we can do that in the model of Hervey Bay Secondary College in Queensland, or Redlands or Roma, then I applaud those as models. But I also recognise the fact that there are other models that have something to offer, and they include Oxley Secondary College in Queensland, which offers cradle to grave education, and particularly Upwey primary and high school in my electorate, which now will offer education from prep through adult education, from 7 o'clock in the morning until 11 o'clock at night. That is not a bad community education concept as a model.

The third issue that I wanted to address is the country areas program. In that respect, assistance for isolated children and Austudy are in desperate need of relief from the assets test for families on farms and families caught up in the assets test who have businesses which are failing, for which they have assets, but for which they have little income. I suggest that one of the things we might consider in the tertiary sector is the creation of a distance allowance for students, to give those who live a long way away from the tertiary institutions the opportunity to attend, a bit of an extra allowance on top, and to give them a chance to catch up with their city cousins. That would not be a bad idea.

I turn lastly to the White Paper. I think the White Paper had some good things to say. It had some positive things to say, such as the fact that it acknowledged our illiteracy problem. It established nationally consistent guidelines for assessment of literacy skills, but it failed in that it did not suggest national testing and it failed in that it is based on this silly concept—if the Minister will excuse me—of Australian English and standard Australian English, and non-standard Australian English and Aboriginal standard Australian English, which is a bunch of bureaucratic nonsense.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise an issue concerning a person well known to most Victorians, if not many Australians, through his regular appearances on the Saturday evening variety program Hey Hey It's Saturday. While I must confess that I am not an avid fan of Hey Hey, that does not detract from the fact that Mr Ken Morgan, through years of hard work, helped promote the Toyota brand name and, in doing so, created job opportunities for many thousands of our fellow Australians, not counting the 200 or more people who were directly employed in his three dealerships in Melbourne.

PARA.TAB: As I understand it, Mr Morgan and his associates are taking Toyota Motors Corporation and Toyota Finance Corporation to court, alleging that the Ken Morgan group was misled and forced to sign a contract, under economic duress, that effectively led to the receivers being brought in. As that matter is set to proceed later this week, it would be wrong to go into the specifics of the case. However, I believe it is fair to say that similar problems concerning Japanese manufacturers and Australian dealers are arising with an alarming frequency.

Last year, the honourable member for Stirling (Mr Ronald Edwards) spoke of a number of Honda dealers who were told that their franchise agreements would be renewed if there were certain improvements to their premises. Despite those improvements taking place, Honda refused to carry out its side of the bargain. The honourable member for Stirling raised that issue because `others may move in and take up market share'. He then cited the fact that the Otsuka family of Japan took up one of those franchises.

In Victoria, we have seen similar cases. In the hard hit area of Geelong, Toyota moved swiftly against a local dealer, Mr Wal Lawler, who has been the subject of much publicity. Again, in the Morgan case there appears to be little consideration of what receivers have done to hard working Australian families, already devastated by the worst recession—some say depression—in 60 years. I know that the Motor Trades Association of Australia is doing a great deal to remove some of the worst inequities arising from the franchise laws but, for many Australians, the changes will come too late.

In effect, it is difficult to withdraw from the view that some overseas companies—Japanese in this case—are using an economic downturn to drive local dealers to the wall, thus picking up commercial property and dealerships at bargain basement prices. I concur with the honourable member for Stirling that it is an issue that ought to be addressed as a matter of urgency by the Trade Practices Commission. Companies such as Toyota ought to be aware of the difficulties a situation such as that affecting Mr Morgan can create. While I certainly do not condone racism in any shape or form, sadly, there are many Australians who will judge the case of a Honda or a Toyota crushing local businessmen as good reason for limiting overseas control of our major industries.

TALK.START.PARA: —On this day we remember two important events: one is, of course, Remembrance Day, which we should all remember with pride; the other happened in 1975 when it was said that we should maintain the rage. I believe we should, too. On this day in 1975 the Whitlam Government was dismissed. I remember it very vividly. I was painting my father's house when I was informed that a democratically elected government was dismissed by a Governor-General, something that I certainly find repugnant even today.

PARA.TAB: As we remember where we were when John F. Kennedy was assassinated, we all remember where we were when Whitlam was sacked. As a member of the Australian Labor Party and as someone who is proud of the Labor Party, I believe, recognising that it is this time of night, that the day should not pass without someone on this side of the House standing to say that we still maintain the rage.

It is important to note the way in which the Government was sacked. It was sacked because of the loss of life of a very fine man, Senator Bert Milliner, who was replaced by someone who allegedly should have been supportive of the Government—his name was Albert Patrick Field—but who then determined to vote against the Government in the Senate and consequently block Supply, which contributed to bringing down the Government.

It is interesting to note that today that the person who was involved in doing that has been acquitted, through British justice, of any corruption charges and is free. I acknowledge that. He is entitled to that freedom. However, his closest associate, Terry Lewis, is doing 14 years for corruption. We should not forget the memory of people like Bert Milliner and the late Kevin Hooper, and the principles that were torn up in 1975.

I do maintain the rage. I would like just to put on notice here tonight that, while it may be 1991, many of us who were in our twenties on that day find it repugnant that at a time when we can land rockets on the moon we can see also a democratically elected government of this nation sacked by someone who owes his allegiance to a different set of circumstances. I just wanted to place that on record, and I conclude on that note.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport and Communications, upon notice, on 20 August 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) How does his Department fulfil its obligation under paragraph 125D(I)(c) of the Broadcasting Act 1942 to correct interference with television and radio reception, particularly that caused by amateur radio transmitters licensed under the Radiocommunications Act 1983.
(2) How many complaints has his Department received concerning interference with television or radio reception caused by radio transmitters.
(3) Were any of the complainants referred to in part (2) advised to buy filters or other equipment to screen out unwanted signals; if so, how many.

(4) Has his Department engaged in discussions with the Australian Standards Council concerning the development of improved and compulsory standards to counter the lack of radio frequency immunity referred to at page 20 of his Department's publication Better Television and Radio Reception; if so, what was the outcome and recommendations of the discussions.
(5) Is he able to say whether standards operate in the USA and Germany which require certain immunity levels.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) My Department fulfils its obligations to correct interference to radio and television reception by providing a level of service that is scaled in response to the concern. The initial response is to determine whether a problem being experienced by a television viewer or radio listener is interference or simply a problem associated with the installation or location of the complainant. To do this the Department provides affected viewers/listeners with a comprehensive, illustrated booklet entitled Better Television and Radio Reception.
This booklet is designed to enable people to identify and resolve the majority of interference problems themselves, or to refer the concern back to the Department by means of a questionnaire.

With regard to radio and television interference caused by transmitters licensed under the Radiocommunications Act—including amateur radio transmitters—the Department has found that the basic cause of the problem, in the majority of cases, is the inability of the affected radio or television receiver to reject signals from transmitters located nearby.

Such `interference' can usually be cured when the affected party installs appropriate filters in the affected television or radio receiver. In some instances, the assistance of a technician may be required.
When the Department determines that a transmitter is the cause of the complaint, the owner of the offending transmitter is required to rectify the problem before resuming transmission.

(2) During the last fiscal year the Department forwarded 16,244 Better Television and Radio Reception booklets to persons complaining of reception difficulties. From these, 2,438 questionnaires were returned to the Department. Investigations emanating from these questionnaires revealed that approximately 50% of the concerns still related to immunity, whereas only 10-15 complaints were related directly to problems with a radio transmitter.

(3) No records are kept that would identify the number of complainants who have been advised to obtain filters or have their equipment modified. However, it is probable that nearly all complainants would have received this advice.

(4) It is assumed that the honourable member's reference to Australian Standards Council should be Standards Australia. The Department has had discussions with Standards Australia concerning the development of improved and compulsory standards to counter the lack of radio frequency immunity.
The Department is also working with supplier organisations to ensure that the industry as a whole is more aware of and responsive to this problem.

The Department liaises with Standards Australia as a forum during the development of standards for radiocommunications and broadcasting. Currently there are no agreed international standards for television receiver immunity to radio-frequency interference. The German administration has the only known comprehensive standards of this type. While immunity standards have been discussed it would be impracticable for Australia to impose standards of its own in advance of international agreement as there is no domestic receiver manufacturing industry.

If immunity standards were introduced now for new television receivers it is estimated that it would take ten to fifteen years before the majority of televisions in use would be equipped with this feature.
(5) In the USA—no. In Germany—yes.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 8 October 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) What is the function of the Australian Science and Technology Council (ASTEC).

(2) What is ASTEC's precise relationship with (a) the Minister for Science and Technology, (b) the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce, (c) the Prime Minister's Science Council and (d) the Chief Scientist.
(3) Is there any overlapping or duplication of functions between ASTEC and the entities referred to in part (2); if so, to what extent.
(4) Where does the responsibility for the formulation of federal Government policy with respect to science and technology lie.
(5) Has ASTEC's input been decisive with respect to any policy matters since 1980; if so, in which matters.
(6) What has been the relationship between ASTEC and successive Ministers for Science and/or Technology since 1980.
(7) Has any Minister for Science and/or Technology been invited to attend formal meetings of ASTEC since 1980; if so, on what occasions.
(8) Has any Minister for Science and/or Technology ever been invited to nominate members of ASTEC.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Australian Science and Technology Council was established as a statutory authority on 28 February 1979 under the Australian Science and Technology Council Act 1978. The functions of the Council, usually known by the acronym ASTEC, are to investigate, and to furnish information and advice to the Commonwealth Government in respect of, matters relating to science and technology, including the following matters:
(a) the advancement of scientific knowledge;
(b) the development and application of science and technology in relation to the furtherance of the national well-being;
(c) the adequacy, effectiveness and overall balance of scientific and technological activities in Australia;
(d) the identification and support of new ideas in science and technology likely to be of national importance;
(e) the practical development and application of scientific discoveries;
(f) the fostering of scientific and technological innovation in industry; and
(g) the means of improving efficiency in the use of resources by the application of science and technology.

ASTEC is empowered to operate by holding meetings, appointing committees, conducting inquiries, and collecting or arranging for the collection of information. The Council provides reports to the Minister (who, under past and existing Administrative Arrangements, is the Prime Minister) on matters related to its functions, either at the request of the Minister or as the Council thinks fit.
(2) (a) ASTEC consults with and provides information to the Minister for Science and Technology and to other Ministers with responsibilities for science and technology.

(b) ASTEC consults with the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce on matters of common interest. Consultation has been assisted by the establishment in 1989 of the Coordination Committee on Science and Technology, on which both ASTEC and the Department are represented.
(c) The Chairman of ASTEC is a member of the Prime Minister's Science Council. Members of ASTEC have attended particular sessions of the Prime Minister's Science Council.

(d) The Chairman and Secretary of ASTEC consult the Chief Scientist on matters of common interest. As noted above, ASTEC is represented on the Prime Minister's Science Council, of which the Chief Scientist is Executive Officer, and the Coordination Committee on Science and Technology, which is chaired by the Chief Scientist.
(3) No. ASTEC provides independent advice to the Government, based on the procedures set out in (1) above.

(4) The responsibility for the formulation of Federal Government policy with respect to science and technology lies with those Ministers with portfolio responsibilities in this area, and with Cabinet.

(5) Governments have received advice from ASTEC on a wide range of matters since 1980. In many cases, this advice has been an important input to the development of policy. Examples of advice of particular significance are contained in the reports Australia's role in the nuclear fuel cycle and Future directions for CSIRO. ASTEC has provided a substantial input to the development of the forthcoming White Paper on Science and Technology through its report Research and technology: future directions.
(6) ASTEC has had cordial and productive relationships with successive Ministers for Science or Science and Technology.
(7) Yes. The current Minister attended a meeting in September 1991.

(8) There have been no formal requests to Ministers for nomination of Council members. The Prime Minister invites the Chairman to nominate a panel of names for membership of ASTEC from which the Prime Minister makes his choice.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, upon notice, on 17 October 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) Did the federal Government undertake to contribute $16.5 million towards compensation to the Maryborough/Hervey Bay/Cooloola region, Queensland, for losses arising from the World Heritage listing of Fraser Island and the Great Sandy Region; if so, was any portion of that sum allocated in the $38 million compensation package announced by the Queensland Premier on 17 September 1991.
(2) Is she able to say whether the measures announced by the Queensland Premier amounted to less than half the total actual package of $37.7 million.
(3) Will additional compensation be provided; if so, when will it be announced.
(4) How many new jobs expected to last 5 years or longer have been created under the compensation package.
(5) Is she able to say what percentage of the jobs made available in the compensation package will be on the Queensland Government payroll.

(6) Is the federal Government ensuring that compensation funding provided by the Commonwealth is not being used by the Queensland Government to fund activities, including the thinning of pine forest plantations, which would have been conducted in the region with or without World Heritage listing; if so, how.

(7) Is the federal Government ensuring that new jobs created under the compensation package are genuine new positions and not the replacement of State Government paid employees with another group paid from Commonwealth funds; if so, how.

(8) Has any portion of the sum provided by the Commonwealth been allocated to the Maryborough City Council for its Wharf Street redevelopment program; if so, how many new jobs will be created within the program.
(9) Is she able to say whether the program referred to in part (8) was completed three months ago.
(10) Were Commonwealth funds used in the purchase of a $70,000 luxury four-wheel drive vehicle for use by a liaison unit associated with the compensation package.

(11) Is she able to say whether the vehicle referred to in part (10) has been used by any members of the personal staff of the Queensland Premier, including his social policy adviser, Mr T Grau; if so, who authorised its use.
(12) Will Commonwealth funds be used to subsidise the construction of a proposed new woodchip plant in the Fraser Island/Cooloola region.
(13) Was the federal Government consulted about the appointment of the Interim Board of Management and Advisory Committee for the Fraser Island and Great Sandy Region.
(14) Will the federal Government recognise the bodies referred to in part (13) as the management authority for the World Heritage listed area.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: Parts (1) to (12) The Commonwealth Government has decided to provide a total of $16.5 million to the Queensland Government in 1991-92 and the two subsequent years, as a conditional grant to supplement Queensland's own expenditure on structural adjustment assistance in the Fraser Island and Great Sandy Region. An agreement is currently being drafted for consideration by both Governments covering the detailed terms and conditions of this grant.

Management of the assistance program is the responsibility of the Queensland Government, and decisions about what particular projects are to be funded will be made by that Government. The use of Commonwealth funds will be subject to agreed terms and conditions, and the Commonwealth will require that Queensland provide it with acquittal details relating to the expenditure of Commonwealth funds.
The honourable member should therefore contact the appropriate Queensland Minister to obtain any additional information he may require.

(14) The World Heritage nomination outlines the proposed management structure. Further negotiations will be undertaken between the Queensland Government and the Commonwealth Government on the reporting, policy coordination and management arrangements to apply to the area, having regard to the arrangements for existing Australian World Heritage properties.
